pr_title: Prasad condoles the death of P. Madhavan
pr_content: The Minister of Information and Broadcasting, Shri Ravi Shankar Prasad has condoled the death of well-known Tamil film director, Shri P. Madhavan, who passed away in Chennai today. In his message, Shri Prasad said that Shri Madhavan was a famous filmmaker and his contribution to the Indian regional cinema will be remembered for long.

pr_title: World Bank to provide US$ 240 million for Allahabad Bypass Project
pr_content: Government of India and World Bank signed legal agreements for Allahabad Bypass Project, here today. The World Bank will provide a loan of US$ 240 million for the project. The agreements were signed by Shri Ranjit Bannerji, Joint Secretary (M&FI), Department of Economic Affairs on behalf of the Government of India; Mr. Michael F. Carter, Country Director, World Bank on behalf of the World Bank and Shri Nirmal Jit Singh, Member (Technical) National Highways Authority of India o! n behalf of National Highways Authority of India. The project has the following components: · Bypass Construction: Construction of a 4-lane divided carriageway, including service roads and a 4-lane bridge across the Ganga river. · Corridor Management: Implementation of a corridor management Programme. · Institutional Strengthening. The IBRD loan has a variable spread over LIBOR and is a US$ denominated loan with a moratorium on principal payment for five years and a maturity of 20 years. The project is expected to be completed by December 31, 2008.

pr_title: Government submits action taken report on the recommendations of JPC on Stock Market Scam
pr_content: Following the recommendations of the Joint Parliamentary Committee (JPC) on Stock Market Scam, a progress report on action taken by the Government and all concerned agencies has been filed in the Lok Sabha/Rajya Sabha on 12.12.2003 and 16.12.2003 respectively. The initial Action taken Report was submitted to the Parliament on 9.5.2003. Between the last Action Taken Report and the present progress report, a number of measures have been taken; which include setting up of additional institutional mechanism to keep a regular watch on the financial markets, establishment of a coordination mechanism with regulators and investigating agencies, reference to SEBI regarding the secondary market investment decisions of UTI in 89 companies identified by Tarapore Committee, setting up of Serious Frauds Investigation Office etc. The Joint Parliamentary Committee (JPC) on Stock Market Scam and matters relating thereto, submitted its report to Parliament on 19.12.2002. The report contains 276 observations/conclusions/recommendations. The Committee recommended that the Government should present its Action Taken Report to the Parliament within six months and thereafter a periodic progress report every six months until action on all the recommendations has been fully completed to the satisfaction of Parliament. Government has greatly benefited from JPC’s deliberations and its wide-ranging and valuable suggestions. While certain legislative measures such as amendment of the SEBI Act, and Repeal of UTI Act, etc. have already come into effect, other proposals like the amendment to the Securities Contract (Regulations) Act for ensuring demutualisation and corporatisation of stock exchanges and amendment of the Banking Regulations Act for better re! gulation of Cooperative Banks are before the Parliament. It has been the Government’s endeavor to act upon each of the recommendations/suggestions of the JPC in right earnest. Government is also considering bringing about other legislations like the Companies Law (Amendment) Bill and Government Securities Bill, 2003. Government will ensure that the remaining recommendations of th! e JPC are most expeditiously completed.

pr_title: President Kalam dedicates to nation the Brain Research Centre Calls for focus on mentally challenged children Dr. Joshi says NBRC will be turned into world-class institute
pr_content: The President, Dr. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam has called for a focussed attention on mentally challenged children, while dedicating to the nation the state-of-the-art National Brain Research Centre at Manesar, Haryana today. The NBRC which is a deemed university now, will be turned into a world-class institution said Dr. Murli Manohar Joshi, the Minister for Human Resource Development and Science & Technology in his introductory remarks. Dr. Kalam urged the Centre to see how, we can provide a normal life to the mentally challenged children, whose number has been growing not only in India but also in many developing countries. He called upon the Bio-scientists, Neuro scientists, Medical scientists, Electron experts, IT and communication experts, to jointly strive for finding solutions to brain-disorders that afflict the poor and rich, the male and the female alike irrespective of age. He also called for global participation in a comprehensive project to tackle the problem that is looming large over humanity. Mental health should form part of holistic healthcare, he said. Dr. Joshi said that brain research requires cutting edge technology and most modern infrastructure. Hence, the government took the initiative to set up this centre, with India being a pioneer in brain research and neuro sciences. He said the NBRC’s major efforts will be to coordinate and serve as the Apex Nodal Centre of brain research across universities and institutions throughout the country. Indeed, the current efforts to network 42 institutions in India, is the first step in that direction. Then global networking would follow. Dr. Joshi also pointed out that India has successful, on-going collaborative programmes in brain related disorders with leading institutions of United States, France, Russia and Japan.

pr_title: Wage ceiling for coverage under ESI scheme raised
pr_content: The Employees’ State Insurance Corporation at its meeting held at New Delhi this evening decided to enhance the wage ceiling for purpose of coverage of employees under the scheme from the existing Rs.6500/- to Rs.7500/- per month. The new ceiling will come into force shortly. Speaking on the occasion the Union Minister of Labour and Chairman ESIC, Dr. Sahib Singh said that the new wage ceiling will initially remain in force for a period of two years whereafter it would be reviewed for further enhancement. The upward revision of the wage ceiling had become necessary as over 13 lakh employees had gone out of coverage over the last five years due to crossing of the present wage ceiling, the Minister elaborated. On the other hand the exodus of insured employees had resulted in underutilization of infrastructural facilities. Another significant decision taken at today’s meeting was bringing down the threshold for purpose of coverage of factories and establishments to ten employees irrespective of the criterion whether power was being used or not in the manufacturing process. This decision is expected to bring thousands of additional factories and establishments under the purview of the Act and provide for social protection to a sizeable number of additional workers. The Corporation at its meeting today also decided to unbundle the integrated package of social security benefits provided under the scheme and give workers an option to select the need based benefits at a lower rate of contribution. The scheme will be introduced after necessary amendment to the ESI Act. The Corporation also granted relief to the workers in the lowest wage bracket and earning upto Rs.50/- a day by exempting them from payment of their share of ESI contribution. The exempted employees will, however, be entitled to all social security benefits under the scheme.

pr_title: PM flagged-off
pr_content: 1. PM flagged-off "Vigyan Rail" at Safdurjung Railway Station, at 10 am. 2. Andhra CM N.Chandrababu Naidu called on PM at 10, Parliament House at 12.45 pm.

pr_title: Purchase of Laser Guidance Kits/penetration bombs
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA Comptroller and Auditor General observed that the cost of procurement of Laser Guidance Kits in 1999 was higher as compared to figures arrived at by escalating the last purchase price using normal escalation factors. A contract was concluded with a foreign vendor in August 1999 for supply of Laser Guidance Kits (LGK) to fill up War Wastage Reserve (WWR) deficiencies as per approved scales and the prescribed procedure. The cost was higher because the proposals entailed supply of additional items, which were not separately priced in the contract, as well as a faster delivery schedule, etc. These LG kits were procured for General Purpose 1000 lbs Bombs. However, since these kits can be fitted to PB-500 Deep Penetration Bombs also, it was subsequently decided to procure these Deep Penetration Bombs too. Since bombs complementary to the LGKs were always available, question of reduction of shelf life of these kits due to mismatch with bombs does not arise. The urgency of procurement of LGK was based on the requirements to fill up the then existing deficiency in the War Wastage Reserve. Appropriate action has been taken on the report and comments have been sent to the Office of Principal Director of Audit Defence Services (Air Force & Navy) This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Shri Murli Deora in Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Reduction of avian menace
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA Indian Air Force has taken steps to reduce avian menace. These include vegetation clearance, use of zon guns, reflective tapes, bird shooters, establishment of bird hazard combat teams, denial of habitat to birds and use of microlites etc. This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Shri Ekanath K Thakur in Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Flag meetings between Coast Guard and Marine Security Agency of Pakistan
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA The Coast Guard has put forward new proposals for periodical flag meetings between Coast Guard and the Marine Security Agency of Pakistan. This proposal suggests alternate flag meetings, onboard ship of Indian Coast Guard/Pakistan Maritime Security Agency, in the month of April and September. Such meetings will facilitate frequent Repatriation of the Apprehended fishermen of both countries. This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Shri Rama Muni Reddy Sirigireddy in Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Induction of Mid-Air Refueling System by Indian Air Force
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA Indian Air Force has inducted air-to-air Flight Refueling aircraft but it has no weapon platforms in space. There is no proposal to add futuristic weapons system in space for Indian Air Force. This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Shri Rumandla Raamachandrayya in Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Refurbishing of life expired Missiles
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA India has a massive stockpile of missiles accumulated over the last 25 years which are now becoming life expired. Missiles have a fixed life which, depending on various parameters, is extended, from time to time, in consultation with Directorate General of Quality Assurance. M/s Bharat Dynamics Limited (BDL) has been nominated by the Department of Defence Production and Supplies as the Nodal Agency to carry out life extension/refurbishment of missiles held by the Defence Forces at a cost to be negotiated. It will be the contractual liability of BDL to ensure reliability of this refurbishment and upgradation. This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Shri Prem Chand Gupta in Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Enhancing the fire power of Infantry units
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA Modernisation of Infantry has been accorded the highest priority in the current Army Plan. The Army Infantry units on borders have been equipped with modern and effective fire power systems like 84 mm Rocket Launcher MK-III; Automatic Grenade Launcher AGS-30; Multi Grenade Launcher (MGL); Anti Material Rifle (AMR) and Flame Thrower RPO-A (FT). The reconnaissance and surveillance equipment include state of the art, equipment like Hand Held Thermal Imagers, Battle Field Surveillance Radar (Short Range) i.e. BFSR (SR); High Resolution Binoculars and Unattended Ground Sensors. All these items have been imported from various foreign countries like Russia, South Africa, Sweden, Israel, France, Germany and USA. The equipment is procured only after observing the prescribed acquisition procedure. Wherever required, and possible transfer of technology is also taken to manufacture such equipment in India. The Transfer of Technology (ToT) has been taken for Hand Held Thermal Imagers and these are now being manufactured indigenously by M/s Bharat Electronics Ltd. The ToT for Unattended Ground Sensors has been taken by M/s Nelco, a Tata Company, without any expenditure by Government of India. Battle Field Surveillance radar (SR) was earlier imported from Israel but now has been developed by DRDO and Technology has been passed on to M/s Bharat Electronics Ltd. In such case, there is varying degrees of indigenisation achieved. In all the cases of procurements for Infantry, deficiencies are being made up and older generation weapons and equipment are being replaced by modern weapons and equipment. Technology for Armaments like 84 mm Rocket Launcher, Automatic Grenade Launcher, Multi Grenade Launcher, Anti Material Rifle and High Resolution Binocular is also proposed to be taken from the original manufacturers from whom Arms, Ammunition and equipment have been procured after trials evaluations and found acceptable by the Armed Forces. This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Shri Nandi Yellaiah in Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Performance of Israeli Barak Defence System
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA Although the target was successfully shot down during one of the two firing runs, it was declared unsatisfactory because of certain technical malfunctioning. The malfunctions noted during the trials have been examined by the equipment manufacturer and a re-trial of the system is being scheduled shortly. This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Shri KB Krishna Murthy in Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Steps to boost combat efficiency of Army
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA Several issues relating to stagnation in officers cadre and older age profile of commanders of the Army were brought to the notice of the Ministry of Defence. In order to examine these issues, a committee under the Chairmanship of Special Secretary in the Ministry of Defence was constituted. The recommendations of the Committee were examined in the Ministry and some of them have been accepted in principle for implementation. As far as the structure of training is concerned, the process is itself dynamic. The training needs are based on changing threat perception, operational objectives and analysis of the weaknesses and strengths of the forces. Army also issues a Biennial Training Directive, the core policy document which lays down the policy for the entire Army. It contains the Army vision, training objectives and approach to be adopted in meeting the training needs of the Army. Training needs are continually reviewed, updated and monitored at all levels. This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Shri Vijay J Darda in Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Modifications proposed in Building Bye Laws for Delhi
pr_content: Centre has proposed certain amendments/modifications in the Building Bye Laws, 1983 for Delhi. A public notice to this effect has been notified calling for objections/suggestions. The modifications are as follows – (i) 6.5. (d) – “Plans submission fee for the approval of layout for development sub-division of land shall be calculated @ 10,000 per acre.” (ii) 7.5.2 – “Notice of completion – Every owner shall have to submit a notice to the Authority regarding completion of the work described in the building permit. The notice of completion shall be submitted by the owner through the licensed Architect/Engineer/Supervisor/Group as the case may be who has supervised the construction.” Completion plan and requisite documents are required to be submitted alongwith a fee of Re. one per sq. meter of the covered area. (iii) 6.8 – “The sanction once accepted through building permit shall remain valid for five years from the date of sanction for the residential, industrial, commercial buildings as well as larger complexes and multistoreyed buildings. The building permit shall be got revalidated before the expiry of this period. Revalidation shall be subject to the Master Zonal Plan Regulations & Building Bye-Laws, then in force, for the area.”

pr_title: NIEPA to conduct a survey on Foreign Eductional Institutions
pr_content: LOK SABHA The Government has asked the National Institute of Educational Planning and Administration to conduct a detailed survey on operation of foreign educational institutions in the country, covering various aspects including their accreditation in their own countries and the twining arrangements with local institutions. This information was given by Dr. Vallabhbhai Kathiria, Minister of State for Human Resource Development in written reply to a question in the Lok Sabha today. In his reply the Minister informed that the All India Council for Technical Education has notified AICTE regulations for Entry and Operation of Foreign Universities in India Imparting Technical Education 2003, according to which no foreign university/institution shall establish/operate its educational activity in India leading to award of diplomas/degrees including post graduate and doctoral without the expressed permission /approval of the Council. According to the Association of Indian Universities there are 144 foreign universities/colleges/institutions are offering various courses of study to the Indian students. Out of them 117 offer programmes on their home campuses and the remaining 27 are conducting programmes in India through their Indian partners. Though the Government has not received any specific complaint about fake foreign universities/educational institutions enrolling Indian students, with a view of averting such an eventuality Indian missions in major foreign countries such as United States of America, United Kingdom, Australia, Canada and New Zealand were asked to check on the antecedents and credibility of educational institutions from these countries. The feed back received from the missions has revealed that some of these institutions are not approved/accredited by the relevant agencies in their home countries and the Ministry has since approached Ministry of External Affairs before taking up the matter with the missions of the relevant foreign countries in India.

pr_title: Expert Committee set up by UGC on Universities
pr_content: LOK SABHA The University Grants Commission (UGC) has been set up a four-member Expert Committee consisting of senior academicians to conduct a review of the governance, organisation and management of universities in the country and to recommend a Model Act for universities of the 21st century in India with a view to prepare the Indian Universities System for the future. The Committee is likely to finalize its report shortly. This information was given by Dr. Vallabhbhai Kathiria, Minister of State for Human Resource Development in written reply to a question in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: DPEP results in significant increase in student enrolment
pr_content: LOK SABHAThe reviews and various evaluatory studies of the District Primary Education Programme have brought out that the programme has resulted in significant increase in enrolment, improvement in learning achievement, reduction in repetition rates/dropout rates with increased community participation, improvements in classroom processes, etc. The DPEP is supervised and evaluated through periodic supervision missions. So far, 12 internal supervisions and 18 Joint Review Missions (JRM) comprising representatives of Government and external funding agencies have supervised/evaluated the programme. The findings of the missions are communicated to the state implementing societies and to the education secretaries/chief secretaries of the concerned states for taking remedial actions and for further improvements. The programme was launched in November 1994 in 42 districts in seven selected states and subsequently extended to 273 districts in 18 states in a phased manner. After completion, the project has already been closed down in 144 districts on 31.12.2002 and 30.6.2003. At present the project is continuing only in 129 districts in 9 states. To meet the rising demand for primary education, the Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan has been launched as a national programme to achieve the goal of universalisation of elementary education. This information was given by Dr. Sanjay Paswan, Minister of mState for Human Resource Development in written reply to a question in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Environment protection under Mining Acts
pr_content: RAJYA SABHAMinistry of Mines is responsible for administration of Mines and Minerals (Development & Regulation) Act, 1957 (MMDR Act) which provides for development and regulation of mines and minerals under the control of the Union. Section 18 of MMDR Act enjoins upon the Central Government to take all necessary steps for the conservation & systematic development of minerals and for the protection of the environment. To ensure conservation and systematic development of minerals and protection of environment, all lessees of major minerals are required to get the mining plan approved, before actual mining can take place. The mining plan inter-alia includes assessment of impact of mining activity on forest, land surface and environment including air and water pollution, details of scheme of restoration of the area by afforestation, land reclamation, use of pollution control devices and such other measures as may be directed by the Central Government or the State Government from time to time. Mining lease holders are required to obtain appropriate clearances from Ministry of Environment and Forests and mining activities in ecologically fragile regions are subject to the environmental statutes and direction of Courts. This information was given by the Minister for Mines, Shri Ramesh Bais in a written reply in the Rajya Sabha today. The Minister mentioned that at present, no Bill prescribing limit of construction and mining work in Himalayan States is under consideration of the Ministry of Mines.

pr_title: Expansion of NALCO
pr_content: RAJYA SABHANational Aluminium Company Limited (NALCO) is currently implementing Rs.4,206.60 crore expansion project comprising of expansion of its Mining capacity from 24,00,000 TPY to 48,00,000 TPY, Refinery capacity from 8,00,000 TPY to 15,75,000 TPY, Smelter capacity from 2,30,000 TPY to 3,45,000 TPY and expansion in the capacity of its Captive Power Plant (CPP) from 6 X 120 MW to 8 X 120 MW by addition of 7th and the 8th units with additional capacity of 120 MW each. Out of this, the work for expansion of mining & refinery capacity and addition of 7th unit in the CPP has been completed. The smelter expansion project has also been mechanically completed but out of the 240 pots, only 120 pots have been operationalised. The remaining 120 pots are likely to be operationalised by April, 2004 after commissioning of 8th unit of CPP which is expected to be synchronised by February, 2004. NALCO has submitted a proposal for second phase expansion of the capacities of its Bauxite Mines from 48,00,000 TPY to 63,00,000 TPY, Alumina Refinery from 15,75,000 TPY to 21,00,000 TPY, Aluminium Smelter from 3,45,000 TPY to 4,60,000 TPY and Captive Power Plant from 8 X 120 MW to 10 X 120 MW at a total investment of Rs. 4,091.51 crore. The proposal is under the consideration of the Government. This information was given by the Minister for Mines, Shri Ramesh Bais in a written reply in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Chromite Reserves in the country
pr_content: RAJYA SABHAReserves of Chromite have been identified in Andhra Pradesh, Jharkhand, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Manipur, Orissa and Tamil Nadu. The data is available in the Indian Mineral Year Book published by the Indian Bureau of Mines, a subordinate office under the administrative control of the Ministry of Mines. As identified upto April 2000, Orissa has the maximum Chromite reserve of more than 11 crore tonnes followed by Karnataka 21.14 lakh tonnes, Maharashtra 5.43 lakh tonnes, Jharkhand 4.66 lakh tonnes, Tamil Nadu 2.82 lakh tonnes, Andhra Pradesh 1.87 lakh tonnes and Manipur 92,000 tonnes. This information was given by the Minister for Mines, Shri Ramesh Bais in a written reply in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: AICTE discontinues MoU system
pr_content: The All India Council for Technical Education has decided to discontinue with the system of MoU in the interest of the stakeholders of technical education. This follows the failure of the system to serve the purpose it was intended for. A number of problems cropped up in the smooth functioning of the AICTE, due to indifferent attitude of the Council of Architecture (CoA). An Mou was signed with the CoA only to facilitate visits of Expert Committee to the Architectural Institutions by it and nothing else. This too was done by the AICTE by delegating its authority of inspecting institutions to the CoA through an MoU. But it was found that the CoA was failing in its duty to meet the obligations fully under the MoU and was rather creating hurdles in the functioning of AICTE and Architectural Institutions, which were not in the interest of technical education. This was purely an administrative arrangement for better coordination of activities concerning technical education. Since the MoU was entered into, without any legislative action, its termination also did not require any such action and in all cases the final decision always rested with the AICTE under the latest act i.e. AICTE Act 1987. No legislative powers can be vested with any Authority through an MoU. In the light of the non-cooperation of CoA, the AICTE Executive Committee while reviewing the MoU recently, decided to do away with the system and carry out its own functions as per the mandate given in the act. Henceforth the CoA will only act as per the manner provided in the CoA act.

pr_title: Highlights of NSS Report on Consumption-Expenditure and Employment-Unemployment
pr_content: The National Sample Survey Organisation (NSSO) has released its Report on Household Consumer Expenditure and Employment-Unemployment Situation in India, 2001-2002 – the NSS 57th Round (July 2001-June 2002). Here are some highlights of the report: Consumer expenditure <U+F0B7> The all-India average monthly per capita consumer expenditure (MPCE) was Rs 498 and Rs 933 for rural and urban areas, respectively. Thus, the average MPCE for urban areas at all-India level was 87% higher than that in rural areas. <U+F0B7> For rural India, average MPCE of Rs 498 comprised Rs 276 for food, and Rs 222 for non-food. Food expenditure included Rs 96 for cereals and cereal substitutes, and Rs 93 for milk, milk products, vegetables and edible oil. Non-food expenditure included Rs 44 for fuel and light, and Rs 40 for clothing and footwear. <U+F0B7> For the urban sector, average MPCE of Rs 933 comprised Rs 402 for food and Rs 531 for non-food. Of food expenditure, only Rs 99 went towards cereals and cereal substitutes while Rs 148 was spent on milk, milk products, vegetables and edible oil. Rs 83 was spent per person per month on fuel and light, and Rs 68 on clothing and footwear. <U+F0B7> At the all-India level, the share of cereals and cereal substitutes in total consumption expenditure was 19% in rural India and 11% in urban India. <U+F0B7> There was a decline in the share of food in total expenditure. It was 55.5% in rural areas and 43% in urban areas during NSS 57th round compared to 64% in rural areas and 56% in urban areas during NSS 43rd round (1987-88). Adequacy of food <U+F0B7> At the all-India level the proportion of chronically hungry households (not getting enough to eat even during any month of the year) was 0.5% for rural areas and 0.1% for urban. As for seasonal hunger, 16 per 1000 households in rural areas and 3 per 1000 households in urban areas reported getting enough food only in some months of the year. Other living conditions <U+F0B7> The percentage of households living in dwelling units owned by them was 94 in rural India and only about 60 in urban areas; 34 per cent of households lived in rented dwelling units in urban areas. <U+F0B7> There was an increase of around 2.5 per cent in the proportion of urban households using LPG for cooking over the previous year. The proportion of urban households depending on firewood and chips for cooking also increased by 2% whereas the same for rural areas decreased by 2%, during the same period. <U+F0B7> About 99% of the households were dependant on kerosene and electricity for their lighting purposes in both rural and urban India. At the all-India level the percentage of households using electricity was 91 in urban areas and 52 in rural areas; the remaining households were, mostly, users of kerosene. Employment and unemployment <U+F0B7> Over two-fifths of the population (43%) in rural areas – and more than one-third (36%) in urban areas – were in the employed category as per their usual status (principal and subsidiary status taken together). <U+F0B7> The worker population ratio (WPR) according to the usual status (principal and subsidiary status taken together) differed between males and females in both rural and urban areas. In rural areas, the rates were 55 and 31 per cent for males and females, respectively. In urban areas, the corresponding rates are 55 and 14 per cent, respectively. <U+F0B7> Both for males and females, the unemployment rates were appreciably higher in urban areas than in the rural areas. <U+F0B7> In rural India, according to the usual status (principal and subsidiary taken together), about 68 per cent of the male workers and 84 per cent of the female workers were engaged in agricultural activities. In urban India, about 60 per cent of the male workers and about 46 per cent of the female workers were engaged in the tertiary sector activities as per the usual status (principal and subsidiary status taken together). <U+F0B7> The proportion of usually employed (principal and subsidiary status taken together) who reported themselves as not employed (i.e. unemployed or out of labour force) as per current weekly status was higher for females than for males. For females, it was 24 per cent in the rural areas and 20 per cent in the urban areas.

pr_title: Railways exceed freight target during April- November, 2003
pr_content: Indian Railways transported all time record 358.27 Million Tonnes (MTs) of revenue earning freight during the first eight months during the current financial year ending November, 2003 as compared to 334.45 MTs of such traffic during the corresponding period of the previous year, recording an increase of 23.82 MTs. This was higher by 8.88 MTs as compared to the proportionate target of 349.39 MTs. The performance of revenue earning freight traffic indicates buoyancy in the core sector of the economy as also in iron ore for export. Of the total revenue freight traffic, coal accounted for 161.28 MTs , raw material to steel plants 28.45 MTs , finished iron and steel from steel plants 9.03 MTs, iron ore for export 16.46 MTs, cement 31.42 MTs, foodgrains 30.25 MTs, fertilizers 17.59 MTs, petroleum oil and lubricant (POL) 20.85 MTs and other goods 42.94 MTs. During November 2003, the Railways transported 46.98 MTs of revenue freight, registering an increase of 1.43 MTs over the target of 45.55 MTs for the month. This was higher by 3.43 MTs as compared to the corresponding month of the previous year.

pr_title: Prime Minister to meet SC/ST Members of Parliament
pr_content: The Prime Minister Shri Atal Behari Vajpayee will meet Members of Parliament belonging to Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes in New Delhi on Friday. The meeting, organised by the Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment, will among other things discuss various schemes and new initiatives for speedy empowerment of the people belonging to Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes. These schemes and initiatives are for educational and economic empowerment of the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes to ensure that these communities are able to meet the challenges of competitive market economy and do not slide on the socio-economic ladder. The Minister of Social Justice and Empowerment Dr, Satyanarayan Jatiya, the Minister of Tribal Affairs Shri Jual Oram and several other Union Ministers belonging to SC/ST Communities as well as MPs irrespective of party affiliations will participate in the meeting.

pr_title: Stoppage of Indore-Bilaspur Narmada Express at Tarana Road Station restored
pr_content: The Ministry of Railways has ordered restoration of stoppage of Indore – Bilaspur Narmada Express (8233/8234)at Tarana Road Station in Madhya Pradesh with effect from January 10, 2004. The decision comes in the wake of a strong popular demand of the local people to this effect. The issue was taken up by the Minister of Social Justice and Empowerment Dr. Satyanarayan Jatiya with his counter-part in the Railway Ministry Shri Nitish Kumar. Dr. Jatiya had said that not stopping the train at Tarana Road Station would seriously affect the economic activity in the area and had pleaded for its restoration on an urgent basis. Tarana Road is the headquarters of the Tarana Sub-Division in Ujjain District. It is the nerve centre of the economic activity in the area. Earlier, Indore-Bilaspur train would stop at Tarana Road Station. But after its upgradation as an express train, the stoppage was abandoned.

pr_title: North East to have a Member in Board of Governors of Indian Institute of Forest Management(IIFM)
pr_content: Recognising the importance of the North-Eastern States, it has now been decided to include one Principal Chief Conservator of Forests of this region in the Board of Governors of the Indian Institute of Forest Management (IIFM), Bhopal, on rotation basis for two years to be nominated by the Central Government. The decision was taken at the Annual General Meeting of the Society of IIFM under the chairmanship of the Minister for Environment and Forests, Shri T.R.Baalu in New Delhi today. Addressing the members, Shri Baalu expressed satisfaction at the steps taken by IIFM to address the emerging capacity building needs of the forestry sector by giving attention to subjects e.g., livelihood, cultivation and utilization of medicinal plants, eco-tourism, joint forest management, environmental and ecological economics. He complimented IIFM for continuing to bag several national and international consultancy assignments. Shri Baalu assured the members that all efforts will be made to find a suitable Director for the Institute at the earliest.

pr_title: NCC Delegation returns from Singapore
pr_content: A ten Member NCC delegation including two officers and eight cadets visited Singapore from 04 Dec to 14 Dec 2003. During their stay the cadets participated in Camp Pinnacle 2003, visited various landmarks, historical sites and other places of interest. The cadets also stayed with the Singapore families to have insight into their way of life, closer interaction to share and experience their values and culture. The delegation led by Lt Col VP Tripathi the other members of the delegation were Lt Col KM Nachappa, Sgt Tushar Menon, Sgt Bhandari Jignaben RB, Sgt Vinitha BG, Cdt Sharath S, SUO Lata Shetly, Cpl Asha Nair, Cpl Heerak Das and Cpl Sruthi DRV from the states of Uttar Pradesh, Delhi, Gujarat, Goa, Karnataka, Maharastra, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Tamil Nadu and Meghalaya. The member of the delegation called on DGNCC Lt Gen BK Bopanna in New Delhi today. Lt Gen Bopanna commended the role of Cadets as young ambassadors of India, spreading the message of international understanding. He said visit of the Cadets will further strengthen the Indo Singaporean ties. NCC has an ongoing youth exchange programme with a number of countries including Singapore under which cadets from the both the countries visited each other to participate in various activities.

pr_title: Consultative Committee of Chemicals & Fertilizers Ministry meets
pr_content: The meeting of the consultative Committee of Members of Parliament attached to the Ministry of Chemical and Fertilizers was held at parliament House Annexe here this morning. Initiating the discussion, Minister of Chemical and Fertilizers Shri Sukhdev singh Dhindsa highlighted the role that chemical fertilizers have played during the post independence period in achieving self-reliance in foodgrain production in the country. He said the contribution of chemical fertilizers in increasing production and productivity in agriculture sector cannot be undermined. The Minister said the policy of the Government has been aimed not only to achieve maximum possible degree of self-sufficiency in production of Nitrogenous and Phosphatic fertilizers but also to ensure affordability to farmers by fixing uniform selling prices, to be applicable through out the country. Our country has today become the third largest producer in the world by producing about 146 lakh MT of N&P in nutrient terms. He said while India has achieved near self-sufficiency in production capacity of urea, in case of DAP and complexes, their installed capacity has bypassed the current level of domestic requirement. However, to meet the requirement of potash, the country will continue to depend entirely on import in the absence of its own reserves. Referring to the last month’s reports of inadequate availability of DAP from States like UP, MP and Punjab he said due to timely intervention by the Department, adequate availability was ensured in those areas. Department of Fertilizers is continuously in touch with all the State Governments so as to ensure timely and adequate supply of the major fertilizers for meeting their total requirement. Shri Dhindsa said that in order to further capacity addition in the urea sector, the department is currently in the process of seeking approval of the Government on the pricing policy for investment to be made in new and expansion projects of urea as well as existing non-gas based urea units converting to natural gas and LNG for feedstock. With this policy, he said, some more projects other than the expansion project of KRIBHCO, which is already under active consideration, will come up. Joint venture project in Oman having an annual production capacity of 16.5 lakh MT of urea is likely to be commissioned in June-July 2005. Over and above, Namrup revamp is also under advanced stage of implementation. With these projects, it is hoped that by the end of 10th Five year Plan, the production capacity of urea would be sufficient enough to meet the country’s entire requirement. Similarly, production capacity of DAP along with a reasonable mix of import, will be adequate to meet the country’s demand by the end of this plan period. He said the Department is formulating a revised policy for indigenous DAP and imported DAP and MOP based on Tariff Commission’s Report. Over and above, as stated earlier, for bridging the gap between the demand and supply of urea in the mid term scenario, the Government is in the process of formulating a policy for new and expansion of urea units, debottlenecking leading to higher capacity and conversion of existing costlier feedstock units to gas and LNG based units. The members made various suggestions to improve the production of fertilizers. They also emphasized the need to promote eco-friendly bio fertilizers balanced use of nutrients. The Minister of State for Chemical and Fertilizers Dr. Chhatrapal Singh and Members of Parliament S/Shri Chandran Pillay, A.C. Jose, Manoj Bhattacharya and Mohendra Prasad attended the meeting.

pr_title: Coal Bed Methane Project in progress
pr_content: RAJYA SABHAGas emitting out of coal mines is a type of natural gas which can be used for industries depending on its composition, heat value and other infrastructure for use of the gas. A demonstration project namely Coal Bed Methane Recovery & Commercial Utilization has been taken up by government of India in collaboration with United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), Global Environment Facility (GEF) at Moonidih and Sudamdih mines of Bharat Coking Coal Limited in Jharia Coalifields, District Dhanbad. The Central Mine Planning & Design Institute Limited (CMPDIL) is the main local implementing agency on behalf of Government of India. Bharat Coking Coal Limited is the co-implementing agency. The demonstration project has been sanctioned by Government of India in September, 1999 with the total cost of Rs. 76.85 crores and the project is now under implementation. The duration of the project is of five years. The objectives of the Project are as under: (i) To harness methane to minimize safety risks in mines, to utilizer potential energy source and to mitigate damage to atmosphere as other wise release of methane to atmosphere will be detrimental to environment. (ii) To bring to the country state-of art Methodology for resource assessment and Recovery Techniques for coal bed methane with due regard to the Indian conditions. (iii) To demonstrate utilization of the recovered coal mine gas for generation of power as well as compressed natural gas for use in coal dumpers. This information was given by the Minister of State for Coal, Shri Prahlad Singh Patel in a written reply to a question by Shri Rajiv Ranjan singh ‘Lalan’ & Shri Lajpat Rai in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: PM’s statement in Lok Sabha on the need for a financial package to Bihar for developmental works
pr_content: Following is the text of the statement of the Prime Minister Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee on the subject of need for a financial package to Bihar for developmental works in the state, in Lok Sabha today: "I learnt about the concerns expressed by the Hon’ble Members about the development problems of Bihar and I am here to assure you that the issue of effectively addressing the problem of poverty and backwardness of some regions, including Bihar has been engaging our attention and we have initiated the Rashtriya Sam Vikas Yojana (RSVY) in the Tenth Five Year Plan which has a special economic package for Bihar. Under this plan, projects in critical sectors requiring intervention have been identified and full central assistance will be given for their implementation. As you are aware, Central Assistance is being given to fund the State Plans as per the Gadgil-Mukherji formula under which 85% weightage is given to population and per capita income, which helps states like Bihar. Besides, Additional Central Assistance is also given for a number of identified programmes and special projects to finance the state plans. As a matter of fact, 83% of the plan outlay of Bihar of Rs.3320 crore for the current year is financed by central assistance. Now, I would like to elaborate on the efforts being made by the Union government for development of critical sectors in Bihar to which the Hon’ble members have drawn the attention of the House. Roads Out of 3408 km of National Highways in Bihar, 723 km is included for development of 4-lanes under the National Highway development Project. It includes 206 km of NH No.2 under Golden Quadrilateral and 517 km length of East-West corridor. The balance is being developed through the State Government and other agencies. A special project to upgrade and strengthen the State Highways is being funded under the RSVY. Improvement of Major District Roads/Other District Roads will be taken up under Rural Infrastructure Development Fund (RIDF) of NABARD. Rural roads are to be upgraded using Prime Minister’s Gram Sadak Yojana (PMGSY) funds. An amount of Rs.150 crore is allocated to Bihar per annum for development of rural roads under PMGSY. Unfortunately, no funds could be released in 2002-03 due to poor pace of expenditure by the State Government. Power At present, most of the requirement of power of Bihar is being met from the Central utilities. Further, the NTPC is planning to take up three mega projects in Bihar with an aggregate capacity of 4480 MW at an estimated cost of about Rs.18,700 crore during the Xth/XIth Plan periods. Besides, surplus power from the hydel projects of the North East will also be available for the region. It is not the availability of power which is problematic, but the capacity of Bihar to absorb more. Therefore, a project for strengthening the sub-transmission system in the State at a cost of Rs.365 crore is being taken up under the RSVY. Further, schemes for improvement of distribution infrastructure costing Rs.765 crore have been finalized under the Accelerated Power Development and Reforms Programme (APDRP) for completion within two years. With this investment, Bihar state would be able to utilize more power and improve its economy. Some members have mentioned about low Plant Load Factor (PLF) of state run power stations. NTPC is willing to take over Muzaffarpur power station, invest on its modernization and improve the PLF if the State Government agrees. Irrigation and Floods Although irrigation and flood control are state subjects, the Central Government has been alive to the problem and assisting the state through various schemes. Keeping in view the flood problems of North Bihar on account of rivers like Kamla, Bagmati and Kosi emanating from Nepal, the Government of India has already reached an agreement with Nepal for taking up investigations and project-report-preparation for construction of storages on Sapta Kosi and Sun Kosi. Discussions are going on for similar projects on the other two rivers also. The Central Government has also sanctioned four schemes in the flood-control sector for maintenance of Kosi and Gandak embankments, flood-proofing, extension of embankments into Nepal territory and anti-erosion works. It is for the State Government to take advantage of these schemes and utilise the available funds fully. Under the Accelerated Irrigation Benefits Programme, the Central Government has already approved seven projects to create an additional irrigation potential of about three lakh hectares. The drawals by the State Government in the last two years, however, have been far short of the ceilings fixed. The State Government should utilize the allocated funds fully for completion of the on-going projects. The Central Government has also agreed to fully fund the project for restoration of Eastern Gandak canal system at a cost of Rs.294 crore under the RSVY. This project will restore an irrigation potential of about 3.5 lakh hectares lost due to siltation and dilapidation of the canal system. A programme for installation of a million shallow tubewells to irrigate two million hectares is being taken up under the RSVY. I am told that by the end of this year, one lakh tubewells will be installed. I am sure, this programme will benefit millions of farmers of Bihar to improve their income from agriculture. Special projects for development of Mango, Lichi, Makhana crops and Spices in four districts of Bihar to improve its horticultural economy is being taken up. Railways Thirteen projects for construction of new lines, ten for gauge conversion, fifteen for doubling of lines and two for electrification have been taken up in Bihar. Rashtriya Sam Vikas Yojana (RSVY) Under this programme, the following projects worth Rs.2531.35 crore have been identified for implementation during the 10th Plan: Name of Projects Crore Rupees 1. Million Shallow Tubewell Programme (Subsidy Component) 578.28 2. Strengthening of Sub-transmission system in Bihar 365.00 3. Development of State Highways in Bihar 846.29 4. Restoration of Eastern Gandak Canal 294.00 5. Development of Horticulture (Subsidy Component) 36.78 6. Integrated Forest Management 351.00 7. Integrated Watershed Development 60.00 TOTAL 2531.35 Let me assure you that as committed by the Planning Commission, overriding priority will be given to the implementation of these projects which have been identified after wide-ranging consultations and there will not be any constraint of funds. Central assistance at the rate of Rs.1000 crore per year will be made available during the 10th Plan subject to actual utilisation. Central agencies will be involved in the timely implementation of projects. Under the Backward Districts Initiative, eight districts of Bihar, affected by extremism, have been included. These districts will receive grant at the rate of Rs.15 crore each per year for three years. My attention has been drawn to the exclusion of Bihar and Orissa from the normal component of this Initiative. I would like to assure all of you that eligible districts of these two States will also be covered under the programme. Thus, a multi-pronged effort is being made to address the development problems of Bihar. However, the Hon’ble Members will agree with me that successful project implementation requires conducive environment, effective administration and quick decision making from all concerned. The State Government needs to gear up its machinery for timely completion of projects so that the funds allocated to the State under various schemes are utilized and the intended benefits flow to the State and the ultimate beneficiaries. With the joint efforts of the State and the Central Government, I am hopeful that the initiative taken through the special Plan under the Rashtriya Sam Vikas Yojana will help trigger the development process in the State.

pr_title: IBP pays interim dividend for the year 2003-04 at 100 per cent
pr_content: Shri Ram Naik, Minister of Petroleum & Natural Gas, received the interim dividend from IBP Company Limited, a subsidiary of Indian Oil Corporation Limited, for the year 2003-04. A cheque for the amount of Rs. 5.75 crore (Rs. 5,75,82,900) was presented to the Minister by Shri A.K. Sinha, Director (Finance), IBP representing payment of interim dividend for the Financial Year 2003-04 at an impressive rate of 100 per cent of the equity. Smt. Sumitra Mahajan, Minister of State for Petroleum & Natural Gas and Shri B.K. Chaturvedi, Secretary (P&NG) were also present on the occasion along with the Senior Officers of the Ministry and IBP Company. The Government currently holds 26% of the paid-up capital of the Company while IOC holds 53.58% of the Company’s paid-up share capital. IBP is simultaneously paying to IOC a sum of Rs. 11,86,72,620/- as interim dividend on the shares held by the IOC. During the first half of current year, IBP has recorded a turnover of Rs. 4847 crore as against Rs. 4600 crore in the corresponding period of last year. The profit before tax and profit after tax of the company during the said half year period was Rs. 146.77 crore and Rs. 81.09 crore as against Rs. 185.13 crore and Rs. 87.75 crore respectively in the full financial year 2002-03. The profit has been achieved despite absorbing significant under-recovery of subsidy on account of SKO (PDS) and LPG (domestic) and under-recovery of freight for sales in inland locations in the post-APM period. The paid-up capital of the Company is currently Rs. 22.15 crore while its accumulated reserves aggregate Rs. 476.71 crore. During the financial year 2002-03, IBP commissioned 523 new Retail Outlets in a single year which was the highest amongst the Oil Marketing Companies and an all-time record. The tempo has been maintained this year with the commissioning of 215 new outlets and the Retail network at the close of November 2003 stands at 2294 retail outlets and 378 SKO/LDO dealerships.

pr_title: Hydel Power Delvelopment Policy, 1998
pr_content: RAJYA SABHAShri Anant G. Geete, Minister of Power, informed the Rajya Sabha while replying to a question on Hydel Power Development Policy, formulated in the year 1998 that under this Policy, small hydel projects upto a capacity of 25 MW were transferred to the Ministry of Non-Conventional Energy Sources (MNES) to provide greater thrust for its development. As per information provided by MNES, there is an estimated potential of about 15,000 MW in the country from Small Hydel Projects (SHP) upto 25 MW station capacity. So far, 4,233 small hydel potential sites aggregating about 10,324 MW capacity have been identified. A total number of 466 SHP projects (upto 25 MW) with aggregate capacity of 1,530 MW has been set up which include 339 MW capacity commissioned after 1.4.1998. Similarly, 196 projects aggregating to about 610 MW are presently under construction. Referring to the policy Shri Geete said that with a view to accelerating the pace of hydro-electric power development in the country, the Government formulated the Policy on Hydro Power Development in 1998. The aim of the policy is to initiate measures to check the declining trend in the share of hydro in the overall energy generation in the country and to exploit the large hydroelectric potential available, especially in the North and North-Eastern region. The objectives of the policy inter-alia include promotion of small and mini hydel projects. The small and mini hydel potential can provide a solution for the energy problems in remote and hilly areas where extension of the grid system is comparatively uneconomical and also along the canal systems. Small hydro projects can be developed in a shorter timeframe as well as with a lower capital investment. They also involve fewer environment and rehabilitation and resettlement problems. In reply to another question Smt. Jayawanti Mehta, Minister of State for Power, informed the House in a written reply that through a process of countrywide consultation, 162 hydro-electric schemes with an estimated capacity of 50,560 MW have been identified for preparation of feasibility studies. This initiative for tapping 50,000 MW of hydro power was launched by the Prime Minister on May 24, 2003 and will pave the way for the creation of a shelf of projects which will be implemented in the next two Five Year Plans. This exercise is being undertaken by various organisations under the overall coordination of Central Electricity Authority.

pr_title: Press Communique
pr_content: The President is pleased to appoint Shri Justice Mangat Ram Verma, Additional Judge of the Himachal Pradesh High Court, to be a Judge of the Himachal Pradesh High Court with effect from the date he assumes charge of his office.

pr_title: A delegation led by Union Minister Shri C.P. Thakur called on PM for inclusion of ‘Maithili’ language in the Constitution at 10 Parliament House, at 12.30 pm
pr_content: 1. A delegation led by Union Minister Shri C.P. Thakur called on PM for inclusion of ‘Maithili’ language in the Constitution at 10 Parliament House, at 12.30 pm. 2. A delegation led by Shri Mallikarjun Kharge, Home Minister, Govt of Karnataka called on PM regarding drought related issues in Karnataka, at 10, Parliament House, at 12.45 pm. 3. PM attended a cultural evening at the residence of the Vice President Shri Bhairon Singh Shekhawat, at 6.30 pm, at the latter’s residence.

pr_title: Recruitment of additional workers
pr_content: LOK SABHA At present, Railways propose to recruit around 20,000 Group ‘D’ personnel. The process of recruitment was scheduled to be completed by February 2004. However, in view of the recent incidents in Assam, Bihar and Mumbai, the process may be completed by mid-2004. Indian Railways have planned to rightsize staff strength in the organization by controlling fresh recruitment against vacancies caused by natural attrition. Railways being a dynamic organization whose network, services are constantly increasing, categories related to safety/operations/security require to be filled up/ augmented in a regular basis. To maintain reliable service, Railways have decided to strengthen their staff in these categories as per requirements. The process of rightsizing will however continue for the categories other than those which fall under safety, security and operational needs. Staff identified as surplus in such other categories will be suitably redeployed after retraining them and ensuring that they comply with the medical category required for the category where they will be redeployed. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Vilas Muttemwar in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Container Corporation of India
pr_content: LOK SABHAContainer Corporation of India Ltd. (CONCOR) is planning to set up rail-linked container terminals at following location : Agra, Dhappar (Chandigarsh), Raipur, Bhopal, Gandhidham (Kandla), Ankleshwar, Belgaon, Visakhapatnam, Kotal, Kolkata Port Trust area (KoPT), Vapi (Gujarat) and Shambhupura (Rajasthan). Thirty two depots are in operation presently. Regular train services are running between Tughlakabad (Delhi) and Cossipore Road (Kolkata). During the year 2002-2003, containers handled and financial turnover of CONCOR at Cossipore Road (Kolkata) was 24793 Twenty Feet Equivalent Units (TEUs) with the turnover of Rs. 21.47 crores. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Tufani Saroj in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Improvement in rail coaches
pr_content: LOK SABHAM/s. Rail India Technical and Economic Services (RITES) have been entrusted the work of redesigning the coach body structure to make it crashworthy in association with Transportation Technology Centre Inc. and Applied Research Associates of United States of America. The agreement has been signed on June 17, 2003. The work is to be completed by January 2005. The details of the assignment given under the contract are analysis of strength of existing design, carry out crash simulation, develop crashworthy design, carry out crash simulation of new design, develop test rig for testing of the new design, train Indian Railway personnel in theory and concept of crashworthiness, modeling, simulation, testing, instrumentation, data acquisition and analysis and supply of hardware for the same. RITES shall complete the work within eighteen months and from the date of signing of the agreement by January 2005. The design will be given by RITES and the prototype coaches shall be manufactured by Railways. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Prof. Ummareddy Venkateswarlu in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: MoU between Railways and Production Units
pr_content: LOK SABHAA draft Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) for granting more autonomy to Production Units for marketing to Non-Railway Customers and exports has been prepared and circulated to all Production Units. Replies of all the Production Units, including the Chittaranjan Locomotive Works (CLW), has been received and suggestions made by them have been examined. The matter was also discussed with Staff Council, CLW, which is the recognized labour representative body of CLW and their apprehensions were addressed for satisfactory conclusion that the Memorandum does not seek to detach the Production Units from Indian Railways. No other Staff Council and the other Five Production Units have expressed its opposition. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Basudeb Acharia in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Provision of AC in rail engines
pr_content: LOK SABHAA decision has been taken in principle to provide an air-conditioner in the driver’s cab of locomotives on trial basis. Air-conditioners have been provided in some of the locomotives. Air-conditioning of cab will help to reduce the fatigue during long hours of driving without halt. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Adhir Chowdhury in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Circular trains throguh South India
pr_content: LOK SABHAThe issue of introducing a tourist train covering the Southern state capitals was raised in a conference of the South Indian Tourism Ministers held on June 5, 2003 at Hyderabad. Thereafter, a meeting of the South Indian Tourism Ministers and the South Indian State Tourism Departments with the Railway officials was scheduled to be held in Hyderabad in September 2003. However, the meeting did not take place and there has been no further development in this regard. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Dr. D.V.G. Shankar Rao in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Zonal Security Plan
pr_content: LOK SABHA‘Corporate Safety Plan’ of Indian Railways for the period 2003-2013 has been finalized and laid on the Table of the Lok Sabha on August 19, 2003. This document states the objectives, strategies and targets for which the Indian Railways would be striving in the next decade. As mentioned in the Corporate Safety Plan, each Zone and Division is required to identify safety risks and has to prepare a detailed safety action plan, dovetailed with the Indian Railway’s safety objectives to ensure that the standards of safety are improved. Administrative instructions to make out zonal and divisional safety action plans have also been issued. Action has already been initiated on the zones and divisions. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Prof. Ummareddy Venkateswarlu in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Setting up of power plants by Railways
pr_content: LOK SABHAProject Committee set for identifying suitable site(s) for setting up of a Captive Power Plant in joint venture with the National Thermal Power Corporation (NTPC) has recommended Nabinagar (Bihar) as suitable site for setting up of 1000 MW (4 units of 250 MW each) Power Plant. For this purpose, it is proposed to form “Bhartiya Rail Bijlee Company” in joint venture with NTPC. Rs. 4374 crore will be the estimated cost of the project. The Plant will be commissioned in 4-5 years from the date of Government approval. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from S/Shri Basudeb Acharia and Prabodh Panda in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Bamboo processing centres should be set up to alleviate rural unemployment: T. R. Baalu
pr_content: The Minister for Environment and Forests Shri T.R.Baalu has emphasized the need for the commercial exploitation of bamboo based technologies developed by Indian Plywood Industries Research and Training Institute (IPIRTI), Bangalore. In his presidential address at the Annual General Body Meeting of IPIRTI here last evening, Shri. Baalu called for setting up of primary bamboo processing centers with the active involvement of Joint Forest Management Committees (JFMC) in the bamboo growing areas to generate employment for rural people, especially women. The centres will provide raw material base for commercialization of technologies on bamboo mat board, bamboo mat corrugated sheet, bamboo laminates, developed by IPIRTI, he said. The Minister appreciated the efforts of IPIRTI in developing wood substitutes from bamboo. The meeting was attended by senior officials of MoEF, representatives from Planning Commission, wood based industries, Bureau of Indian Standards (BIS), other government departments and scientists from IPIRTI.

pr_title: Constitution of Commando Force
pr_content: LOK SABHA In Sep 2003, government had sanctioned Commando Force with the nomenclature “Garud” having a total strength of 1090 personnel. The functions of the force are protection of critical Air Force bases and installations; search and rescue during peace and hostilities and disaster relief during calamities. This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Shri Amir Alam in Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Procurement of Mirage Aircraft
pr_content: LOK SABHAQatar has offered 12 Mirage –2000 –V aircraft for sale along with a package. The package includes supply of necessary tools, testers, spares, ground equipment and training aids, etc. in addition to the aircraft. The above package would facilitate the maintenance of the aircraft. This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Shri Dinesh Chandra Yadav and Shri Ramjivan Singh in Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Building of Aircraft carriers
pr_content: LOK SABHAThe Government has sanctioned the construction of an Air Defence Ship of approximately 37500 MT at Cochin Shipyard Limited, Kochi. Work on the design of the ship has started. Other activities for constructing the ship as per the time schedule laid down have also commenced. A monitoring mechanism to monitor the progress of ship construction activities at the high level has been set up so that the ship construction activities proceed smoothly without any hindrance and the time schedules laid down for construction are adhered to. Presently only one ship of this type is planned to be constructed in India. This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Shri Ramsheth Thakur and others in Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Production of Defence equipment by Private Sector
pr_content: LOK SABHAThe Department of Industrial Policy & Promotion (DIPP), in consultation with the Ministry of Defence have so far issued 15 letters of intent for manufacture of various types of defence equipment, which include Armoured & Combat Vehicles, Radars, Electronic Warfare equipment, Warships, Submarine, Avionics, Military aircraft, Safety & Ballistic products, armaments and ammunition etc. The Government aims to achieve indigenous content in Defence systems to the extent of 70 per cent by 2005. To achieve this, the Government has allowed private sector participation in production of Defence items upto 100 % with Foreign Direct Investment permissible upto 26 per cent both subject to licensing. Till date, no proposal of Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) for manufacturing defence related products has been received. It is entirely a decision of the individual entrepreneur depending on his commercial perception, to seek FDI. This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Shri Chandra Bhushan Singh in Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Delay in development of weapons/equipment
pr_content: LOK SABHAThere have been certain delays in major state-of-the-art systems, (costing Rs. 100 crore and above), undertaken by DRDO. These systems are Main Battle Tank ‘Arjun’, Guided Missiles, Light Combat Aircraft ‘Tejas’, Kaveri engine for Tejas, Integrated Electronic Warfare (EW) system for Army, Samyukta and EW systems for Navy Sangraha. The time taken for indigenous development of these complex systems has been about 20 years for MBT Arjun, LCA Tejas and some of the missiles of Integrated Guided Missile Development Programme (IGMDP) whereas, for other systems it is about 10 years. The main reasons for the delays are Technological complexities and other problems related to technological development; insufficient industrial infrastructure within the country; non availability of materials, indigenous components and devices; technology sanctions and embargoes imposed on our Research and Development establishments and industries; upgradation of qualitative requirements and scope of the projects midstream by user services and long and extended user trials over several years. From the projects amongst IGMDP, Prithvi missile for Army is under regular production and it has been inducted into service. Development work on Prithvi for Air Force has been completed. Naval version Dhanush has been accepted for induction by Navy. Agni class of missiles are in production and induction phase. BrahMos, a joint development missile system has been accepted for induction by Navy. Samyukta (com segment) has been successfully evaluated by Army. Sub-systems of Sangraha have been inducted by user services. The other major systems like Tejas, Kaveri engine for Tejas, Trishul, Akash and Nag missiles are in advanced stages of evaluation. This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Shri Chandrakant Khaire in Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Reservation to girls in NCC
pr_content: LOK SABHAAt present there is no policy of reservation for girl cadets in the National Cadet Corps (NCC). However, efforts are being made by the NCC to encourage the enrolment of girl cadets. At present girl cadets constitute about 15.9 % of the enrolled strength of NCC cadets. Efforts are being made by NCC Directorate to increase the strength of girl cadets further by encouraging composite units of girls and boys within the existing overall sanctioned strength of cadets. The girl cadets are provided with every opportunity to undertake armed training. Specialized flying and boating training is already being imparted to the girl cadets. Girl cadets also take an active part in all other adventure – training activities conducted by NCC. This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Bhartruhari Mahtab in Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Visit of diplomats to forward areas
pr_content: LOK SABHADefence Attaches (DAs) from 19 countries stationed in New Delhi were taken to forward areas of Jammu & Kashmir on Sep 29, 2003. While the group did not meet any apprehended terrorist, the weapons and equipment captured from terrorists were shown to them during this visit. However on Oct 07, 2003 one captured terrorist, a Pakistani national, named Mohammed Shahzad, belonging to Lashkar-E-Tayyeba, a terrorist organization, was produced before the DAs in New Delhi. A few selected DAs were taken in a helicopter and given an overview of the site in Baramulla District, where a major infiltration bid from across the border was foiled by Indian Troops. This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Dr. (Mrs) Rajeswaramma Vukkala in Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Procurement of INS Talwar
pr_content: LOK SABHAIndian Navy has got its first stealth ship with invisible war technology, INS Talwar, the 4000 warship with cutting edge technology. Three ships modified Krivak class are being acquired from Russia for the Indian Navy. These ships have state-of-the-art anti-submarine, anti-ship and anti-air capabilities besides latest stealth features. This information was given by the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes in a written reply to Jyotiraditya M Scindia in Lok Sabha today.
