pr_title: Alumina and Aluminium sales in November
pr_content: The National Aluminium Company Limited (NALCO), a public sector unit of the Ministry of Mines sold 1,00,216 tonnes of Alumina during November 2003 exceeding the target of 98,000 tonnes. This includes Alumina export of 97,866 tonnes and domestic sale of 2350 tonnes. Out of 142,200 tonnes of Calcined Alumina produced in the month, 44,070 tonnes was despatched for smelting and 82,775 tonnes was despatched to port for export. The cumulative sale has been 5,84,998 tonnes against the target of 6,51,000 tonnes. During the month 9,996 tonnes of aluminium metal was exported against the monthly target of 11,800 tonnes. The cumulative export has been 87,377 tonnes against the target of 91,900 tonnes and that is 21.8% more as compared to same period of previous year. During the month, 13,907 tonnes of aluminium metal was sold in domestic market exceeding the monthly target of 11,450 tonnes. The cumulative domestic sale has been 106,948 tonnes exceeding the target of 96,700 tonnes. The same is 28.02% more compared to the same period of last year. The total metal sale during the month has been 23,903 tonnes exceeding the target of 23,250 tonnes and the cumulative sale has been 1,94,324 tonnes exceeding the target of 1,88,600 tonnes. The same is 23.48% more compared to the same period of last year.

pr_title: BARC develops new wound healing technique
pr_content: The Bhabha Atomic Research Centre (BARC) has just developed a new wound healing technique called “Hydrogel Wound Dressing”. This is highly useful for burns, leprosy ulcers, diabetic foot ulcers, animal bites, plastic surgery etc. The treatment based on this methodology is also known as “Moist Would Healing”, and is a well established practice in Europe, America and other developed countries. No such dressing was manufactured in India until recently and the imported ones were very expensive. Even in developed countries such healing techniques are very costly. But the product developed by BARC, using radiation processing is very cost-effective. The BARC has transferred this technology to the industry for commercialisation and the product is now available in the market. Radiation technology finds varied applications in the field of industry, healthcare, agriculture and research. India is a leading producer of radioisotopes in the world. Radioisotopes are produced at the research reactors Apsara, CIRUS and Dhruva at Trombay. The first indigenous cobalt-60 tele-therapy source was prepared for use in treatment of cancer. The radioisotopes are processed and supplied to medical users across the country.

pr_title: Research Project on transgenic crops proposedCONSULTATIVE COMMITTEE OF MINISTRY OF AGRICULTURE MEETS
pr_content: A network project on transgenics, covering 12 crops is on the anvil. The proposed research project of the Indian Council of Agricultural Research (ICAR) will cover maize, pigeonpea, chickpea, soyabean, cotton, brassica, tomato, brinjal, banana, papaya, potato and cassava. The Agriculture Minister, Shri Rajnath Singh said this while addressing a meeting of the Parliamentary Consultative Committee attached to his Ministry here today. The Minister said that the proposed project would focus on specially targeted trait improvement such as resistance to insect pests, fungal diseases and viral diseases, tolerance to abiotic stresses and extended shelf life in each of the 12 crops. Other crops may be included as the programme develops. The subject of today’s discussions in the Consultative Committee was “Transgenics in Agriculture”. Shri Rajnath Singh said that initial steps have been taken for indigenous development of transgenics in India in rice, cotton, potato, mustard, pigeonpea, chickpea, brinjal, tomato, cabbage, cauliflower, tobacco, pulses, castor and groundnut to address the problems of resistance or endurance to biotic and abiotic stress factors or those related to nutritional factors. Transgenic lines developed in different crop species by ICAR institutions, several other institutes and the private sector are under various stages of development or testing in the country. Advances have been made at the ICAR experimentation plots in transgenic potato in terms of improved nutritional quality and balanced amino acid composition. Indigenously developed Bt detection kits by the ICAR have proved effective. The Agriculture Minister stressed the need to develop a suitable capacity building programme and also a human resource development project to cater to research and development needs in the country in respect of agro-biotechnological applications. In addition to enriching bio-technology laboratories of the ICAR system, bio-technology laboratories in various State Agricultural Universities also need to be strengthened. Shri Rajnath Singh said that bio-technology applications in general and transgenics in particular offer new opportunities in agriculture to increase production and productivity. It is imperative to assess the potential role and requirement for promotion and regulation of transgenics for their fruitful utilization in Indian agriculture. The Minister emphasised that farmers’ acceptance coupled with farm prosperity is the foremost guiding principle for release of transgenic crop varieties. The release of these varieties should be based not only on their environment and biosafety clearance, but also on their coordinated value for cultivation and use. The Agriculture Minister also stressed the need to promote public awareness in matters relating to agricultural bio-technology. He also called for giving priority to isolation of indigenous genes. He cautioned that post release monitoring and management of transgenics and their products is essential. Participating in the deliberations, the members appreciated the tremendous scope for increase in agricultural production through transgenics. They suggested extensive discussion with the State Governments to ensure smooth application of transgenics. The Members also stressed the need for proper assessment of risk factors involved in transgenics. The need for proper communication between scientists and farmers was also highlighted. Some members suggested identification of certain areas for propagating transgenic crops. The global area under the genetically modified (GM) crop varieties increased to 58.7 million hectares in 2002. The principal biotech crops were soyabean, corn, cotton and canola. In India, the environmental release of transgenics Bt cotton hybrids in 2002 heralded a new era with 3 transgenic cotton hybrids namely, MECH-184, MECH-162 and MECH-12 being approved for cultivation. In India, assessment of transgenics for environmental and bio-safety criteria and release for commercialization is carried out under the Environment (Protection) Act, 1986. The Ministry of Environment and Forests is the nodal ministry responsible for environmental release of genetically modified organisms including transgenic crops. The Genetic Engineering Approval Committee accords approval for or rejects applications for the release of transgenics for commercialization after due deliberation. Today’s meeting was attended by S/shri Bhartruhari Mahtab, Chunni Lal Bhau Thakur, Mahboob Zahedi, K.Sreenivasulu, K.P.Singh Deo, Haribhai Choudhary and Anadi Charan Sahu, all from the Lok Sabha.

pr_title: Industry poised for era of sustained high growthJAITLEY PRESIDES OVER PARLIAMENTARY CONSULTATIVE COMMITTEE OF COMMERCE & INDUSTRY
pr_content: Indian economy is poised to grow at over 7% in terms of real GDP during 2003-04, with industrial growth and manufacturing growth, in particular, having reached a stage where all the ingredients are in place to trigger an era of sustained high growth. The overall investment climate today is conducive to promoting growth and investment in industry as reflected in buoyant investment indicators. This was indicated in a presentation on the “Present Industrial Scenario” at a meeting of the Parliamentary Consultative Committee of the Ministry of Commerce & Industry, which was presided over by Shri Arun Jaitley, Union Minister of Commerce & Industry and attended by Shri Suresh P. Prabhu, MP (Shiv Sena); Shri Kapil Sibal, MP (INC); Shri M. Master Mathan, MP (BJP); and others. Shri Dipak Chatterjee, Commerce Secretary and Shri Lakshmi Chand, Secretary (Industrial Policy & Promotion) were present. On the external front, the country’s foreign exchange reserves continue to surge and have now exceeded US $ 96 billion. Healthy growth in imports may also have a favourable impact on industry in the coming months, while surge in non-oil imports (in April-October 2003) reflects strengthening of domestic demand. Over the same period, export growth in dollar terms has been sustained, although at a slower pace compared to high base of the previous year. However, improved prospects for global recovery should provide a fresh impetus to export growth, it was indicated. Members present stressed the need to increase the share of manufacturing in GDP to generate greater employment opportunities, especially in rural areas. Apart from the contribution of services to GDP and its expanding growth in the country’s overall growth process, it was mentioned that employment generation would come essentially through the manufacturing, mining and construction sectors. Fortunately, construction activity was looking up as also steel and cement and these were positive signals. The importance of manufacturing was brought out in the presentation which said that in India it currently accounted for about 17% of real (measured) GDP, 12% of the total workforce and 24% of the total workforce engaged in the organised sector, and little less than three-fourth of India’s total merchandise exports. “The combination of low inflation, low interest rates, tax buoyancy and the revival of public spending on infrastructure together signal a very high likelihood of a significant acceleration in overall growth and industrial growth, in particular”, it said. The discussions also briefly touched upon the performance and progress of Special Economic Zones (SEZs) in the country. It was mentioned that SEZs in the first six months of the current financial year (April-September 2003) registered an export growth of 23% as against around 10% for the non-SEZ sector. Members emphasised the need for having the SEZ Act in place early, as a proper regulatory framework was needed to attract investment in the zones and facilitate faster implementation of the SEZ scheme.

pr_title: Minimum wages payable to daily wager
pr_content: RAJYA SABHAIn pursuance of the decision taken at tripartite fora of Central Advisory Board constituted under section 8 of the Minimum Wages Act, 1948 in its meeting held on 27th June, 2002, the Government set up a Working Group to go into the Codification of the concept of Minimum Wages, Listing out Guidelines based on Critical Evaluation of Various Parameters and also to Study the Problems in Implementation of Minimum Wages. It has recommended the norms in terms of 3 consumption units and per capita requirement of food, clothing, fuel, lighting and miscellaneous items including Children’s education, medical requirement etc. as determined by the results of quinquennial Consumer Expenditure Survey for Rural Areas conducted by National Sample Survey Organization. Based on these norms the Working Group worked out afresh the national minimum wage at Rs.66/- per day to be made applicable to unskilled labour in respect of each employment. No decision has yet been taken by the Government regarding acceptance of the report of the Working Group. The national minimum wage of Rs.66/- per day as worked at by the Working Group would be higher by 32 percent from the present level of Rs.50/- per day revised with effect from 01.09.2002. In comparison to this, the Consumer price Index number for Industrial Workers (Base 1982=100) increased by 3.5 percent only to 501 (July, 2003) from 484 (August 2002). This information was given by Dr. Sahib Singh, Union Labour Minister in reply to a question in Parliament today.

pr_title: Indo Myanmar relations
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA The Vice President made an official visit to Myanmar from 2-5 November, 2003. Earlier Foreign Office consultations were held between the two countries on 23-24th October. During the meetings all bilateral, regional and international issues of mutual interest were discussed by the two sides. Both sides agreed to cooperate in preventing, countering and suppressing the activities of terrorist groups and for ensuring that their common border remains one of peace, stability and tranquility. The two sides shared the view that the United Nations reform process should be expedited. Myanmar informed the Indian side of its willingness to support the aspiration of India to become a Permanent Member of the United Nations Security Council when the issue comes up. The two sides agreed top work jointly to strengthen regional cooperation, including in ASEAN, the BIMST-EC and the Mekong-Ganga Cooperation, in which both countries are actively involved. Agreements were signed on visa exemption for official and diplomatic passport holders and in the field of dollars 25 million to Myanmar, for which a bilateral agreement was signed. This information was given by Shri Vinod Khanna, the Minister of State in the Ministry of External Affairs in his statement in the Rajya Sabha.

pr_title: Indian partnership with Syria
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA During Prime Minister’s State visit to Syria on November 14-16 2003, the two sides agreed to strengthen their bilateral relations. Both sides had comprehensive exchange of views on a wide range of important bilateral, regional and international issues, in a way that reflects the deep historical relations between India and Syria. They expressed their satisfaction at the steady and comprehensive growth in bilateral relations. They, however, emphasized that enormous potential by further bilateral cooperation needed to be tapped for mutual benefit. They committed themselves to further strengthening and expanding their bilateral cooperation, especially in political, economic, commercial, cultural and science & technology sectors. The two sides identified fields such as Biotechnology, Information Technology, Hydrocarbons, Railways, Education and Agriculture where existing complementarities could be exploited for mutual benefit. They agreed to encourage the private and public sectors to expand the scope of mutual trade and investments. In the presence of the President Dr. Bashar Al-Assad and Prime Minister Shri Vajpayee, nine bilateral documents were signed in diverse areas such as Culture, Information Technology, Agriculture, Technical Cooperation, Education, Literature, Small Scale Industries, Biotechnology and Science & Technology. The two sides hoped that these documents would further enhance the bilateral legal and institutional framework and boost their cooperation in respective sectors. Both sides agreed to hold periodic consultations between the two governments on topical issues. Both sides also agreed to increase the frequency of bilateral visits by Ministers and officials and to consolidate the ties between business communities of the two countries. People-to-people relations will also be encouraged, in order to increase and deepen understanding between the societies. In view of the potential for cooperation in the Hydrocarbon sector, both sides decided to set up a Joint Hydrocarbon Committee, having three representatives from each side. This Committee will be mandated to suggest specific projects for joint cooperation in the Hydrocarbon sector within a specified timeframe. The two sides agreed to consider setting up an Institute of Petroleum with the assistance of the Government of India. Both sides reviewed their economic and commercial cooperation and identified fields such as Biotechnology, Information Technology, Hydrocarbons, Railways, Education and Agriculture where existing complementarities could be exploited for mutual benefit. They agreed to encourage the private and public sectors to expand the scope of mutual trade and investments. Prime Minister of India also announced a Credit Line of US$ 25 million (US dollar twenty five million) for development of bilateral trade. The announcement of credit line by India for the purpose of boosting bilateral trade was welcomed by Syria. Both sides agreed to double the bilateral trade by 2005 and decided to identify priority areas for this purpose. Both the governments noted with satisfaction the progress achieved in bilateral cooperation in biotechnology sector. The establishment of Syrian National Biotechnology Centre at the University of Damascus with Indian assistance will further enhance their peaceful cooperation in this vital field. Both sides will undertake joint projects for mutual benefit. Indian Prime Minister announced a special grant of US$ 1 million to assist implementation of the agreed programme of cooperation and made the Centre an Institute of excellence. This information was given by Shri Vinod Khanna, the Minister of State in the Ministry of External Affairs in his statement in the Rajya Sabha.

pr_title: Minerals exploration by GSI -Backgrounder
pr_content: BACKGROUNDER Geological Survey of India (GSI) as a part of its charter of functions carries out regional exploration for locating additional mineral resources in various parts of the country. As regards exploration of coal, bauxite and iron-ore, it has undertaken 37 items of regional exploration for coal (+ lignite), 2 items each for iron ore and bauxite during the field season 2003-04 in various parts of the country. pr_title: `Jal Samvardhan Yojana’ for rainwater harvesting on the anvil
pr_content: Ministry of Rural Development proposes to launch `Jal Samvardhan Yojana’ for rainwater harvesting shortly. This was informed by Shri Kashiram Rana Union Minister for Rural Development, here today. Shri Rana said that the annual allocation of the scheme would be about Rs. 1000 crore. Modalities are being worked out for the scheme. Our country is facing water problem not because we do not have adequate sources of water. The problem lies in our inability to conserve all the rainwater. Most of the rain water flows into the seas without being harnessed. Therefore, revival, renovation and maintenance of all the available sources of water is the need of the hour, Shri Rana said. Shri Rana highlighted that the Ministry of Rural Development places special emphasis on monitoring and evaluation of its programme being implemented in rural areas all over the country. The success of the programmes largely depends at the effective delivery system, proper utilisation of funds and efficient implementation of the grass-root levels. Shri Rana said that the role of media is especially significant in the context of implementation of various rural development programmes. Media can play effective role in creating awareness amongst the target groups of the programme and mobilise them towards participatory development. Shri Rana released annual edition of Gramin Bharat (Hindi fortnightly) here today. Shri Annasaheb.M.K.Patil and Shri U.V. Krishnam Raju, Ministers of State for Rural Development were also present there. Talking to the media, Shri Rana informed that in order to ensure capacity building of the Panchayati Raj functionaries by providing easy access to information on Rural Development Programmes, in April, 2002, the Ministry of Rural Development started publication of monthly news letter titled`Grameen Bharat’. The newsletter is being published in Hindi, English and eleven Regional languages and distributed free of cost to all the Panchayats in the country. The newsletter serves not only as a unilinear vehicle to communicate messages and information on rural development programmes but also as a reliable source of getting feedback on the implementation of the programmes at the field level in the form of responses from the readers.

pr_title: India and Iran to set up `Joint Working Group on Rural Development’
pr_content: An Iranian delegation led by Minister of Agriculture Shri Mahmood Hojjati met Union Minister for Rural Development, Shri Kashiram Rana here today. To facilitate exchange of successful experiences in the field of rural development, both the countries proposed to set up a `Joint Working Group’. It will provide assistance in evolving an integrated approach to rural development for more effective and speedier implementation of the schemes in the rural areas to benefit societies and economies. Shri Mahmood Hojjati, Minister of Agriculture, Iran informed that migration from rural areas to urban areas is very high in Iran. Shri Rana highlighted that Ministry of Rural Development is implementing a number of programmes for wage-employment generation in rural areas and self-employment for rural poor. These programmes contribute to a great extent in alleviating rural poverty and in improving the quality of rural life. Shri Rana further informed that there has also been a paradigm shift in the strategy for Rural Development with focus on decentralization through speedy and effective devolution of financial and administrative powers to the Panchayati Raj Institutions. Panchayats are directly implementing schemes for Rural Drinking Water and Watershed Development. Under Sampoorna Gramin Rozgar Yojana (SGRY) the wage-employment programme, each level of Panchayat is independently responsible for the implementation of the programme. Iranian delegation expressed the desire to benefit from India’s experience particularly in the fields of self-employment, low cost rural housing, rural drinking water supply and people’s participatory approach for rural development. Additional Secretary, Land Resources and Director of Rural Development, Iran met to work out modalities to form `Joint Working Group’ so that India and Iran can share common interest in rural development.

pr_title: India and Iran to set up a Joint Working Group for cooperation in combating desertificationIRAN SEEKS INDIA’S ASSISTANCE IN IMPROVING FOREST COVER
pr_content: India and Iran have decided to set up a Joint Working Group to cooperate on issues such as desertification, reafforestation in arid and semi arid zones and exchange of plant species. This was decided at a meeting between the Iranian Minister for Agriculture Mr. Mahmood Hossatti Najafabadi and the Minister for Environment and Forests Shri T.R.Baalu here today. Mr. Hossatti commended India’s achievement in improving the forest cover in the face of global trend of decline of the same. He said Iran has only 7 per cent forest cover and he sought the assistance of India in increasing it. Shri Baalu said that a series of measures have been taken by the Indian Government to help in improving the forest cover such as Legislative Acts, Joint Forest Management Committees and the involvement of women. He invited a group of experts from Iran to see the functioning of the JFMCs. Shri Baalu also said that the Arid Research Institute, Jodhpur is working on plant species which may be suitable for Iran. The two sides agreed to cooperate on soil conservation and also exchange at plant species through seeds and saplings for the arid and semi arid regions. Shri Baalu reminded his Iranian counterpart about a suggestion given by India last year to exchange Asiatic Cheetah now extinct in India with Asiatic Lions, not found in Iran. The Iranian delegation was presented with copies of a booklet on Joint Forest Management.

pr_title: Prime Minister to launch Artisan Credit Card tomorrow
pr_content: Artisan credit card scheme to meet the requirement of the artisans for both for investment and working capital shall be launched tomorrow. The Prime Minister Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee will launch the Scheme. The scheme will be simultaneously launched in Uttar Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh and Orissa tomorrow. All artisans involved in production/manufacturing process and otherwise eligible for credit facilities, for carrying out the proposed activities’ under any of the existing bank scheme would be eligible for the credit card. Preference would be given to artisans registered with Development Commissioner (Handicrafts). Thrust in financing would be on Clusters of artisans and artisans who have joined to form Self Help Groups (SHGs). Beneficiaries of other Government sponsored loan schemes will not be eligible for coverage under ACC scheme. Beneficiaries will be issued a photo card indicating sanctioned limit and validity period of credit facility. They will also be issued a passbook or a credit cum passbook incorporating name, address, borrowing limit, validity period, etc. Credit limit would be fixed based on the assessment of working capital requirement as well as cost of tools and equipment required for carrying out manufacturing process. The maximum credit limit to be sanctioned under the scheme would, however, be Rs.2 lakh. The Artisan Credit Card limit could normally be valid for a period of three years subject to annual review by the bank. For the purpose of annual review the borrower may not be required to submit any financial statement. Based on the assessment of performance during inspection by field staff and operations in the account, the review exercise may be carried out annually and a decision on continuation or otherwise of the limit sanctioned may be taken. Need for enhancement in the limit sanctioned may also be considered as part of the review. No fee will be charged for review/renewal of the limit. The rate of interest will be as per RBI norms and the policy of the lending bank. Beneficiaries who are registered with Development Commissioner (Handicrafts) would be eligible for coverage under group insurance scheme and the premium paid by the Government and the beneficiaries in the ration 60:40 respectively or as mutually agreed between office of the Development Commissioner (Handicrafts) and Insurance Company.

pr_title: Track renewals
pr_content: Indian Railways have renewed 2,043 kilometres of tracks during the first half of the current financial year 2003-2004. The target for the full year is 3,850 kilometres. To wipe out overdue renewal of assets, a non-lapsable Special Railway Safety Fund (SRSF) has been created in 2001-2002. An allocation of Rs. 7,670 crores out of a total of 17,000 crores SRSF has been made for track renewals. A programme has been made to wipe out overdue renewals of tracks as existed on April 1, 2001 by April 1, 2007.

pr_title: Statement of Minister of Social Justice and Empowerment Dr. Satyanarayan Jatiya in the Lok Sabha in response to the calling attention notice
pr_content: The Minister of Social Justice and Empowerment Dr. Satyanarayan Jatiya gave a Statement in the Lok Sabha today in response to the Calling Attention Notice tabled by Shri Rajesh Ranjan and other Members of Parliament regarding "the need to include Dalit Muslims, Dalit Christians and certain other backward communities in the list of Scheduled Castes/ Scheduled Tribes and provide reservation benefits to them". Here is the text of Dr. Jatiya’s statement :- "As per article 366 (24) of the Constitution, "’Scheduled Castes,’ means such castes, races or tribes or parts of or groups within such castes, races or tribes as are deemed under article 341 to be Scheduled Castes for the purpose of this Constitution." Clause (1) of Article 341 of the Constitution provides that "The President may with respect to any State or Union Territory, and where it is a State, after consultation with the Governor thereof, by public notification, specify the castes, races or tribes or parts of a groups within castes, races or tribes, which shall for the purpose of this Constitution be deemed to be Scheduled Castes in relation to that State or Union Territory as the case may be". Further, Clause (2) of Article 341 of the Constitution provides that "Parliament may be law include in or exclude from the list of Scheduled Castes specified in a notification issued under clause (1) any caste, race or tribe or part of or group within any caste, race or tribe, but save as aforesaid a notification issued under the said clause shall not be varied by any subsequent notification. The test applied for inclusion in the list of Scheduled Castes is ‘extreme social, educational and economic backwardness arising out of the traditional practice of untouchability." Para 3 of the Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order 1950 includes, only the Hindu, the Sikh and the Buddhist religions. Thereby persons belonging to these religions are eligible to be included in the list of Scheduled Castes, if they fulfill the conditions laid down in the said Constitutional Order. The validity of paragraph 3 of the Presidential Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950 was considered by the Supreme Court in the case of Soosai etc. vs. the Union of India and others (Writ petition No.9596 of 1983), wherein Apex Court observed, in para 7 of the judgement that, "Now it can not be disputed that the caste system is a feature of the Hindu social structure. It is a social phenomenon peculiar to Hindu society. The division of the Hindu social order by reference at one time to professional or vocational occupation was moduled into a structural hierarchy, which over the centuries crystallized into stratification where the place of the individual was determined by birth. Those who occupied the lowest rung of the social ladder were treated as existing beyond the periphery of civilized society, and were indeed not even "touchable". This social attitude committed those castes to severe social and economic disabilities and cultural and educational backwardness, The Apex Court in para 8 of their Judgement further observed that, "It is quite evident that President had before him all this material indicating that the depressed classes of Hindu and Sikh communities suffered from economic and social disabilities and cultural and educational backwardness so gross in character and degree that the members of those castes in the two communities called for the protection of the Constitutional provision relating to the Scheduled Castes. It was evident that in order to provide for their amelioration and advancement it was necessary to conceive of intervention by the State through its legislative and executive powers. It must be remembered that the declaration incorporated in paragraph 3 deeming them to be members of the Scheduled Castes was a declaration made for the purpose of the Constitution. It was a declaration enjoined by Clause (1) of Article 341 of the Constitution." The Apex court in para 8 of the Judgement concluded thus, "It is therefore, not possible to say that the President acted arbitrarily in the exercise of his judgement in enacting paragraph 3 of the Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950". It is alleged that the "Dalit " Muslims were getting benefits as are available to Scheduled Castes during the period 1935-50 and the Constitution (Scheduled Castes) Order, 1950 has debarred them from getting such benefits. It is clarified that there is no record available which shows that "Dalit" Muslims are getting benefits as are available to Scheduled Castes during the period 1935-50. It is contained in the Report of the Advisory Committee on the Revision of the lists of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes, Government of India, " The relevant record shows in drawing the list of Scheduled Castes, the test applied was the social, educational and economic backwardness arising out of the historical customs of untoucahbility. The list of Scheduled castes drawn in 1950 was a revised version of the list of Scheduled Castes under the Government of India Act, 1935, which, in turn was the continuation of earlier list of depressed classes. The depressed classes, it is well known were systematically categorized in 1931 by the Census Commissioner of India, who had given the following instructions for the categorization :- "I have explained depressed castes as castes, contact with whom entails purification on part of high caste Hindus. It is not intended that the term should have any reference to occupation as such but to those castes which by reasons of their traditional position in Hindu society are denied access to temples for instance or have to use separate wells or are not allowed to sit inside school house but have to remain outside or suffer similar disabilities." Thus it is clear that "Dalit" Muslims or "Dalit" Christians were not included in the list of Depressed Classes during the period 1935-50. The issue of inclusion of Scheduled Castes convert to Christianity in the list of Scheduled Castes has been processed in consultation with the Registrar General of India and the National Commission for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes. The Registrar General of India has opined that stratification among Christians on the basis of caste could well become a matter of international controversy and it may be misunderstood internationally as if India is imposing its caste system among Christians and that such reservation is not justifiable. The National Commission for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes have opined that the inclusion of `Dalit’ Christians in the list of Scheduled Castes for the purpose of reservation is neither desirable nor justifiable. Similarly in the case of inclusion of Scheduled Castes converted to Islam, the Registrar General of India has opined that it will be a serious controversy and also discontentment among the Muslims, if their community is recognised at par with those of Hindu castes on the ground of backwardness arising due to the traditional practice of untouchability, especially for the purpose of Article 341 of the Constitution of India. In this regard, the National Commission for Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes has opined that there is no justification for the proposal to add Muslims in the list of Scheduled Castes. For inclusion in the list of Scheduled Tribes there is no bar on religious grounds. "

pr_title: NCBC rejects proposal for the inclusion of `Maratha’ caste in the Central OBC List
pr_content: The National Commission for Backward Classes (NCBC) has rejected the proposal for the inclusion of `Maratha’ caste/ community as synonym of `Kunbi’ in the Central List of OBCs for Maharashtra State. The Commission has examined the proposal and has found that it is not a synonym of `Kunbi’. It also has advised the Government that `Maratha’ should also not be included in the Central List of Backward Classes for Maharashtra as a separate entry, as it is not socially backward caste/community but on the contrary is socially advanced and prestigious caste/community. This was stated by the Minister of State for Social Justice and Empowerment Shri Nagmani in a written reply in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Social Justice Ministry funds 350 NGOs for prevention of alcoholism and drugs abuse

pr_title: Govt issues notification prescribing rules and form for audit report under section 44DA
pr_content: The Central Government have issued a notification prescribing rules and form for the audit report under section 44DA of the Income-tax Act. The Finance Act, 2003 inserted a new section 44DA in the Income-tax Act, 1961 relating to special provisions for computing income by way of royalties, etc. in case of non-residents. Under this section the non-resident assessees are required to get their books of account audited and furnish the audit report in the prescribed form with the return of income. The notification as also the Form No. 3CE is available on the website of the Ministry of Finance (finmin.nic.in).

pr_title: Independence struggle and fight for social equality are of equal importance says the Prime Minister
pr_content: The Prime Minister Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee has underlined that the issue of Social equality and our struggle for Independence are Complementary. There is no question of comparing one with the other. Those who fought for freedom and those who worked for ensuring social equality deserve equal importance and place in our history. Dedicating to the nation Baba Saheb Dr. Ambedkar’s Parivirvan Sthal here today, Shri Vajpayee said that Baba Saheb Dr. Ambedkar believed that battle for independence and social equality have to be fought on equal footing. Describing Gandhiji and Dr. Bhimrao Ambedkar as great leaders, the Prime Minister said that the two should not be compared with eachother as both had immense contribution to the struggle for freedom of the country and for equality in Indian Society. Lauding Baba Saheb Dr. Ambedkar’s contribution to post-independent India the Prime Minister said that he ably steered the framing of the Indian Constitution which became a beacon for emerging nations. Shri Vajpayee said that the 26 Alipur Road permises is a pious place as Baba Saheb lived here from 1st November, 1951 to 6th December, 1956 when he breathed his last. The Prime Minister, who also inaugurated the development work of the Dr. Ambedkar National Memorial, said that it would be developed into a Museum that would inspire the people for social equality. He said that Baba Saheb’s Collected Works should be made available to people in all Indian languages. The Minister of Social Justice and Empowerment Dr. Satyanarayan Jatiya said that the dedication to nation of Baba Saheb Dr. Ambedkar’s Parinirvan Sthal meets the long due demand for a national memorial. He thanked the Union Urban Development Ministry and Delhi Administration for their help in setting up of the memorial. He said that the Collected Works of Baba Saheb have been translated into 11 Indian languages so far. The function was attended among others by the Minister of State (I.C) Shri Bhandaru Datatarya, Lt. Governor of Delhi Vijay Kapoor, Delhi Chief Minister Smt. Sheela Dixit, Minister of State for Sports, Shri Vijay Goel, Minister of State for Food Processing Shri Sang Priya Gautam and Minister of State for Communications Shri Ashok Pradhan. At the time of attainment of Maha Parinirvana by Bharat Ratna, Dr. Bhim Rao Ambedkar, 26 Alipur Road was the private property of Maharaja of Sirohi who had invited Baba Saheb to stay there after he resigned from the Union Cabinet in 1951. Later the property had been taken over by an industrial house. In pursuance of the decision of the Centenary Celebrations Committee of Dr. Ambedkar, to set up a suitable National Memorial, the Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment started the process of acquiring the site from its owners. After undergoing several legal procedures, finally on 14th October, 2003, the execution of exchange deed took place between the Ministry of Urban Development and its owners in the presence of Dr. Satyanarayan Jatiya. The Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment will now hand over the land to the Ambedkar Foundation to set up Dr, Ambedkar National Memorial which is long cherished project of the Foundation.

pr_title: India asks developed countries to reduce domestic support to agriculture
pr_content: India has called upon the developed countries to effect a substantial and real reduction in the domestic support, provided by them to their agriculture. Addressing the thirty-second session of the Conference of the Food and Agriculture Organization (FAO) in Rome today, the Agriculture Minister Shri Rajnath Singh also called for a genuine differential treatment to the developing countries to address their special concerns. He warned that any agreement on agriculture which does not take care of the concerns of small and marginal farmers in the developing countries would endanger their livelihood and food security. The Minister expressed disappointment over the outcome of the WTO Ministerial Conference at Cancun and regretted that adequate cognizance had not been taken of the interests of farmers, particularly small landholders in the developing countries. Shri Rajnath Singh pointed out that in globalized agriculture, domestic market prices for agricultural products are largely governed by prevailing prices in the international market. International prices of almost all agricultural commodities are distorted on account of huge domestic support and export subsidies provided by the developed countries to their agriculture. Due to these subsidies, the international prices get depressed and competitiveness of farmers in countries like India gets adversely affected, threatening their livelihood. Due to resource constraints, the developing countries cannot match the subsidies provided by the developed countries to their farmers. The only option available to these countries is to provide protection to their farmers through the mechanism of tariff. The Minister informed the Conference about India’s experience in managing last year’s unprecedented drought, which affected over 300 million people. Nearly a billion mandays were generated in eight months and nine million tons of food grains were distributed. Interventions were made for provision of drinking water, cattle care and movement of food grains, entailing an expenditure of more than 4 billion US dollars. India could tackle the adversity, largely due to its self-sufficiency in agricultural production. Shri Rajnath Singh said that India has put added emphasis on developing watersheds as units of crop diversification and development of horticulture to ensure sustained development of agriculture. Shri Rajnath Singh pledged India’s continued support to the FAO in achieving its objective of global food and nutritional security and raising the standards of living of farmers. The 12-day FAO Conference began on the 29th of last month. It is being attended by Agriculture Ministers from around the world.

pr_title: Shri Ram Naik receives Interim Report from Independent Enquiry Committee on Mumbai Offshore helicopter crash
pr_content: Shri Ram Naik, Minister of Petroleum & Natural Gas received here today an Interim Report from the Independent Inquiry Committee, which was set up by the Government on 18th August, 2003 to look into safety and security related aspects of Off-shore Operations of ONGC, after the crash of helicopter The Interim Report is in regard to Safety and Security of lives in Offshore Operations, especially air logistics & inspection mechanism and hiring of helicopters, specifically MI-172 helicopters, including the circumstances under which the ill-fated helicopter was hired. Before submission of the Interim Report, the Committee has interacted with various individuals, organizations and ONGC. The Committee was set up in pursuance of a Suo Motu statement in the Parliament on 13th August, 2003 made by Shri Ram Naik, on ‘crash of a helicopter hired by ONGC in Mumbai Offshore on 11th August, 2003’. While 2 persons could be saved, 27 lives were lost in the unfortunate accident. Shri Naik informed that compensation and other benefits have already been given to affected families by ONGC. The Committee is headed by Shri T.S. Vijayaraghavan, who has held the post of Secretary to Government of India in the Ministries of Petroleum & Natural Gas, Defence Production and Heavy Industry & Public Enterprises. The other members are Maj. Gen. (Retd.) S.C.N. Jatar and Prof. Pritam Singh. Maj. Gen. Jatar has served the Corps of Engineers of Indian Army and is a former CMD, of Oil India Limited. Prof. Pritam Singh, a Management specialist and Padma Shri Awardee, has been a Director of Indian Institute of Management, Lucknow. Shri Naik informed that the Committee was given the task to enquire into safety and security of lives in Offshore Operations, including air-logistics and inspection mechanism. The Committee, inter-alia, was also advised to look into aspects such as maintenance/ repairs/ replacement of offshore installations; hiring of helicopter; the circumstances under which the ill-fated helicopter was hired; adequacy of efforts made by ONGC; any act of omission and the role of management, short & long term remedial measures to be taken for safety and security of personnel engaged in offshore operation etc. As regards the cause of accident, a statutory investigation is separately being made by Directorate General of Civil Aviation (DGCA), who is vested with such functions under Aircraft Act and Rules. The Committee has sought extension of tenure to enable it to study and give its Report on all aspects referred to the Committee, which are extensive in coverage. On specific request of the Committee, the tenure of the Committee has been extended by 3 months, i.e. up to 17th February, 2004. Shri Ram Naik reiterated that the Government is committed to ensuring safety and security of lives of persons engaged in exploration and production of oil and gas as also the installations and assets deployed in such operations. The Interim Report will be examined by the Ministry for implementing the recommendations, added Shri Naik.

pr_title: New Member Engineering Railway Board
pr_content: Shri S.P.S. Jain, a Member of Indian Railway Service of Engineers (IRSE), has taken over as Member Engineering , Railway Board and ex-officio Secretary to the Government of India in the Ministry of Railways. He succeeds Shri Kanwarjit Singh, who retired on superannuation on November 30, 2003. Earlier, Shri Jain was General Manager, Central Railway, Mumbai. He also held concurrently the charge of Western Railway, Mumbai. Shri Jain graduated in Civil Engineering from Roorkee University in 1966. He joined Indian Railways on November 7, 1967 and has worked on different Railways, such as, Northern, Northeast Frontier, Western, South Eastern, Central and South Central Railways as also Railway Board in various capacities. He has served as Divisional Railway Manager at Ratlam on Western Railway and as Chief Engineer on South Central and South Eastern Railways. Shri Jain had Senior Management training in Manchester and had been on deputation in Zambia for World Bank Projects. Shri Jain brings with him experience and expertise to oversee and execute various works programmes to augment infrastructure of Indian Railways.

pr_title: Construction of an Adivasi Bhawan in capital is on the anvil
pr_content: Union Ministry of Tribal Affairs has already approached the Ministry of Urban Development and Poverty Alleviation to allot 2000 square meters of land in Kotla Road, Rouse Avenue, New Delhi and the matter is being followed up with that Ministry for early allotment of land. Meanwhile the Planning Commission have been requested to provide additional funds amounting to an initial sum of Rs. 10 crore (non-recurring) towards the cost of land and building of Adivasi Bhawan and a further amount of Rs. 1.5 crore (recurring) per annum for the maintenance of the Advisai Bhawan and the facilities to be provided therein. Action to finalise the Expenditure Finance Committee (EFC) Memo and Scheme for this purpose is also underway.

pr_title: Tribal Affairs Ministry mulls to promote tribal culture in the country
pr_content: Union Tribal Affairs Ministry is in the process of finalisation of an Expenditure Finance Committee (EFC) Memo for a new Scheme titled ‘Financial Assistance for Support, Promotion, Expansion and Dissemination of Art and Culture and Traditional Sporting Events of Scheduled Tribe Communities’ and the guidelines for the implementation of the said Sheme. The scheme along with the draft EFC Memo, is being circulated amongst the experts of the Tribal Art for their comments/suggestions. Pending finalisation of this Scheme, the Ministry has, however, projected to the Planning Commission the requirement of additional funds amounting to Rs.2.5 crore (recurring) per annum approximately.

pr_title: Press Communique
pr_content: The President is pleased to appoint (1) Shri Kantilal Ambalal Puj and (2) Shri Jayant Maganlal Patel, to be Additional Judges of the Gujarat High Court, in that order of seniority, for a period of two years each with effect from December 3, 2003.

pr_title: High Power Parliamentary Delegation from Ukraine called on the Vice President of India
pr_content: Chairman of the Rajya Sabha and Vice President of India, Shri Bhairon Singh Shekhawat expressed happiness over recent intensification of bilateral exchanges between India and Ukraine, which have covered a wide range of areas like steel, space, science and technology, and defence. The high-power Parliamentary delegation from Ukraine called on the Vice President of India today. The growing bilateral cooperation between the two countries have provided opportunities to exploit existing areas of cooperation with major focus on defence, military and technical cooperation, metallurgy, power, transport, space etc. and on identifying new areas of bilateral cooperation in IT, telecommunication, banking etc. Mr. M.V. Lytvyn, Chairman of the Parliament of Ukraine expressed his desire to further intensify the interaction with the Parliaments of both the countries. He also invited Chairman of the Rajya Sabha to visit Ukraine. Shri Shekhawat expressed his keen interest in the agriculture of Ukraine. He also apprised the delegation that there is increasing awareness about Ukraine among the Indian business community. Shri Shekhawat apprised the Chairman of Ukraine Parliamentary delegation about the functioning of the Upper House of the Indian Parliament and its proceedings etc. The 11-member high power delegation includes the Chairman/Members of the Parliamentary Committees of Ukraine

pr_title: Export growth sustained INDIA’S FOREIGN TRADE DATA: APRIL-OCTOBER 2003-04
pr_content: India’s Exports during April-October, 2003-2004 are valued at US $ 32092.42 million which is 8.44% higher than the level of US $ 29595.19 million during April-October, 2002-2003. This is over and above 19.13% export growth in April-October, 2002-03 over the corresponding previous period. In rupee terms, the exports were Rs. 148691.84 crore, during April- October, 2003-2004 which is 3.15% higher than the value of exports during April- October, 2002-2003. Exports during October, 2003 are valued at US $ 4884.66 million which is 5.07% higher than the level of US $ 4649.16 million during October, 2002. This is over and above the 25.05% export growth in October, 2002 over October, 2001. In rupee terms, the exports in October, 2003 were Rs. 22170.16 crore, which is 1.42% lower than the value of exports during October, 2002. India’s Imports during April-October, 2003-2004 are valued at US $ 41361.66 million representing an increase of 21.46% over the level of imports valued at US $ 34052.68 million in April- October, 2002-2003. In Rupee terms, the imports have increased from Rs. 165854.55 crore to Rs. 191660.54 crore showing a growth of 15.56% during the period. Oil imports during April- October, 2003-2004 are valued at US $ 10867.64 million which is 6.48% higher than oil imports valued at US $ 10206.48 million in the corresponding period last year. Non-oil imports during April- October, 2003-2004 are estimated at US $ 30494.02 million which is 27.88% higher than the level of such imports valued at US $ 23846.20 million in April- October, 2002-2003. Imports during October, 2003 are valued at US $ 6905.70 million representing an increase of 23.47 % over the level of imports valued at US $ 5593.07 million in October, 2002. In Rupee terms the imports increased by 15.85% during October, 2003. The trade deficit for April- October, 2003-2004 is estimated at US $ 9269.24 million which is higher than the deficit at US $ 4457.49 million during April- October, 2002-2003. Tables giving details of exports, imports and trade balance, according to the provisional estimates of Directorate General of Commercial Intelligence & Statistics (DGCI&S) are attached. pr_title: India wins GSP case against EC at the WTO
pr_content: A WTO dispute settlement panel established at India’s request in January 2003 has upheld India’s contention that the European Communities has violated its GATT/WTO obligations in granting tariff preferences to 12 countries under the “Drug Arrangements” window of its GSP scheme without extending these preferences to other developing countries. The Panel has also ruled that the EC has failed to demonstrate that the Drug Arrangements are justified under the Enabling Clause, which otherwise allows the developed countries to grant tariff preferences to developing countries without allowing the same advantage to developed countries. India would seek the adoption of the panel report at the earliest in accordance with the provisions of the Dispute Settlement Understanding. Disputing parties in the WTO have a right to appeal a decision of the panel to the Appellate Body. This WTO ruling is likely to provide some relief to the Indian exporters to EC, particularly those in the apparel sector, who are otherwise disadvantaged by duty concessions to Pakistan under the Drug Arrangements. India’s dispute with EC had arisen primarily because EC included Pakistan as beneficiary country under its Special Tariff Arrangement for Combating Drug Production and Trafficking under its GSP Scheme for the years 2002-04. Such a scheme was in operation even in earlier years with beneficiaries being restricted to ANDEAN and Central American countries. While the scheme, in India’s view was not compatible with WTO rules even then, it had not agitated the matter in WTO since it was not significantly affected. However, with the inclusion of Pakistan as a beneficiary country with effect from 1.1.2002, Indian exports were directly affected, since there are a number of export sectors such as clothing where the two countries are close competitors in the EC market. The sudden and significant (a 9.6 % tariff preference for instance on certain apparel products) advantage granted to Pakistani products has disadvantaged a significant level of trade flowing from India to EC. India invoked dispute settlement proceedings of the WTO in this case with extreme reluctance and after having exhausted all available avenues for a negotiated settlement with the EC. The matter was taken up repeatedly with the EC at various levels including at the ministerial level. Even after initiating the dispute under WTO’s dispute settlement procedures in March 2002, India continued its effort in seeking a bilateral solution to the problem with EC. However at no stage did EC respond positively to India’s concerns. India continued these efforts even after the panel proceedings were at an advanced stage. During the panel proceedings India also clarified that while it did not dispute EC’s right to give financial assistance to individual developing countries facing problems relating to drug production and trafficking, this could not be done at the expense of other developing countries facing different but equally pressing needs. India also urged EC to obtain a WTO waiver for these arrangements through prescribed procedures under the WTO Agreement. Certain other beneficiaries of the Drug Arrangements implored EC to seek a waiver. However, EC insisted on continuing the dispute. The WTO panel has vindicated India’s stand that the tariff preference under the Drug Arrangements are not given unconditionally to all developing countries. The Panel was not convinced by EC’s contention that the Drug Arrangements are justified under the Enabling Clause. The Panel found that the EC’s Drug Arrangements, as a GSP scheme, do not provide identical tariff preferences to all developing countries and that the differentiation is neither for the purpose of special treatment to the least-developed countries, nor in the context of the implementation of a priori measures. The panel has recommended that the Dispute Settlement Body requests the EC to bring its measure into conformity with its obligations under GATT. Indian exporters to the EC have suffered considerable loss on account of the 10% tariff concessions available to exports from Pakistan of similar products. They can now hope to obtain some succour after the EC implements the findings of the panel in this dispute.

pr_title: Indo South African Defence Meet
pr_content: The South African Defence Secretary Mr. JB Masilela called on Defence Secretary Shri Ajay Prasad in South Block here today. Later delegation level talks were held between India and South Africa. Various matters of mutual interest and defence cooperation were discussed during the delegation level talks. Meetings of two sub-committees on defence technologies and defence policy & defence cooperation were also held. The South African delegation, which arrived yesterday, is on a five-day official visit to India.

pr_title: NCC Cadets to leave for Singapore
pr_content: A group of eight (four boys and four girls) NCC cadets which is going to Singapore to participate in Camp Pinnacle 2003 under Youth Exchange Programme called on the Directorate General NCC Lt Gen SK Bopanna here today. Gen Bopanna offered them his best wishes and exhorted them to bring glory to the country as the young ambassadors of India. During their stay in Singapore, the cadets will visit various historical sites and places of interest besides participating in the camp. They will Singapore families for two days to have closer interaction and to share the experience of their values and culture. The members of the delegation are Sgt Tushar Menon, Sgt Bhadari Jigna, Sgt Vinita BG, Cadet Sarath R, SUO Lata Shetry, Cpl Asha Nair, UO Heerak Das and Cpl R Shruthi. The delegation will leave for Singapore on 04th of this month and will return on Dec 14, 2003.

pr_title: Project Management
pr_content: The 12th Global Symposium-2003 on Taming the Future through Project Management is being organized from 8th to 10th December 2003 in New Delhi. Organized jointly by the Ministry of Statistics & Programme Implementation, Project Management Associates, Centre for Excellence in Project Management, International Project Management Association, Switzerland and many other organizations, the symposium provides a forum to learn and share the most contemporary happenings in the field of project management worldwide. People from all disciplines such as agriculture, construction, finance, engineering, HRD, infrastructure, IT, manufacturing, marketing, planning, projects, R&D, operations, software, services, NGOs etc. can benefit from the symposium who wish to make their organisations locally & globally competitive. With today’s unprecedented rate of change, project management is emerging as a key discipline, which can provide control on future. Project management is not limited to time and cost but covers all aspects of risk, quality, human resource, communication, procurement & integration. ‘Faster, better, cheaper’ can be realized through effective project management processes. Project management is not merely confined to construction projects but effectively encompasses all business aspects of a company. Fortune 500 companies are reducing total cycle time by using project management methodologies.

pr_title: Shri Ashok Pradhan inaugurates BSNL’s Mobile Service at Sikandrabad in Uttar Pradesh
pr_content: The Minister of State for Communications and Information Technology, Shri Ashok Pradhan has announced that mobile services would soon be started at Gulaothi, Debai, Anupshahar, Siyana, Pahasu, Shikarpur and Norora in Bulandshahar district in Uttar Pradesh (UP) during the current financial year. He was speaking at a function to inaugurate the Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited (BSNL)’s mobile service at Sikandrabad(UP). today. The Minister said that the Bulandshahar telecom district has 47 electronic exchanges with a total switching capacity of the Secondary Switching Area(SSA) reaching to more than 84,000 lines including WLL and mobile. However, he expressed dissatisfaction over the lower tele-density of the SSA which stands at 2.3 percent. The Minister strongly advocated the need for telecom infrastructure in the District, especially in the rural areas. Giving details of the development of telecom infrastructure in the country, Shri Ashok Pradhan stated that the total telephone connections in the country were only 2.15 crore in the year 1999 which has now reached 4.73 crore as on 31st October, 2003. Similarly, mobile telephone connections have also reached 1.93 crore as on 31st October, 2003 from mere 12 lakh in 1999. The tele-density of the country has reached 6.24% as on 31st October, 2003 from mere 2.23% in 1999. As per the Telecom Policy, 1999, the tele-density of the country has been targeted to reach 7 by the year 2005 and 15 by the year 2010. The Government is confident to achieve these targets much earlier than planned because of the various steps taken by the Government for the development of the telecom infrastructure of the country, the Minister added. On this occasion, the Minister announced to start the following services in Bulandshahar SSA very soon:- The mobile services at Debai and Guwahati will be launched next week. The mobile services at Narora, Sikarpur, Pahasu and Anupshahar will be launched by March, 2004. 7000 lines NEAX exchange at Bulandshahar and 5000 lines NEAX exchange at Khurja will be repalced by 12000 lines new technology exchange by March, 2004. 7000 lines TAX will be commissioned next year. The integrated billing package DOTSOFT will be started on 26th January, 2004. This will facilitate the issue of duplicate bills and on-line bill payment from all the customer service centers in the SSA. Bulandshahar and Khurja City will be made poleless by laying cable upto the subscriber’s premises.

pr_title: Armed Forces Flag Day observed
pr_content: The Armed Forces Flag Day was observed throughout the country today. On this occasion President Shri APJ Abdul Kalam, Vice President Shri Bhairon Singh Shekhawat, Prime Minister Shri Atal Behari Vajpayee and Deputy Prime Minister Shri LK Advani and the Defence Minister Shri George Fernandes and the Minister of State for Defence Prof Chaman Lal Gupta have all extended greetings and felicitations to the serving and retired soldiers, sailors, airmen and their families. The Chief of the Army Staff Gen NC Vij, Chief of Naval Staff Admiral Madhvendra Singh, Chief of Air Staff Air Chief Marshal S Krishnaswamy, Defence Secretary Shri Ajay Prasad and Director General Resettlement Major General VS Budhwar have also greeted serving and retired soldiers on this occasion and appealed to the citizens to contribute to the Armed Forces Flag Day Fund.

pr_title: Shri Sitaram Maroo
pr_content: The Prime Minister, Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee has expressed profound grief at the demise of renowned journalist and social activist, Shri Sitaram Maroo, Managing Director of Ranchi Express, Ranchi. In a message from Abuja, Nigeria, where he is attending the CHOGM summit, Shri Vajpayee said that Shri Maroo was an effective communicator, who adhered to the traditions and ethics of journalism throughout his life. Shri Maroo was a true son of the soil, who was actively engaged in social service till he breathed his last, the Prime Minister added.

pr_title: Rail Tunnel through Pir Panjal
pr_content: The work of construction of new line from Udhampur to Baramulla is already in progress. This will involve construction of tunnel across Pir Panjal range. The construction of tunnel is likely to start during 2004-2005 after necessary works. The project is targeted for completion by August 15, 2007. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri P. Prabhakara Reddy in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Double-stack container trains
pr_content: A feasibility study is in progress for the movement of double stack containers to and from the ports on the west coast, namely Kandla, Pipavav and Mundra. The Report has not yet been submitted. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri B.J. Panda in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Rail Projects in A.P. with ADB loan
pr_content: Asian Development Bank (ADB) has approved a loan of US$ 313.6 million to finance the Rail Sector Improvement Projects. Currently, the project of doubling of Gooty-Pullampet rail link in Andhra Pradesh has been appraised by ADB for funding under this loan. The work on the project has already been taken up. The project is likely to be completed by March 2008. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Dr. Alladi P. Rajkumar in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Light weight coaches
pr_content: Indian Railways had entered into a contract in October 1995 with M/s Linke—Hoffman—Busch (LHB) Germany (now M/s Alstom-LHB) for the Transfer of Technology (TOT) to manufacture light weight, high speed coaches fit for 160 kmph on Indian Railway system. The TOT was given to Rail Coach Factory (RCF), Kapurthala and RCF has since manufactured and turned out 52 coaches of the new design till date. The new coaches are ready for introduction in the Mumbai-New Delhi Rajdhani Express service shortly. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Karnedu Bhattacharjee in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: India develops MEOR technique for oil extraction
pr_content: India has developed the Microbial Enhanced Oil Recovery (MEOR) Technique for increasing production from oil wells, the Lok Sabha was informed today. The technique, developed jointly by the scientists of The Energy and Resource Centre (TERI) and Oil and Natural Gas Corporation (ONGC) is at field trial stage, Shri Ram Naik, Minister of Petroleum & Natural Gas has said in reply to questions on "Discovery of Microbes for oil extraction." He said the technology had been applied to 15 low productivity ONGC wells of Cambay onland basin in Gujarat. This included nine wells in Kalol, one each in Limbodra and North Kadi, and four wells in Sobhashan fields. A sum of Rs. 1.46 crore had been earmarked for the field trials. He assured that funds would not be a problem adding that besides India, China and Malaysia were also doing researches on use of microbes for enhanced oil extraction. Shri Naik said the MEOR technique was applicable to certain specific reservoir conditions and oil type conditions to enhance oil production from low producing wells. However, the technique could not be applied for revival of sick wells in general. Shri Naik said that once the field trials are successfully completed, the technique would be used for commercial application. He hoped that the ongoing trials would be successful. Shri Naik informed that ONGC had about 475 sick oil wells in onland areas and 35 in offshore areas.

pr_title: Use of old unused tracks
pr_content: The materials, released from main link track renewals which still have residual service life, are re-used for laying track in gauge conversion and secondary renewal, where it can meet the requirement. During the current financial year, till October 31, 2003, a total of 690 kms, has been renewed with used material released from the track. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Santosh Bagrodia in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Auxiliary Warning System in Railways
pr_content: It has been planned to adopt Train Protection and Warning System (TPWS), a variant of Auxiliary Warning System (AWS), to further enhance safety levels in train operations by preventing cases of ‘Signal Passed at Danger’ in 280 Track kilometres of ‘A’ route on Southern and North Central Railway, on trial basis. Functionality wise there is no difference between the two systems, which are basically meant to prevent driver passing signal at danger. However, both the systems use different technologies to achieve the intended functionality. The conventional AWA system uses track magnet, which are basically made of Copper, as track device making it prone to thefts. Information about signal aspect, in AWS, is transmitted from track device to cab equipment through electro magnetic induction. TPWS use Euro Balise as a track device, which is an electronic device with very less copper inside and it uses radio transmission for sending information to cab equipment. TPWS is basically meant to prevent driver from passing a signal at danger thereby preventing accident thereof. The system does not have any functionality, which can curtail outside interference of rail installation, such as track and signal equipment. This information was given by the Minister of Railways Shri Nitish Kumar in a written reply to a question from Shri Rama Muni Reddy Sirigireddy in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Recommendations of Passenger Amenities Committee
pr_content: The important observations/suggestions made by the Passenger Amenities Committee relate to removal of encroachments from railway land and generation of revenue from surplus land, prevention of entry of unauthorized vendors in moving trains, spending of funds for passenger amenities on facilities like drinking water, seating arrangements, maintenance of waiting halls, toilets, lights, fans and not on major construction works and monitoring the quality of meals. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Tarini Kanta Roy in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Sky Bus Service
pr_content: The Sky Bus is not in practice in any part of the world. Trials for proving the technology are yet to be conducted. Once the technology is proved and certified, there are 15 cities in India and 7 cities abroad who have expressed their interest to Konkan Railway Corporation Ltd. to have this technology. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Priya Ranjan Dasmunsi in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Sale of contaminated water at Railway Station
pr_content: A surprise inspection was conducted by the Minister of State for Railways at Old Delhi Railway station on September 25, 2003 and some deficiencies were noticed in the sealing of Rail Neer bottles and it appeared as if these had been refilled by vendors of four stalls/trolleys. Indian Railways Catering and Tourism Corporation Ltd. (IRCTC) has taken immediate steps to improve the quality of seal caps. An in-depth enquiry was conducted by Northern Railway and IRCTC which has revealed that there is no complicity on the part of any Railway Official. However, vendors of stalls/trolleys responsible for selling refilled Rail Neer bottles at Old Delhi station were punished suitably. Preventive checks have since been intensified by the Northern Railway to curb filling up tap water in Rail Neer bottles. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri N. Janardhana Reddy in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Deccan Odyssey luxury train
pr_content: A Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) has been signed between the Indian Railways and the Maharashtra Tourism Development Corporation for running of a luxury tourist train which would originate and terminate at Mumbai and cover the tourist destinations of Ratnagiri, Sindhudrug, Goa, Pune, Aurangabad and Nasik. The Railways would be responsible for the operation of the train while the Maharashtra Tourism Development Corporation would provide all the facilities necessary for the onboard services and local sightseeing. The arrangements for launch of the train are under finalization. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Chandrakant Khaire in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Setting up power plant by Railways in Nabinagar
pr_content: The Railways have planned to set up a power plant jointly with NTPC in Nabinagar in Bihar. It is proposed to instal four units of 250 MW each at a cost of Rs. 4374 crores. For this purpose a Joint Venture Company “Bhartiya Rail Bijlee Company” is proposed, to be formed with National Thermal Power Corporation Ltd. (NTPC). About seven years time will be taken for fructification from the date of Cabinet approval. Forty-nine per cent equity will be by NTPC. Annual saving of about Rs. 400 crores is anticipated on commissioning of this project on the basis of current level of traffic and electric traction tariff. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Arun Kumar in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Private Sector participation in Railways
pr_content: Some identified non-core activities are already being executed by agencies other than Railways. Recently, activities like catering, tourism and telecommunication development with optic fibre cables have been corporatised through Indian Railway Catering and Tourism Corporation (IRCTC) and Railtel Corporation of India Ltd. (RAILTEL). The Ministry of Railways is exploring possibilities of forging public-private partnerships in funding of rail infrastructure projects. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Ananta Nayak in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Expansion of Tamluk-Contai rail line
pr_content: On Tamluk-Digha (87.50 km) new line project, the work of Tamluk-Kanthi (Contai) (56.6 km) section has been completed. Efforts are being made to complete the work beyond Kanthi (Contai) up to Digha during 2004-2005. The Tamluk-Digha (87.50 km) new line work is presently sanctioned at a cost of Rs. 293.97 crore. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Rupchand Murmu in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Passenger amenities at Delhi Railway Stations
pr_content: The proposals for development of passenger amenities at Delhi Main Station (Old Delhi), New Delhi Station and Hazrat Nizamuddin Station are in various stages of implementation. Pre-paid taxi and auto-rickshaw services at these stations are run by Delhi Traffic Police. Pre-paid scheme for auto-rickshaw is available at all these stations. However, as a result of a court case in Delhi High Court between Taxi Operator Association and Delhi Traffic Police, taxi operators stopped coming to pre-paid booth at these railway stations. However, ‘rent-a-car’ system is functional at Ajmeri Gate side of New Delhi Station. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basanagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Anantha Nayak in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Uranium mining in Andhra Pradesh
pr_content: The Minister of Mines, Shri Ramesh Bais has assured that all requisite statutory clearances including environmental clearance will be obtained before commencement of the Uranium mining project in Nalgonda, Andhra Pradesh. The Minister gave this assurance in a written reply to the question of Shri R. Raamachandrayya in Rajya Sabha today. Shri Bais stated that as part of the process of obtaining environmental clearance, Environmental Impact Assessment (EIA) and Environment Management Plan (EMP) have been prepared for this Uranium Mining Project. These also include measures to ensure safety of the people residing around the area.

pr_title: No mining lease for bauxite to any multinational company
pr_content: No Mining lease has been granted for Bauxite in favour of any multinational company. This was stated by the Minister of Mines Shri Ramesh Bais in a written reply to the question of Shri Janeshwar Mishra in Rajya Sabha today. Shri Bais stated that Mining leases are granted by the State Government as per provisions of Mines and Minerals (Development and Regulation) Act, 1957 (MMDR Act) and the rules made thereunder. Before granting reconnaissance permit, prospecting licence or mining lease in respect of minerals included in the First Schedule to the MMDR Act, the State Governments are required to seek approval of the Central Government. These proposals are processed and disposed of by the Central Government as per various provisions of the said Act. Under Section 5(1) of this Act, only an Indian national or a company registered in India can be granted a mineral concession. As per information furnished by Indian Bureau of Mines (IBM), a subordinate office of the Ministry of Mines, no mining lease has been granted for bauxite in favour of any multinational company.

pr_title: Sangeet Natak Akademi Awards-2003 announced
pr_content: Sangeet Natak Akademi Awards-2003 announced New Delhi, 3rd December, 2003 Agrahayana 12, 1925 Sangeet Natak Academi has announced its awards for the year 2003. 33 eminent persons will be conferred for these awards in diverse fields of performing arts. The awardees are: Ghulam Mustafa Khan Hindustani Vocal Yashwant Bua Joshi Hindustani Vocal Arvind Parekh Instrumental (Sitar) Bhavani Shankar Instrumental (Pakhawaj) Trichur V.
