pr_title: Issue of shares against external commercial borrowings permitted - Press Note
pr_content: Vide Press Note No. 3 (2003 series) dated 28th July, 2003 issue of equity shares against lumpsum free, royalty and External Commercial Borrowings (ECBs) in convertible foreign currency already due for payment/repayment, subject to meeting all applicable tax liabilities and procedures has been permitted. As a part of the ongoing process of liberalisation, it has been decided to permit issue of equity shares against all External Commercial Borrowings (excluding those deemed as ECBs) received in convertible foreign currency, subject to meeting all tax liabilities and procedures.

pr_title: Jaitley approves 15 proposals of Foreign Technology Collaboration/Franchise Agreements
pr_content: The Commerce & Industry Minister, Shri Arun Jaitley, has approved 15 proposals of foreign technology collaboration/franchise agreements based on the recommendations of the Project Approval Board (PAB) and 9 proposals for grant of Industrial Licence based on the recommendations of the Licensing Committee (LC). The PAB in its meeting held on 20.11.2003 under the Chairmanship of Shri Rajeeva Ratna Shah, Secretary, Department of Industrial Policy & Promotion, had recommended these proposals for approval. The approved proposals include technical collaboration agreement of M/s Tata Motors Ltd. with M/s AVL List GmbH, Austria and M/s Delphi Diesel Systems SAS, France for design and development of Euro IV compliant engine , with EOBD emission norms, for passenger cars. The engine developed under this agreement will help Tata Motors improve their exports, especially in the European Markets in which the Euro-IV emission norms will come into force from 1st January, 2005. The proposal for technology agreement of M/s Finolex Industries Ltd. with M/s. Oxy Vinyls, LP, USA and M/s Aker Kvaerner, Netherlands, for manufacture of Vinyl Chloride Monomer was also approved. The improved technology uses less energy, reduces emissions and improves the conversion rates of feed stock. The proposal of M/s Spicer India Ltd., for extension of their technical agreement with M/s Dana Corporation, USA which will enable the Company to manufacture, inter-alia, Driveshafts for super heavy vehicles and maintenance free Driveshafts was also included in the list of approved cases. The Licensing Committee (LC), in its meeting held on 20.11.2003, under the Chairmanship of Shri Rajeeva Ratna Shah, Secretary, Department of Industrial Policy & Promotion, had recommended 9 proposals for grant of Industrial License and amendments in existing ones. The main sectors/areas of the approvals include textiles, explosives, petroleum and material handling equipments. The detailed list of approved cases is available on the website of the Department of Industrial Policy & Promotion viz., http://dipp.nic.in.

pr_title: Railside Warehousing Scheme
pr_content: Encouraged by the success by the Whitefield (Bangalore) rail-side warehousing scheme, with a godown capacity of 15,000 Million Tonnes built by M/s Central Warehousing Corporation (CWC) in February 2002, Indian Railways are entering into a Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) with the CWC, as its strategic partner, for development of similar integrated rail-side warehouse complexes at 22 locations. The rail-side warehousing complexes are to be built by the CWC at its own cost like that of the Whitefield pilot project. It generated additional revenue of Rs. 20 crores annually. The rail-side warehousing provides integrated seamless services to customers and reduces the overall logistic costs. The 22 locations for development of rail-side warehouse complexes are New Guwahati (Assam), Changsari (Assam), Shakur Basti (Delhi), Holambikalan (Delhi), Ambala (Haryana), Rohtak (Haryana), Gangapur City (Rajasthan), Rajkot (Gujarat), Kalamboli (Navi Mumbai), Pune (Maharashtra), Nasik (Maharashtra), Hatia (Jharkhand), Mandya (Karnataka), Hassan (Karnataka), Hubli (Karnataka), Hosur (Karnataka), Dharampuri (Karnataka), Kottayam (Kerala), Kannur (Kerala), Sambalpur (Orissa), and Royapuram Chennai (Tamil Nadu).

pr_title: Complimetary railway passes
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA To check against the possibility of misuse, complimentary rail passes are issued to various categories with a validity of one year or a maximum of two years, at a time to be renewed thereafter. The validity for complimentary card passes issued to ex-Minister of Railways, ex-Minister of State for Railways, ex-Deputy Minister of Railways, Nobel laureate Shri Amartya Sen and Ms. Rasoolan Bibi, widow of Late Abdul Hamid, Param Veer Chakra Awardee is for life time. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basnagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Abu Asim Azmi in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Development of Anand Vihar Terminal
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA The scope of works for development of Anand Vihar terminal in Delhi envisages construction of three platforms, two washing lines and three stabling lines along with other necessary service buildings and infrastructure. The estimated cost of the project is Rs. 85 crore and is targeted to be completed within five years subject to availability of funds. Detailed survey of the entire land has been conducted, master plan of terminal facilities developed and detailed estimate sanctioned. The tender for appointing architectural/design consultant for designing terminal facilities, station building and circulating area has been processed. The work was sanctioned in 2003-2004 and necessary preliminary works of detailed survey, finalization of scheme and sanction of detailed estimate completed. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basnagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Kalraj Mishra in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Siding track of Kribhco
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA The project to connect Hajira Port to its hinterland is a part of the port connectivity initiative under the National Rail Vikas Yojana (NRVY). The project can be taken up once the financial feasibility is established by the technical and financial study underway. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basnagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Bachani Lekhraj in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Railway recrutiments
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA For recruitment process of Railway Recruitment Boards, interviews have been done away with from the selection process in most of the categories. It is ensured that selections are conducted in a transparent, free and fair manner. Candidates from any part of the country are free to apply to the vacancies advertised by any of the Railway Recruitment Boards under the extant provisions laid down in the directives of Department of Personnel and Training, Government of India, which in turn are based on Hon’ble Supreme Court’s judgement for giving wide publicity for filling up ‘C’ and Group ‘D’ posts. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basnagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Matilal Sarkar in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Quota for locals in railway job
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA Direct recruitment to Group ‘C’ and ‘D’ posts on the Railways are made by selection through Railway Recruitment Boards. The vacancies are given wide publicity including publication in the Employment News and all those who apply against such notifications are considered for recruitment on the Railways. This procedure is in conformity with the Constitutional provisions regarding equality in opportunity to all in the matter of employment under the Central Government and the guidelines issued by the Department of Personnel and Training (which is a nodal Department), pursuant to directives of the Supreme Court. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basnagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Surendra Lath in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Palace on Wheels in different states
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA Luxury tourist train—the "Palace on Wheels"—is being run in Rajasthan in collaboration with the Rajasthan Tourism Development Corporation (RTDC) and the "Royal Orient Express" in Gujarat in collaboration with M/s Tourism Corporation of Gujarat Ltd. (TCGL). On request from State Governments, the Railways run luxury tourist trains for promotion of rail tourism in collaboration with State Tourism Departments Memorandums of Understanding (MoUs) have already been signed for running of such trains in Maharashtra and no-time frame has been fixed in this regard. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basnagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Shri Rumandla Raamachandrayya in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Missing of blankets and sheets at Patna junction
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA From the store of Patna Junction, 500 blankets, 900 bed sheets, 800 pillow covers and 100 big towels were found missing. The assessment of the actual loss is still going on. In this connection, GRP/Patna Junction has registered a case wide Crime No. 402/03 dated November 27, 2003 U/S 461/379 IPC. Apart from this, Railway administration has set up an enquiry under the supervision of ACM/Danapur to go into the fact and circumstances of the case. This information was given by the Minister of State for Railways Shri Basnagouda R. Patil in a written reply to a question from Prof. Ram Deo Bhandary in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Report of CRS on fire in Frontier mail
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA Commissioner of Railway Safety (CRS), North Eastern Circle, investigated the fire accident involving 2903 UP Golden Temple Mail (earlier known as Frontier Mail) on Ludhiana-Amritsar section of Northern Railway on May 14, 2003. He concluded that the most probable cause of the fire that took place in 2903 UP was a bag, lying in sleeper coach (S-4), which contained certain combustible, explosive materials and other compounds capable of spontaneous ignition, with some provision to cause and control the ignition. CRS fixed the ‘primary’ responsibility on ‘an unidentified person’ who either carried or left a bag containing explosive materials in the coach. However, he has also ascribed ‘secondary’ and ‘blameworthy’ responsibility on 6 on-board commercial staff for not vigilant and alert in performance of their duty and not performing specified duties after the accident. Disciplinary proceedings against the identified staff have been initiated. This information was given by the Minister of Railways Shri Nitish Kumar in a written reply to a question from S/Shri K. Rahman Khan and Rumandla Raamachandrayya in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Import facilitation for construction industry
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA The Government has examined the representations from the construction industry regarding the adverse impact of increasing steel prices. In a deregulated and liberalized environment, prices are determined by the free interplay of market forces. Nevertheless, as a measure of import facilitation, the Government has removed 33 steel items from the purview of DGFT Notification No. 44 with effect from 28th October, 2003. Inclusion of steel items in the DGFT Notification No. 44 required the exporters of these steel items to India to register themselves with the Bureau of Indian Standards and was being viewed as a non-tariff barrier. Prices of steel items that reached a peak in August 2003 have subsequently stabilised. The recent upswing in steel prices has had the effect of reducing the profit margins of downstream consumer industries. However, the import facilitation as a result of withdrawal of steel items from the purview of DGFT Notification No. 44 has provided the option to downstream steel consumers to source their requirements through imports. Exporters can also avail of the Advance license route for importing their inputs at zero custom duty. This information was given by the Minister for Steel, Shri B.K. Tripathy in a written reply in Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Disinvestment of Rashtriya Ispat Nigam
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA There is a proposal before the Government for disinvesting Rashtriya Ispat Nigam. It is based on the recommendations of Disinvestment Commission contained in its XIIth Report which are as follows :- The entire accumulated losses of the Company of Rs.4,065.30 crores as on 31.03.1999 should be written off by the Government against its entire share money pending allotment and preference share capital and a part of the equity capital to clean up its balance sheet and keep the company from being referred to BIFR; and Simultaneously to initiate process of disinvestment of not less than 51% of its remaining equity holding in RINL to a strategic buyer. In view of the strengths of the plant, the Commission feels the investor interest in acquiring RINL after the balance sheet is cleaned up. The selection of strategic buyer should be done through global competitive bidding by pre-qualification of bidders. Disinvestment Commission has given the following reasons for their above mentioned recommendations:- The Disinvestment Commission classified RINL as non-core and opined that no public purpose would be served by retaining RINL under Government ownership. Steel industry in India is completely decontrolled with the presence of large number of private producers. Imports are freely permitted with declining import duties. Hence, the Steel market is fully contestable not only vis-à-vis Indian producers but also other steel majors in the world. The public sector steel industry in India would, therefore, have to compete in the highly competitive and technology/market driven international steel sector. Since public sector form of management does not allow such flexibility/investments it would be advisable to disinvest majority Government equity in RINL. RINL has distinct advantages of its location, layout, technology and should be an ideal steel plant in India for steel majors in the world to invest in. With proper restructuring the plant can be converted into a 10 million tonne export oriented plant by one of the international steel majors. The next steel upturn is expected in 2002 and plant should be disinvested looking at the time of the next steel upturn. The Disinvestment Commission felt that the company needed substantial financial support from Government of India for financial restructuring and expansion and that as this would involve huge cash outflow from the Government, this would not be justified and is avoidable. It was further of the view that capital expansion in the steel plant would be more expensive in terms of time and money if undertaken while remaining under Government of India control. The turn over and profit/loss of Rashtriya Ispat Nigam during the last four years, year-wise are as under :-(Rs. in crores) Item 1999-2000 2000-01 2001-02 2002-03 Turnover 2973 3436 4081 5059 Net Profit -562 -291.30 -75 521 This information was given by the Minister for Steel, Shri B.K. Tripathy in a written reply in Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Naresh Chandra Committee Report to be discussed By Parliamentary Consultative Committee attached to Civil Aviation Ministry
pr_content: The Parliamentary Consultative Committee attached to the Civil Aviation Ministry will discuss the Naresh Chandra Committee Report before it is sent to the Cabinet. Assurance to this effect was given by the Civil Aviation Minister Shri Rajiv Pratap Rudy at the Consultative Committee meeting here today. Several members observed that the recommendations of the committee have far reaching consequences and therefore need to be deliberated by the members. The meeting will take place early next month as there is a need to expedite the process for a Civil Aviation Policy. Today’s meeting was called to discuss the sub-committee report on Indian Airlines. Participating in the discussion members pointed out that the government should expedite the decision to purchase new aircraft for Indian Airlines as the delay was leading to fall in its market share. They also suggested that the government should strengthen the equity of Indian Airlines by providing Rs.325 crore as recommended by the Kelkar Committee Report. Members also supported the recommendations of the sub committee that there should be a judicious application of the guidelines for operation on category II and category III routes on all the operators, so that the burden of uneconomic operation is equally shared failing which Indian Airlines should be compensated for the losses incurred by them in excess of the guidelines as a part of their social commitment. They felt that there is an urgent need to redefine the routes/stations to be covered under categories I, II, III and to ensure a level playing field. Members demanded that operators should be asked to publish Citizens Charter and carry stretcher patients on all routes. They expressed satisfaction at the improvement in the quality of service both at the airports and during flights. In his opening remarks the Civil Aviation Minister Shri Rajiv Pratap Rudy gave an overview of the important developments since the last meeting. He said, India and Pakistan will resume direct air links and over flights with effect from1st January, 2004 on reciprocal basis. He also briefed the members about the decisions in relation to the flights to and from the ASEAN countries and Sri Lanka by their designated carriers. The Minister said that Reduced Vertical Separation Minima (RVSM) has been introduced in the Indian and surrounding airspace with effect from 27th November 2003. Members of Parliament who attended today’s meeting are Shri Ashok Mohol, Shri Ram Pal Singh, Shri Ashok Argel, Shri Harpal Singh Sathi, Shri Tarlochan Singh Tur, Shri S. Murugesan, Smt. Reena Chowdhary, Dr. Ashok Patel, Shri Ratilal K. Verma, Shri Paban Singh Ghatowar, Shri Ramesh Chennithala, Smt. Renu Kumari, Smt. Kanti Singh, Shri A.P. Jithender Reddy, Dr. Madan Prasad Jaiswal, Smt. Jayaben Thakkar and Shri Pravin Rashtrapal from the Lok Sabha and Shri Ram Nath Kovind, Shri Sanjay Nirupam, Dr. L.M. Singhvi, Shri Santosh Bagrodia and Shri Rajiv Shukla from the Rajya Sabha.

pr_title: Labour Consultative Committee meeting deliberates upon the social security scheme for the unorganised sector
pr_content: Dr. Sahib Singh, Union Labour Minister has said that the Government has enacted some important legislations for the workers including unorganized workers. There are few Welfare Funds being implemented by the Central Government and certain schemes being run by some States for such workers. But the overall coverage under all the schemes is less than even one crore. In addition to this, several poverty alleviation schemes/programmes for the rural poor are under implementation. The Government is also implementing Janshree Bima Yojana through LIC to provide insurance cover to the people below and marginally above the poverty line. He was addressing the consultative committee meeting attached to the Ministry of Labour today. He further said that there is general acceptance amongst all quarters that there is a need to provide social security to these workers and as well as that a Bill to this effect be introduced in the Parliament. The proposed Bill envisages to regulate the employment and conditions of service of unorganized sector workers and to provide for old age pension, health, safety, social security and welfare and labour protection. The proposed legislation, inter-alia provides for establishment of a Central Unorganized Sector Workers Welfare Board and similar Boards at the State Level, Unorganised Workers’ Welfare Fund both at the Central and State level and formulation of social security/welfare schemes. To provide for social security measures to these workers the ‘Unorganised Workers’ Social Security Scheme, 2003 has been formulated in consultation with the experts and an Actuary and will be applicable to all workers drawing pay/wages/income not more than Rs.6500/- p.m. The Minister informed the meeting that the scheme will be implemented through the Employees Provident Fund Organization (EPFO) which will provide single window service to the workers for all the three components of the Scheme. The EPFO has got a wide network spread all over the country and would be able to implement the scheme with assistance and cooperation of Workers’ Facilitation Centres, the Employees State Insurance Corporation, other Insurance Companies and the Central and State labour machinery, and also the Panchayati Raj Institutions, Self-Help Groups and NGO, etc. The administrative cost for implementing the scheme would be within 1% of the contribution. These measures will go a long way in improving the living and working conditions of the workers in the unorganized sector. The members praised the minister for his excellent work done for this sector. Members also said that with these initiatives, this sector is taking shape. They also expressed the apprehensions in implementing the scheme. The Minister assured them that these will be taken care of. The meeting was attended by Smt. Sushila Saroj, Shri P. Rajendran, Shri K. Malaisamy and Shri Prabodh Panda, Members of Lok Sabha and Shri Ramchandra Khuntia and Shri Jibon Roy, Members of Rajya Sabha.

pr_issued_by: Ministry for Development of North-East Region
pr_title: Medical boon for North-East
pr_content: The North-Eastern Indira Gandhi Regional Institute of Health and Medical Sciences(NEIGRIHMS) is coming up apace at Shillong, the capital of Meghalaya. A cent per cent centrally-funded hospital, its first phase is to be commissioned by March 2004. The 500 bed super specialty hospital is under construction at Maw Diang Diang, about 7 kilometres from the main city, on 273 acres of prime land. The estimated cost of the project is nearly Rs. 423 crore. About Rs. 200 crore is being spent on constructing the hospital buildings. The entire project is likely to be completed by 2005. The engineering work has been completed. The first 300 beds in the hospital will be available by March 2004. This referral hospital is expected to be a boon for all the North-Eastern States once it is fully commissioned. Patients will not have to go for specialized treatment elsewhere in the country. It is also designed to nurture local talents. A heli-ambulance is among the facilities that NEIGRIHMS will have to airlift critically ill patients from anywhere in the North-East for treatment. Patients from Bangladesh will also largely benefit from the hospital. (PIB Special Services)

pr_title: Releasing of Central Share for ST schemes
pr_content: LOK SABHA The Ministry of Tribal Affairs does not release Central Share equity to the State Governments/UTs for implementing Scheduled Tribe schemes. However, the Ministry of Tribal Affairs releases funds to State Finance and Development Corporations towards their equity capital up to a maximum amount of 49% of the paid-up share capital of such Corporations. Further, Ministry of Tribal Affairs also releases funds to State Governments/UTs under various Central and Centrally sponsored Schemes of the Ministry for Welfare of the STs. This information was given by the Union Minister for Tribal Affairs, Shri Jual Oram in written reply to a question from Shri G. Putta Swamy Gowda in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: India asks for extradition of Union Carbide Chairman Warren Anderson
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA The Government has forwarded to the US Government a request for extradition of Warren Anderson, who was the chairman of Union Carbide Corporation when the infamous Bhopal gas leak occurred. This information was given by the Minister of State for Chemicals & fertilizers, Dr. Chhattra Pal Singh, in a written reply to a question in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Dr. Joshi in Cairo for ECCE meeting
pr_content: The Minister for Human Resource Development, Dr. Murli Manohar Joshi, has arrived in Cairo from Dubai to take part in the 5th E-9 Ministerial review meeting on Early childhood Care and Education i.e. ECCE. The meeting will consider the "Education for All" global Monitoring Report-2003, in the backdrop of international trends and national experiences. The E-9 group comprises India, Egypt, China, Mexico, Brazil, Pakistan, Bangladesh, Nigeria and Indonesia. The meeting opened today with expert level discussions. Tomorrow, at the ministerial review meeting, Dr. Joshi is expected to stress on gender equity and equality in education, in the light of the communiqué issued at the end of High Level Group Meeting in New Delhi last month. In Dubai, Dr, Joshi inaugurated a Indian Cultural Centre, at the Indian International High School. He said the focus of the new curriculum at all overseas Indian schools will be on India and its culture. The schools should also promote scientific research and popularise scientific temper. The Indian Cultural Centre will strive to promote a feeling of unity for and appreciation of India among people all over the world, as well as showcase the richness and diversity of Indian culture and history. Since its last meeting in Beijing two years ago, the E-9 countries have been working towards achieving the goal of "Education for All". During this period, these countries have prepared their national plans of action concerning early childhood care and education.

pr_title: All-India Consumer Price Index Numbers for Agricultural and Rural Labourers
pr_content: As compared to the month of October, 2003 the All-India Consumer Price Index Numbers for Agricultural Labourers and Rural Labourers ( Base: 1986-87=100) for November, 2003 remained stationary at 333 (Three hundred and thirty three) and 335 (Three hundred and thirty five) points respectively. The rise/fall in indices varied from State to State. In the case of Agricultural Labourers, 8 States reflected an increase ranging between 1 to 4 points in 10 States they showed a decrease ranging between 1 to 4 points while in 2 States they remained constant. Meghalaya with 354 points topped the index table whereas Manipur was at the bottom with index at 310 points. In the case of Rural Labourers in 7 States indices reflected an increase ranging between 1 to 4 points, in 10 States they showed a decrease ranging between 1 to 5 points while in 3 States they remained constant. Meghalaya was at the top of index table with index at 352 points whereas Manipur was at the bottom with index at 311 points. Bihar (including Jharkhand) and Meghalaya experienced a sharpest increase of 4 points each for Agricultural Labourers. On the other hand, Gujarat, Jammu & Kashmir, Madhya Pradesh and Rajasthan recorded a maximum decrease of 4 points each for Agricultural labourers and in case of Rural Labourers, Jammu & Kashmir recorded a maximum decrease of 5 points. Point to point rate of inflation based on CPI-AL and CPI-RL decreased from 3.42% and 3.40% in October, 2003 to 3.10% and 2.76% in November, 2003. Respective rates of inflation during November, 2002 were 3.19% and 3.16%. pr_title: Measures to be brought for greater credit flow to small scale sector: Dr.C.P.Thakur LABOUR LAWS SHOULD BE ABOLISHED FOR SMALL SCALE SECTOR
pr_content: Adequate and timely availability of credit at reasonable cost is most essential for the sustained growth, modernisation, upgradation and capacity expansion of SSI sector. This was stated by Dr. C.P. Thakur , Union Minister for Small Scale Industries and Development of North Eastern Region at the meeting held with the CMD’s of Public Sector Banks regarding lending to Small Scale Sector(SSI) at Udyog Bhavan here today. The meeting was held to discuss the status of credit flow to SSI Sector, the problems coming in the way of realisation of 12% annual growth target for SSI sector , creation of 4.4 million additional jobs during the 10th Five Year Plan and development of clusters which have economies of scale. Dr. C.P. Thakur said that employment generation was a concern of the Prime Minister also. A target of creation of additional 4.4 million jobs in SSI sector during the 10th five year plan with an annual growth of 12% for SSI sector has been fixed. Employment generation will mainly depend on small-scale sector, hence facilities should be given to them to compete with MNCs. There should be easy and cheap availability of credit to SSI, increase of risk taking by banks, increase in awareness about facilities and incentives to SSIs at branch level and facilitation of the problems of women entrepreneurs for SSI growth. Dr. C.P.Thakur said that labour laws should be abolished for small-scale sector which at present are a great hindrance in its growth. A Single window for SSI should be introduced. He said that banks should lend to small-scale sector at a rate not greater than their Prime Lending Rate (PLR). He also said that regional imbalances in growth have become huge. A meeting of bankers, Chief Ministers of states of West Bengal, Bihar, Eastern U.P. , Orissa and North East with the Minister will soon be called to sort out the problem of regional imbalance. The unanimous decision at the meeting was that there was no dearth of money in banking system for SSI lending . Dr. C.P. Thakur said that this attitudinal change of banks towards SSI was a heartening factor. In absolute terms the flow of SSI sector increased by over Rs. 3000 crores during 2002-2003. However, the share of credit to SSI sector as a percentage of net bank credit has declined to 11.1% in March 2003 which needs to be addressed. To improve the flow of credit the Minister suggested to fix a sub-target of 15% of Net Bank Credit within priority sector for SSI on the pattern of agriculture, to project for 15% annual growth in SSI credit at each bank level and to earmark 10% of incremental bank advances to SSI sector. There is a need to evolve a Uniform Scoring Model for banks to facilitate quick decisions on loan applications. This will ensure transparency in the processing of loan applications. The increase of limit for small-scale sector from Rs. one crore to three crores also came up for discussion. For increased awareness of facilities available to SSI sector,the charter available in banks should be displayed at prominent places. There is a need to publish the charter in English, Hindi as well as regional languages for greater dissemination of facilities available. The minister also said that the same principle of NPAs as applied to large industrial houses should not be applied to tiny units. Credit guarantee scheme should also be strengthened for improvement in SSI . Dr. C.P.Thakur said that banks have to play a very eminent role in the progress of the country. The employment scenario of the country will depend on how much the SSI sector is pushed towards growth in the next five years, he said.

pr_title: The Prime Minister Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee has said that an atmosphere has to be created for reservation in the private sector.
pr_content: The Prime Minister Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee has said that an atmosphere has to be created for reservation in the private sector. Addressing the Members of Parliament belonging to Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes who raised the issue at a meeting here today, Shri Vajpayee said that in democracy we can’t force issues. He at the same time he reminded the private sector that it cannot exist in isolation and has to be responsive to the needs of the society. The Prime Minister said that we have to make students belonging to Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes highly qualified so that they can come up the social ladder without reservation. He said reservation is only a first step in this direction. "It is a crutch and should not be misunderstood for foot," he added. Emphasizing on empowerment through education, Shri Vajpayee recalled that Baba Sahib Dr. B.R. Ambedkar had while urging people to strive for justice laid stress on education. He lamented that girls education among Scheduled Castes has been overlooked as their literacy percentage was less than 10% in one hundred districts. The Prime Minister said that India is surging ahead and "nobody can keep anybody behind". He said that millions of people are still victims of untouchability. Carrying of night soil on head is still in practice despite laws prohibiting it. The Prime Minister urged the SC/ST Members of Parliament to raise their issues jointly, He said "in democracy vote has a great power and only it needs to be speeded up". Shri Vajpayee said that he has been attending this meeting for the last two years to personally know the problems of Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes. The Prime Minister urged the people to visit 26, Alipur Road in the capital which has been dedicated to the nation as Baba Sahib Dr. B.R. Ambedkar’s "Parinirvan Sathal". He said it is a pious place ad Baba Sahib Ambedkar lived his last days here. Earlier welcoming the Prime Minister, the Social Justice and Empowerment minister Dr. Satyanarayan Jatiya said that his Ministry has accorded highest priority to educational empowerment of dalits. He said that Dr. Ambedkar National Merit Scholarship was launched last year to promote quality education among SC/ST students. He said that two new schemes have been cleared relating to admission of SC students in public schools and setting up of residential schools. The Minister of Tribal Affairs Shri Jual Oram, Minister of State Shri Sangh Priya Gautam, Shri Kailash Meghwal, Dr. Sanjay Paswan, Shri Ashok Pradhan, Shri Faggan Singh Kulesate and Ms. Jas Kaur Meena and SC/ST MPs belonging to various political parties attended the meeting.

pr_issued_by: Ministry of Health and Family Welfare
pr_title: Health Minister Smt. Sushma Swaraj calls for concerted action to arrest the declining female sex ratio
pr_content: The Minister for Health & Family Welfare and Parliamentary Affairs, Smt. Sushma Swaraj, has called for a change in the mindsets of people to arrest the alarmingly declining trend in female child sex ratio. Addressing the Consultative Committee attached to the Ministry of Health & Family Welfare here today, she said that child sex ratio in the 0-6 age group, which was 945 per 1000 in the 1991 census, has come down to 927 per 1000 in the 2001 census. This problem is particularly acute in Punjab and Haryana. There are 16 districts all over the country having less than 800 girls for 1000 boys as per 2001 census. Of these ten are in Punjab, five in Haryana and one in Gujarat. This means for every 1000 boys 200 girls are missing in these districts. The Minister said that there is a need for a concerted effort to change the prevalent social thinking and remove gender-based discrimination. She informed the Members that Government has launched "Save The Girl Child" campaign with a view to discourage son preference by highlighting the achievements of young girls. The Minister also said that the Tennis Champion, Ms. Sanya Mirza, has been appointed as the first ambassador for this campaign. In this context, she referred to the National Commitment Campaign launched on the 11th July of this year on the occasion of World Population Day. Smt. Sushma Swaraj also said that the Health Ministry is designing a tableau for the Republic Day around the concept of "Save The Girl Child" campaign. The tableau will depict the growing social concern about the gender imbalance and will send a subtle message to the people to discard the notion of son preference. The Minister also said that she intends to write to the Sarpanches of the Panchayats all over the country about the importance of the girl child campaign. The members have welcomed the steps announced by the Health Minister and called for stricter implementation of PNDT law to tackle the problem. They also called for sensitization of people through mass media campaigns on a greater scale. The Members who attended the meeting are Shri Datta Meghe, Shri Ravula Chandrasekhar Reddy. Shri Moti Lal Vora, Shri Abu Asim Azmi and Prof. M.M. Agarwal from Rajya Sabha and Shri Virender Kumar, Dr. R.C. Dome, Dr. M Jagannath, Dr Ram Lakhan Singh from Lok Sabha.

pr_title: DVC targets capacity addition of over 10000 Mega Watts PARLIAMENTARY CONSULTATIVE COMMITTEE ON POWER MEETS
pr_content: Shri Anant G. Geete, Minister of Power, informed the Parliamentary Consultative Committee attached to his Ministry that Damodar Valley Corporation (DVC) has set capacity addition target of 2210 MW thermal power generation in the Tenth Plan and 8000 MW during Eleventh Plan. Speaking at the meeting held here late yesterday evening, Shri Geete said that the work on the Mejia project is set to commence soon on receipt of environmental clearance. Other projects of the Corporation are in the tendering stage. In respect of the Maithon Right Bank Project which suffered a set back due to the exit of BSES, DVC has now taken over the project as its subsidiary. Shri Geete emphasised these capacity addition projects are primarily oriented towards export of power to the deficit region in the country. Presently, DVC has reached a generation capacity of 2761.5 MW starting with a small capacity in 1953. DVC is the first Multi-Purpose River of its kind which was set up as a Joint Venture of State of Bihar, West Bengal and the Union Government on the pattern of Tennessee Valley Authority (TVA) of USA. The Corporation was expected to help tame the turbulent Damodar River and contribute to the growth of the valley. Starting with construction of dams in the early 50s, the Corporation entered the areas of irrigation, hydro electricity generation, etc. Over the years, the Corporation has shifted its activities to thermal power generation in Eastern India. It currently has, in addition to power generation capacities, its own 56 substations and transmission lines with a total of 5121 circuit kms. of 33 KV, 132 KV and 220 KV. The Corporation has made profit on sustained basis besides carrying out several social development programmes. The net profit of the Corporation was Rs. 196 crore in 2002-03 against Rs. 192 crore in 2001-02 which is anticipated go upto Rs. 260 crore during 2003-04. Lauding the performance of the Corporation, the Members made suggestions for further improvement. They pointed out that the losses in the transmission could be brought down and the delay in project implementation should also be cut down. Smt. Jayawanti Mehta, Minister of State for Power was also present along with Shri R.V. Shahi, Secretary (Power) and other Senior Officers of the Ministry. The following Members attended the meeting:- S/Shri Suresh Chandel, Dr. Raghvansh Prasad Singh, Subodh Ray, Jai Bhadra Singh, Prof. (Smt) Rita Verma, Maheshwar Singh (All from Lok Sabha), Smt. Jamana Devi Barupal, Bashishtha Narain Singh, Harish Rawat (All from Rajya Sabha) and Prof. Ram Deo Bhandary (RS), a permanent Special Invitee.

pr_title: Rs.8 crore plant to convert plastic waste into hydrocarbon proposed at Nagpur INITIATIVES UNDER WAY TO HARNESS ALTERNATIVE SOURCES FOR AUTO FUELS: RAM NAIK
pr_content: Shri Ram Naik, Minister of Petroleum & Natural Gas, informed the Parliamentary Consultative Committee last evening that a proposal has been drawn up for setting up of 5 tonne plant at Nagpur at a cost of about Rs. 8 crore to convert plastic waste into value-added hydrocarbon products. In a statement circulated at the meeting Shri Naik said that the Plant will come up with technical assistance for the process being provided by IOC (R & D). The proposal envisages that the funding of the project would be done by the Oil Industry Development Board (OIDB). The Ministry has referred the project proposal to Scientific Advisory Committee on Hydrocarbon of the Ministry of Petroleum & Natural Gas for their consideration and recommendation. The proposal comes in the wake of a break-through claimed by Professor Alka Zadgaonkar, Head of the Department of Applied Chemistry of an Engineering College at Nagpur regarding recovery of oil from plastic waste. Several experiments were conducted by a joint team of IOC (R&D) and Prof. Zadgaonkar between 1st July and 10th July 2003 at the R&D Centre of IOC, Faridabad. The findings of the report prepared by IOC (R&D) on the process indicate that before the fuel obtained is used for auto and other purposes, its chlorine content, diene level etc., are required to be controlled. On the bio-diesel front, Shri Naik informed that a 3 pronged strategy is being followed by the Ministry of Petroleum & Natural Gas which involve commencing a pilot project at Rewari, Haryana to see the impact of 5% bio-diesel blended diesel on vehicles in Indian conditions and monitoring the Memorandum of Understanding signed by IOC with the Indian Railways for production of bio-diesel. Thirdly, the Ministry is cooperating with the Ministry of Rural Development in implementation of the Report prepared by the Planning Commission on "Development of Bio-Fuels". Keeping in view, the high cost of implementation of the project due to high price and lower availability of bio-diesel, Shri Naik said the Ministry is seeking exemption on import of bio-diesel for pilot project purpose from customs duty. He further informed that a limited tender for procurement of bio-diesel for the purpose of pilot project at Rewari has obtained response from two parties only at a price of about Rs. 70 per litre at Faridabad. Bio diesel from non-edible oils seeds is not available within the country. Project funding is proposed from the OIDB’s budget. To stop poor quality of oils from being passed off as bio-diesel, Shri Naik emphasised that standard specifications for the product are required to be formulated before a large scale bio-diesel programme takes off in the country. Shri Ram Naik also informed that the Government has directed Oil Companies to sell only Ethanol-Blended Petrol (EBP) in the State of Tamil Nadu and Union Territory (UT) of Pondicherry w.e.f. 1.1.2004 as the State Government of Tamil Nadu has now reduced the sales tax from 12% to 8% and scrapped purchase tax on inter-oil company transactions in petrol. The programme was kept in abeyance in these areas vide notification dated 29.9.2003 due to complex and high tax structure which made the sale of EBP unviable in Tamil Nadu and Pondicherry. So far 7 states namely, Goa, Gujarat, Haryana, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Punjab & Uttar Pradesh and 3 UTs of Chandigarh, Dadra & Nagar Haveli and Daman & Diu have been fully covered and Andhra Pradesh which is now partially covered would have the supply of only EBP by 31.12.2003. The States of Uttaranchal from 1.1.2004 and Madhya Pradesh from 1.3.2004 would also be covered with the sale of ethanol blended petrol. Replying to queries of the Members, Smt. Sumitra Mahajan, Minister of State for Petroleum & Natural Gas, emphasised that the programme to produce bio-diesel has larger interest of the nation in mind as they offer avenues for reducing India’s import dependence for oil together with efforts to produce more oil and gas in the country and to acquire equity oil abroad. She reiterated that the ethanol blending with petrol would be expanded to other States in phases. Besides reducing import dependence it would help farmers with better returns and reduce emission of vehicular pollutants to bring environmental benefits. Regarding high procurement cost of bio-diesel, Smt. Mahajan pointed out that the programme is at very initial and experimental stage, therefore the cost of procurement as of now should not be the judging factor for viability of the programme. In the ultimate analysis, it is very important to take up such a project from the standpoint of immense potential for benefitting the country. Regarding loss of gas through flaring Smt. Mahajan informed that under a programme to reduce gas flaring it has come down from about 8 per cent to 4 per cent or less which is a significant achievement. Government is also examining if the flaring can be reduced further in oil gas producing areas including North-Eastern States. The Members lauded the efforts of the Government for launching ethanol-petrol blending programme initiative , efforts to harness bio-diesel and the initiative to convert plastic waste into petrol. They have, however, suggested that the Government should see that the benefit of the programme reach the farmers, and result in price reduction whenever possible. The Members felt that these initiatives have great potential for enhancing self sufficiency in oil sector. Additional Secretary .(MOP&NG), Shri M.S. Srinivasan, CMDs of Oil PSUs and other senior officers of the Ministry and oil PSUs also attended the meeting. Following are the Members who attended the Consultative Committee meeting: S/Shri Lal Bihari Tiwari, Jaswant Singh Bishnoi, Dr. Laxminarayan Pandey Manibhai, Prof. Rasa Singh Rawat, Ram Shakal, Ram Singh Kaswan, N.H. Diwathe, Kishan Singh Sangwan, M.H. Gavit, Jai Prakash, Zora Singh Mann, Ram Sajiwan, Ram Jeevan Singh, Prasanna Acharya, Shyam Bihari Mishra and Harpal Singh Sathi (All from Lok Sabha) and Prof. Ram Bakhsh Singh Verma, Prof. Ram Deo Bhandari, A. Vijaya Raghavan, Satish Pradhan, Rajubhai A. Parmar, Prof. M.M. Agarwal, and Lajpat Rai (All from Rajya Sabha).

pr_title: India has fastest growth in mobile telephony : Shourie CONSULTATIVE COMMITTEE OF THE MINISTRY OF COMMUNICATIONS AND INFORMATION TECHNOLOGY MEETS
pr_content: The Minister of Communications, Information Technology and Disinvestment, Shri Arun Shourie has said that the country has the fastest growth in mobile telephony in the world with as many as 13 lakh cellular connections are being added every month. Addressing the Members of the Consultative Committee of the Ministry of Communications and Information Technology here today, the Minister said that the Bharat Sanchar Nigam Limited (BSNL) has not lagged behind in the competition with private cellular operators. Shri Shourie stated that in a year and two months time, the BSNL has acquired 43 lakh customers of ‘CellOne’ that has set the pace for tariff reduction and has unnerved private operators. Informing the Members about the several initiatives taken in the telecom sector the Minister said that these steps would completely re-orient the entire sector. He further stated that anomalies in the existing licensing system which were restricting the fair competition in cellular field had been removed with the introduction of Unified Licensing Regime. He said technology available in the market allows the operators to provide multiple facilities to the cellular users. Concerning the limited availability of spectrum, the Minister informed that talks are being held with the Defence Ministry for widening the bandwidth for smooth and easier accessibility. Once the Defence Ministry releases spectrum, the Telecom Ministry would have adequate bandwidth to release it to the telecom operators. Highlighting the initiatives taken in the field of Information Technology, the Minister said that several innovative ‘citizen-centric’ softwares are being developed in the country. He particularly mentioned the software developed by the Centre for Development of Advanced Computing (C-DAC) for the visually impaired, which transform text into speech. To enable the people to access these new technologies, Shri Shourie stated that a software had also been developed that transforms the text and converts speech automatically from one language to another. He further informed the Members that through software exports, India has earned $13 billion this year. During the meeting, a presentation was made on ‘Rural Telephony Scheme’ by the Gramin Sanchar Society, Kolkata, highlighting the various steps taken for increasing the accessibility through telephones in the rural areas in West Bengal. Participating in the discussion, Shri Nilotpal Basu said that the Scheme has led to the growth of new business opportunities for self-employment. He further said that paradigm shift is required in the rural telephony by shifting from individual telephones to the community based telephone system to serve the social justice. Shri Shourie also felt the need for replicating such community based system in rural areas of the country. The Minister of State for Communications and Information Technology, Shri Ashok Pradhan, while participating in the discussion informed the Members that directions had been given for regular holding of Telephone Adalats in all Circles for redressal of public grievances. The Minister of State for Communications and Information Technology, Shri Su. Thirunavukkarasar also attended the meeting. The Members who participated in the meeting include: S/Shri Ramanand Singh, Padamsen Chaudhary, Radha Mohan Singh, Gordhanbhai Javiya, Laxmanrao Patil, Bhan Singh Bhaura, Sanat Kumar Mandal, D.B. Atkinson, Col. Sona Ram Choudhary, Shriniwas Patil, Pradeep Rawat, Chandrakant Khaire, Hassan Khan, K.P. Singh Deo and Smt. Ratna Singh – Lok Sabha members. Rajya Sabha Members who attended the meeting include: Shri Nilotpal Basu, Shri P.G. Narayanan and Shri Suresh Bhardwaj.

pr_issued_by: Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food & Public Distribution
pr_title: Statement by Shri Sharad Yadav in Lok Sabha on buffer stock of sugar
pr_content: Shri Sharad Yadav, Minister of Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution has made a statement in Lok Sabha in a reply to starred question. His complete statement is as follows:- " A buffer stock of 20 lakh tonnes was created for sugar for a period of one year from 18th December, 2002 to 17th December 2003, so that Rs. 786 crore can be arranged and the cane arrears can be paid to the farmers directly by the sugar mills. Out of this amount, Rs. 412 crore were to be received from the Sugar Development Fund (SDF) and Rs. 374 crore from various banks. During the current year till September, 2003 the sugar mills had stocks of about 103 lakh tonnes and since the prices are going down again the period for buffer stock has been extended for one more year till 17 December, 2004. So that, the farmer may get the same amount as arrears from sugar mills as in previous year. There is a Monitoring Committee in the Ministry, which looks after the interest of the farmers. The Committee has taken precautions so that sugar mills can open separate accounts in the banks to get this money or Cane Commissioner has to certify that the mill owner has given the money directly to the farmers."

pr_title: There can be no greater tribute to our freedom fighters than to fulfil their dream through speeding up growth and development: Shekhawat
pr_content: Vice President Shri Bhairon Singh Shekhwat has said our freedom fighters had the dream of making India a developed Nation, free from hunger and disease. There can be no greater tribute to our freedom fighters than to fulfil their dream through speeding up growth and development. Vice President was addressing today the vast gathering at historic liberation ground at Goa on the occasion of 42nd Anniversary of liberation of Goa, Daman and Diu at Goa. He said that we have the vision of being the developed Nation by the year 2020. This task of building a developed Nation is going to be full of challenges. We have to address the problems of improving public governance and providing healthy environment conducive to development and growth. We need hassle-free and corruption-free governance for the common man. The key issues and challenges coming in the way of development such as population stabilization, reforms in administration, judiciary and electoral system have got to be addressed with a sense of urgency. Vice President has further said that the progress of India since independence is a success story of what can be achieved in a populated country within a democratic and constitutional framework. Thanks to our agricultural scientists, technologists and our farmers, we have achieved self-sufficiency in food; our granaries are full with stocks of more than 22 million tonnes of food grains. Our achievements in industry, defence, space and atomic energy have been spectacular. Our economy is stable and resilient; we are approaching the target of 8% growth of GDP in the Tenth Plan. Our Foreign Exchange Reserves are more than 96 Billion US Dollars. On this strength, India is now at the take-off juncture and ready to be on high growth trajectory. Shri Shekhawat also said that in the task of national development, all parts of the country have to be working together in partnership. It is heartening to find Government of Goa fully committed to accelerate its development. Goa is beautiful land with glorious heritage. Goa has been endowed by nature with bounties rather liberally. Its long beaches, beautiful hills, rolling plains, perennial rivers and a great variety of flora and fauna could be envy of any region. Every inch of this enchanting land bears testimony to its natural and cultural tapestry. On the occasion Shri Shekhawat also honoured 155 Freedom Fighters from all parts of the country who contributed to the Goa Liberation Movement.

pr_title: Prime Minister launches Artisan Credit Card Scheme WOMEN BENEFICIARIES TO GET 0.5 PERCENT REBATE IN INTEREST
pr_content: The Prime Minister Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee has said that the Artisan Credit Card Scheme will prove to be an important step in meeting the credit needs of the weavers and artisans at an affordable rate. He was speaking after launching the scheme here today. The Prime Minister said that there are about one crore twenty five lakh weavers and artisans in the country, most whom are landless. They need credit at reasonable rates to compete effectively both at home and abroad . He said, being landless, they are forced to borrow at higher interest. The Prime Minister said, the scheme has been prepared keeping this in view. The Prime Minister distributed cards to eight beneficiaries to mark the launching of the scheme. The scheme was simultaneously launched in Etawah by Uttar Pradesh Chief Minsiter Shri Mulayam Singh Yadav, in Bhubaneswar by Orissa Chief Minster Shri Naveen Patnaik and in Hyderabad by Andhra Pradesh Ckhief Minister Shri Chandrababu Naidu with the three centres connected to Delhi through videoconference. Speaking on the occasion the Minister for Textiles Shri Syed Shahnawaz Hussain said that the Prime Minster had announced the scheme in his address to the nation on the Independence Day. He said, we have now fulfilled the promise. The country earns foreign exchange worth 12 billion Dollars by exporting handicrafts, handlooms, garments and textiles. He said, the scheme has been prepared in association with the Indian Bank Association. Shri Hussain said, we need to create conditions to make our weavers and artisans competitive as the quota system ends in 2004. He hoped that the credit card will be an important step in that direction. Under the scheme the maximum credit limit is Rs. 2 lakh and it carries an interest of nine percent. However, women borrowers will get half a percent rebate in interest.

pr_title: India reiterates support for multilateral process TEXT OF STATEMENT BY ARUN JAITLEY REGARDING CANCUN MINISTERIAL CONFERENCE
pr_content: India has been engaging constructively in the multilateral trade negotiations and is optimistic that despite the lack of progress at the Cancun Ministerial Conference, it would be possible to move forward in the weeks to come. India is also committed to ensuring that "development" lies at the core of the Doha agenda. In a statement regarding the Fifth Ministerial Conference of the World Trade Organisation (WTO) held at Cancun, Mexico during 10-14 September, 2003, in the Lok Sabha today, Shri Arun Jaitley, Union Minister of Commerce & Industry, emphasised that for India, the multilateral process is extremely important and said: "we are willing to work together and engaged in a process of give and take so that mutually acceptable outcomes may be reached. Movement forward demands understanding and accommodation". The following is the full text of Shri Jaitley’s statement: "1. I rise to make a statement on the proceedings of the Fifth Ministerial Conference of the WTO held at Cancún, Mexico during 10-14 September 2003. A copy of the Ministerial Statement is being placed on the Table of the House. 2. The Cancún Ministerial Conference was due to take stock of the progress in negotiations under the Work Programme launched by the Doha Declaration and to provide guidance to negotiators on key areas such as agriculture, tariff negotiations for non-agricultural products, special and differential treatment and implementation issues. The Conference also had to decide on whether or not to launch negotiations on Singapore Issues based on modalities agreed to by ‘explicit consensus’. 3. In preparation for the Conference, the Government held wide-ranging consultations with all major stakeholders and had accordingly formulated its negotiating strategy. This strategy was based on an appreciation of our trade interests, development concerns and gains to be made by improving the multilateral trading system. We went to Cancún in a positive frame of mind with a desire to engage proactively in the negotiations for a fruitful outcome. 4. The Conference which concluded in Cancún on 14 September 2003 could not reach a decision covering all areas. An important reason for the lack of a decision at Cancún was the inability of the proposals on the table to forge a consensus by taking into account the concerns of all Members on many contentious issues. The conference ended with a Ministerial Statement which recognised that more work needed to be done in key areas to enable WTO Member countries to proceed towards the conclusion of negotiations under the Doha mandate. 5. The developments at Cancun have been a disappointment for us. We are interested in having a healthy, effective multilateral trading system, which would provide the institutional backdrop for a process of economic development that would benefit all countries. The overriding priority and consideration for a developing country like India in any trading arrangement is the implication of such an arrangement for its economic development. This focus on development determines our position on any trade rules and proposals at the WTO. Our goal at Cancun on major issues was guided by national interest. 6. In agriculture, our desire was to ensure that agriculture markets across the world are freed from the substantial distortions that are caused by large scale subsidisation. These distortions prevent agriculture from fulfilling its potential of being an engine of growth. Income inequalities caused so far by such distortions continue. It is essential in the interests of equity, justice and fair play that the distortions in agriculture are gradually eliminated. Therefore, agricultural market access in developing countries has to be sequenced appropriately with reductions in market distortions elsewhere. At the same time, we wish to protect the interests of the millions of subsistence level framers who depend on agriculture as their sole means of sustenance. Therefore, there has to be a calibrated approach to market access vis-à-vis reduction in distortions in agriculture with a transition period in which affected farmers are shielded through the use of special safeguard mechanisms and protection for special products. In view of all this, expecting us to make onerous market access commitments inconsistent with the reality in agriculture was unreasonable. The draft modalities on agriculture proposed at Cancun, on the other hand, did not take into account these concerns fully and would in all probability, have perpetuated distortions. We had no choice but to oppose these modalities. 7. On tariff negotiations in non-agricultural products, significant convergence in negotiating positions could be realised by taking on board the concerns of all Members. 8. On Singapore Issues, one has to address the question of multilateral rule making taking primacy over economic development goals, particularly in areas where the interplay between these new issues and development is unknown. The Ministerial Conference had to take a decision on modalities for all the Singapore Issues. However, this was to be by explicit consensus. Discussions clearly revealed that not only was this consensus absent but that most developing countries felt that the clarification process on these issues had not run its full course. In the absence of clarity on many elements, a majority of the membership of the WTO had rejected launch of negotiations on these issues and sought a continuation of the clarification process. There were concerns that a framework on Investment would constrain the policy space for developing countries in utilising FDI for their development goals. There was no certainty that such a framework would lead to larger FDI flows nor was any need for a framework demonstrated. On Competition Policy, the issue of encroaching upon the freedom of competition authorities was disquieting. The benefits of a framework on Transparency in Government Procurement was also not clear. In spite of this, proposals tabled suggested launch of negotiations in some areas. In the absence of explicit consensus, launching negotiations was, however, an impossibility. 9. India was also disappointed that no time frame was prescribed for resolving outstanding implementation issues. These issues highlight the imbalances arising out of the Uruguay Round agreement and need to be addressed on a priority basis so that imbalances brought in by the Uruguay round are redressed. On Special & Differential Treatment Issues, India felt that adequate urgency was not being shown in addressing these issues. 10. An important outcome from our viewpoint is the engagement of developing countries in the negotiating process. Unlike in the past, when they were blamed for non-participation, the degree of participation of the large group of developing countries is a welcome development. Not only have developing countries become participants in the process but have also shown adequate flexibility to reach out to other fellow countries to form alliances which have been formed during and after the conference. The G-20 on Agriculture and the G-16 on Singapore Issues embody the desire of developing countries to generate common positions on issues. 11. The Ministerial Conference concluded with a Ministerial Statement which recognised that more work needed to be done in some key areas to enable WTO Member countries to proceed towards the conclusion of negotiations under the Doha mandate. The Ministerial Statement has instructed officials to continue working on outstanding issues with a renewed sense of urgency and purpose and taking fully into account all the views expressed in the Ministerial Conference. The Chairman of the General Council of the WTO, working in close coordination with the Director General, were also asked to coordinate this work and to convene a meeting of the General Council at senior officials level no later than 15th December 2003 to enable successful and timely conclusion of the negotiations. 12. As Hon’ble Members would appreciate, trade negotiations are a protracted process. We have been engaging constructively in the negotiations and are optimistic that despite the lack of progress at the Cancun Ministerial Conference, it would be possible to move forward in the weeks to come. Agriculture has been at the core of the negotiations. Our sensitivities on Singapore Issues also need to be understood. We are also committed to ensuring that ‘development’ lies at the core of the Doha agenda, as mandated at the Doha Ministerial Conference of WTO. 13. For India, the multilateral process is an extremely important one. We believe that a rule based trading system provides a fair, transparent, predictable, secure and durable environment for trade relations between nations. We have been demanding that the system be fair – fair to our development goals, to our economic needs, to our economic and social reality and to our aspirations. The multilateral system continues to enjoy our support and we are participating in the process of further negotiations in Geneva. We are willing to work together and engage in a process of give and take so that mutually acceptable outcomes may be reached. Movement forward demands understanding and accommodation. Our only desire is that the discussions be carried out in a more understanding and sensitive manner so that trade liberalization does actually deliver the fruit of development".

pr_title: Ministry denies news item on Personal Income Tax
pr_content: The Ministry of Commerce & Industry has described as incorrect a news item published in an economic daily today which states that the Commerce Ministry has proposed changes in the personal income tax in its pre-Budget proposals to the Finance Ministry. The news item is totally incorrect. Denying the report, Commerce Ministry has said that although it has forwarded several proposals to the Ministry of Finance as a pre-Budget exercise, it has not sent any proposal regarding personal income tax.

pr_title: Legal Aid Centre inaugurated at Jamia Nagar TWENTY MORE CENTRES TO BE OPENED IN DELHI
pr_content: A Family Counselling and Legal Aid Centre was inaugurated today at Jamia Nagar, Okhla today by Mr. Justice B.A. Khan, Judge, Delhi High Court and the Executive Chairman, Delhi Legal Service Authority. In addition to family counselling, the Centre will provide free legal aid to the people below poverty line, women, the Scheduled Castes and Scheduled Tribes, the handicapped whose income falls below Rs.50, 000. Already 16 such Centres are functioning in Delhi. Speaking on the occasion, Mr. Justice Khan said that 20 more Legal Aid Centres would be opened in Delhi during the next year. He said that the poorer sections of the society were not aware of the many laws enacted for their welfare. He called upon the people to make use of the services at the Centre, which would enable them to get legal remedies for their problems. Mr. Justice Dalveer Bhandari, Judge, Delhi High Court and Chairman, High Court Legal Services Committee was also present on the occasion.

pr_title: CAG is reappointed as the external auditor of IMO
pr_content: Shri Vijayendra N. Kaul, Comptroller and Auditor General of India has been reappointed as the external auditor of the International Maritime organisation (IMO). The CAG was appointed unopposed by the Assembly of IMO for the four year period 2004-07. CAG is the current external auditor of IMO for the period 2000-03. CAG is also the external auditor for other important international organizations like the WHO, the FAO etc.

pr_title: India successfully conducts solar eclipse observations in Antarctica
pr_content: The Indian scientific team has successfully conducted for the first time the solar eclipse observations from the icy Continent of Antarctica. The solar eclipse of November 23-24, 2003, was a rare event occurring once in 400 years and hence assumed great scientific importance. The short duration eclipse was observed over India’s permanent station at Antarctica "Maitri". The important experiments conducted by the Indian team included Multi Wavelength coronal imaging, shadow bands observations and Thermal response of the terrestrial atmosphere. The eclipse produced a splendid and spectacular display of some Bailey’s beads, crimson and beautiful diamond rings and a corona in its full golden glory with extended streamers. In addition it resulted in the generation of extensive shadow-bands which are the rarest and of longest duration running into minutes. The experiments done by Indian team were highly successful in recording valuable digital data on various aspects of the spectacle. The most significant was the long duration shadow bands. The data collected are being analysed and the findings would be highly interesting and valuable, as Antarctica plays a vital role in the determination of global climatic and atmospheric conditions. The team was fully supported by our 22nd Wintering Antarctic expedition group. The success of the national mission has brought more glory to the Indian Antarctic programme.

pr_title: President presents National Awards for Welfare of Persons with Disabilties DR. KALAM CALLS UPON INDUSTRIAL AND SECTORS TO VOLUNTARILY PROVIDE JOBS TO PERSONS WITH DISABILITIES
pr_content: The President Dr. A P J Abdul Kalam has called upon the Industrial and Service sectors to voluntarily provide jobs to the persons with disabilities. Speaking at a function after presenting National Awards for the Welfare of Persons with Disabilities here today, Dr. Kalam urged the I T Sector particularly the Call Centres to take up training programmes for the people with disability in a mission mode in order to facilitate their employment. He urged the government sector to respect the 3% job reservation quota for the disabled persons. He also urged the Social Justice and Empowerment Ministry to launch support programmes for the disabled so that they feel secure and independent. The President said that the rehabilitation programme cover only 25 percent of the people suffering from various disabilities and those left out are mainly in rural areas. He asked the SJ&E Ministry to conduct a survey by next year to know the exact umber of disabled persons in the country. Referring to the technological advances in developed countries for helping the disabled, the President said that India should also evolve and adopt such technologies on a mass scale. He urged for undertaking research in disability sector so that the aids and appliances are cost effective and affordable. He said that I T Technology should be harnessed for educating the visually impaired persons. He suggested to the IT Community to produce the Braille key board and connected software so that reading material is available to the visually impaired in Indian languages. Making an impassioned plea for recognizing the abilities of the disabled, the President said that he saw an indomitable spirit among the awardees. He said that it is the winning spirit that has helped them in securing excellence in their respective fields. Striking a chord with the audience on the issue Dr. Kalam rendered the following poem on wining spirit, which was recited with him by the audience as well. "We are all God’s Children, Our Minds are stronger than diamond We will win, we will win, we will win with mighty will" The President made inquires from various awardees. He even came down from the dais to honour some of the awardees. The Social Justice and Empowerment Minister Dr. Satyanarayan Jatiya in his welcome address said that the government has decided to set up a National Commission for the Persons with disabilities. He describe it as a major step in empowerment of the disabled persons. He said that out of 130 Rehabilitation Centres for persons with disabilities being set up across the country 92 have become functional. Dr. Jatiya said that an awareness campaign about various programmes and schemes being run by his Ministry for persons with disabilities would be launched in 399 districts during the 10th Plan. A message of the UN Secretary General Shri Kofiannan was read on the occasion. The function was attended by the Minister of State for Social Justice and Empowerment Shri Nagmani, the Secretary Shri B S Baswan and senior officials of the Ministry. The National Awards or the Welfare of Persons with Disabilities is being given every year since 1969. These include awards in best employer, best employee and best placement agency or officer categories. The recognition of voluntary effort occupies a special place as the awards in this category carries a highest cash prize of Rupees One Lakh, a citation and a certificate. Role Model and National Technology Awards are also given. From this year, the Best Local Level Committee Award has been introduced for the services for implementing programmes of the National Trust. The first award has been shared by the Local Level Committees of Niligiris District in Tamil Nadu and Union Territory of Chandigarh. MLD/PK/SJ&E/144-03 (President-Disability Awards) December 3, 2003

They have to fill up detailed application form which will be supplied to them by the UPSC before being called for interview for Personality Test. In case any of these candidates who have qualified in the written test do not receive a communcation in this regard from the Commission uptill 10th December, 2003, he/she should immediately contact the UPSC in this matter giving particulars (i.e. full name, Roll Number and date of birth, address etc). Union Public Service Commission have a Facilitation Centre near Examination Hall Building of its campus. Candidates may obtain any information/clarification regarding their Examination/Recruitments on working days between 10.00 a.m. to 5.00 p.m. in person or over telephone no.011-23385271/011-23381125 and 011-23098543 from this Centre. Candidates can also obtain information regarding results etc. on Commission’s website at the address: www.upsc.gov.in.

pr_title: EPFO has taken a proactive approach with the result that there is better all round functioning of the organisation - Dr. Sahib singh CBT DISCUSSES THE 50TH ANNUAL REPORT (2202-03), AND RE 2003-04 & BE 2004-05 OF EPFO
pr_content: Dr. Sahib Singh, Union Labour Minister has said that Employees Provident Fund Organisation (EPFO) has taken a proactive approach with the result that there is better all-round functioning of the organization. He further said that 92734 establishments with 91.55 lakh members which were categorized as inoperative even though they are covered under the Act has been brought back into the compliance fold as on 31.03.2003. Dr. Sahib Singh was addressing the 165th Meeting of the Central Board of Trustees (EPF) today. He informed a sum of Rs. 16334.60 crores have been collected as contribution for all the three schemes and a total of 50.05 lakhs number of claims have been settled. He underlined the point that a sum of Rs. 885.99 crores have been recovered as arrear dues. But he expressed concern on the persistent complaints regarding difficulties faced in withdrawing one’s own money from the fund and the general public perception about the rampant corruption. As regards the performance gap in book keeping, the Board decided to entrust the matter to a “fact finding Committee” to plug the loop holes and strengthening the Internal Audit System. This will deter the frauds and cut short the procedural delays. The CBT also approved the Revised Budget Estimates (RE) for the year 2003-2004 and Budget Estimates (BE) for the year 2004-05 for the Employees’ Provident Fund Scheme, 1952, Employees’ Pension Scheme 1995 and Employees’ Deposit Linked Insurance Scheme 1976. Regarding proposal of IFCI for roll over of dues payable to CBT, CBT authorized Chairman CBT to negotiate with IFCI. It may be stated that CBT, made investments in various Bonds/Debentures of IFCI aggregating Rs. 1048.80 crores in respect of principal alone as on 31.03.2003. From November 2001 onwards IFCI committed default in the payment of maturity proceeds as well as interest.
