pr_title: Government takes initiatives in entertainment sector
pr_content: RAJYA SABHAThe Government has taken several initiatives to bring about changes in the entertainment sector in the interest of the overall development of this sector. Access to institutional and bank financing has been facilitated for the entertainment industry, including films. Foreign direct investment policy for the film sector has been liberalized and international visibility has been afforded to Indian films by participation in global markets. Apart from these, in order to suggest a policy framework for the entertainment industry, both at the Centre and the States, a committee for development of the entertainment sector has been set up. The committee had given its first set of recommendations which, including a recommendation to fix a ceiling of 60 per cent on entertainment tax, were circulated among the States and many State Governments have lowered their entertainment tax rates. An anti piracy training programme was also organized for police officers based on the recommendations of the committee, which is expected to be the precursor of many such training programmes. In its recent meeting the committee has made recommendations, mainly relating to a further reduction in entertainment tax rates to 45 per cent, appointment of a nodal officer in each State for assisting in anti piracy matters and facilitating a single point clearance by State Governments for foreign film crews shooting in India. The second set of recommendations of the committee have also been persuasively circulated to State Governments. In order to bring about a receptive investment regime in the entertainment sector, within India, a committee has recently been set up to suggest a strategy to facilitate the flow of venture capital into the sector.

pr_title: Immigrants to developed countries
pr_content: LOK SABHA The number of persons granted emigration clearance for employment abroad during the last three years are as follows: 2002: 3.68 lakhs 2001: 2.79 lakhs 2002: 2.43 lakhs The Government had introduced the Emigration (Amendment) Bill, 2002 in the Lok Sabha on 21.11.2002 which has been referred to the Standing Committee on Labour and Welfare. It is proposed, through the Amendment Bill, to set-up a Central Manpower Export Promotion Council and establish an Indian Overseas Workers’ Welfare Fund. A compulsory Insurance Scheme has been notified on 13.11.2003 and emigration procedures simplified. The Government deals strictly with illegal immigration. All such cases are referred to the Police authorities for booking the unregistered recruiting agents. All State Governments and Union Territory Administrations have also been requested to instruct the Police Stations to keep a strict vigil on the activities of middlemen engaged in illegal emigration. This information was given by Dr. Sahib Singh, Union Labour Minister in reply to a question in Parliament today.

pr_title: Shri Lakshmi Chand takes over as Secretary (IPP)
pr_content: Shri Lakshmi Chand (IAS:1969) has taken over as Secretary, Department of Industrial Policy & Promotion (DIPP), Ministry of Commerce & Industry. He belongs to the UP cadre of the Indian Administrative Service. Prior to taking over as Secretary (IPP), Shri Lakshmi Chand was Secretary (Coal). He succeeds Shri Rajeev Ratna Shah, who has moved as Secretary (Planning Commission).

pr_title: National Steel Policy under preparation
pr_content: LOK SABHAA Committee has been set up under the chairmanship of the Development Commissioner for Iron and Steel to formulate National Policy on Steel. The draft National Steel Policy prepared by the Committee has been circulated amongst a duly constituted Core Task Group (CTG), comprising of professionals and economists who are connected with the steel sector. The comments of individual members of the CTG are being obtained. This information was given by the Minister of Steel, Shri Braja Kishore Tripathi in a written reply to the question of Shri K. Rama Mohana Rao in Rajya Sabha today. Replying to the question as to how the Government are going to ensure protection to domestic industry from unfair competition, Shri Tripathi stated that in a liberalized scenario the Government plays the role of a facilitator. Through policy initiatives the Government provides an enabling environment to foster the growth of steel industry. He added that in a deregulated and decontrolled era decisions regarding improvement in operational efficiency, aimed at reduction in costs of production, are taken by the individual companies in order to maintain their competitive edge in the market. The Government helps in removing the bottlenecks for the overall development of the steel industry.

pr_title: Inclusion of castes
pr_content: LOK SABHAUnion Minister for Tribal Affairs, Shri Jual Oram informed the Lok Sabha today in a written reply that the forty (40) Castes/groups are included in the list of Scheduled Tribes in West Bengal. The Ministry of Tribal Affairs has received several proposal for inclusion in the list of STs in West Bengal. These proposals have been processed as per the modalities approved by the Government of India.

pr_title: Tribal Cooperative Socities in different States
pr_content: LOK SABHAUnion Minister for Tribal Affairs, Shri Jual Oram informed the Lok Sabha today in a reply to a question from Shri K. P. Singh Deo that 12 States have established State Tribal Development Cooperative Corporations. These are the registered societies namely, Girijan Cooperative Corporation (GCC), Andhra Pradesh; Gujarat State Forest Development Corporation Ltd., Gujarat; Manipur Scheduled Caste and Scheduled Tribes Development Corporation Ltd., Manipur; Rajasthan Tribal Area Development Cooperative Federation Ltd., Rajasthan; Jharkhand State Tribal Cooperative Development Coorporation Ltd.; Madhya Pradesh Langhu Vanupaj, Vyapar Avem Vikas Sekhari Sangh, Madhya Pradesh; Maharashtra State Tribal Development Cooperative Corporation Ltd., Maharashtra; Tripura Apex Marketing Cooperative Society Ltd., Tripura; Kerala State Cooperative marketing Federation Ltd., Kerala; Tribal Development Cooperative Corporation of Orissa Ltd., Orissa; Meghalaya State Cooperative marketing and Consumer Federation Ltd. (MECOFED) and West Bengal Tribal Development Cooperative Corporation Ltd., West Bengal. The Minister further stated that these corporations are provided funds under the Central Sector Scheme of Grant in aid to State Tribal Development Cooperative Corporations – mainly for procurement of Minor Forest Produce (MFP). Central Government also provides grants for strengthening the share capital of these Corporations for MFP operations. State wise allocation is not done under the scheme, which is need based. The budgetary allocation under the scheme for the current financial year, i.e. 2003-04, is Rs. 18.00 crores.

pr_title: CARA to host International Meet on Adoption
pr_content: A three- day International Meet on Adoption is being organised by the Central Adoption Resource Agency, CARA, from 8th to 10th December 5, 2003 in New Delhi. Delegates from 15 countries representing the foreign governments and adoption agencies apart from representatives of the Government of India, State Governments, Union Territories and Indian NGOs will be participating in the Meet. The Minister of Social Justice and Empowerment Dr. Satyanarayan Jatiya will inaugurate the Meet. The meet assumes importance in the light of India’s ratification of the Hague Convention on Protection of Children and cooperation in respect of Inter-country Adoption earlier this year. This has been done with a view to strengthen international cooperation and protection of Indian children placed in Inter-country adoptions. The Meet will be the first ever programme to share experiences with different receiving countries and their Central Authorities who have either ratified or signed Hague Convention and have adoption programmes with India. The Meet aims to reflect diverse interests and views, discuss and streamline country practices & procedures of different Central Authorities and review the trends in adoption in both International & domestic sectors. It will also discuss legal and procedural safeguards, as well as transparency in adoption costs etc. as prescribed in Hague Convention on Inter-country Adoption. The delegates will have an opportunity to share their experiences in streamlining adoption procedures. CARA, an autonomous body under the Ministry of Social Justice and Empowerment has given recognition to 73 Indian Placement Agencies and 252 Enlisted Agencies including 131 government bodies in more than 25 countries, to carry out in-country and inter-country adoption of abandoned and orphaned children. More than 12,200 children have found homes through recognized placement homes. These include over 7,200 in-country adoptions and more than 5,000 inter-country adoptions. Andhra Pradesh, Delhi, Goa, Gujarat, Haryana, Karnataka, Kerala, Maharashtra, Orissa, Pondicherry, Tamil Nadu and Uttar Pradesh have active adoption programmes. The adoption activities in other states and union territories are picking up.

pr_title: Import of Chinese silk fabrics
pr_content: LOK SABHAImport of silk fabrics from China has increased from 766 MT in 2001-02 to 3290 MT in 2002-03 with corresponding value of Rs.84.29 crore and Rs.191.52 crore respectively. There has been an increase in import of Chinese silk fabrics after the removal of quantitative restrictions on 1.4.2001. It is too early to assess firm figures of imports since levy of final antidumping duty on raw silk imports in July, 2003, to be able to analyse them. A petition has since been filed by Karnataka Weavers Associations before the Directorate General of Anti-Dumping & Allied Duties, the designated authority, requesting for initiation of antidumping investigations on imports of silk fabrics from China. Through Research and Technological efforts of Central Silk Board breakthrough has been achieved for production of international standard silk to enhance the availability of superior quality silk indigenously. This information was given by the Minister of State for Textiles Shri G.N. Ramachandran in a written reply in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: DMS takes steps to increase sale of milk
pr_content: RAJYA SABHAThe sale of milk supplied by the Delhi Milk Scheme (DMS) has decreased as a result of increase in prices with effect from 1st March this year. However, steps have been taken to boost the sale including conversion of depots into all-day milk stalls, putting into operation abandoned milk booths and face-lifting of the existing milk stalls. The distribution losses suffered by the DMS during 2000-01, 2001-02 and 2002-03 amounted to Rs.84.91 lakh, Rs.95.57 lakh and Rs.43.34 lakh respectively. The percentage of milk in polypacks returned to DMS during these three years was 7.6 , 8.64 and 3.88 respectively. The expenditure incurred in reprocessing the returned polypacks was about Rs.4.2 crore. At present, 214 all-day milk stalls are running in Delhi. These stalls sell DMS milk and milk products. An amount of about Rs.58 lakh has been received as refundable security deposits from these outlets. This information was given by the Minister of State for Agriculture, Shri Hukumdeo Narayan Yaday in reply to two separate questions by S/shri Murli Deora and Santosh Bagrodia in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Phenomenal growth in Indian Handmade Paper Export
pr_content: There has been phenomenal growth in the export market for Indian Handmade Paper and its products, especially in the developed countries like the United States of America, European countries, Australia etc. This was stated by the Minister of State for Agro & Rural Industries, Shri Sangh Priya Gautam while addressing the Buyer-Seller Meet on Handmade Paper at the ‘Paperex-2003’, here today. The Minister said that the export of Handmade Paper and paper products is estimated around Rs. 50 crores and may increase in multiples in the coming years. The last decade witnessed rapid growth in export as a number of Handmade Paper and paper products manufacturing units have become hundred per cent export oriented units and helped in increasing the foreign exchange of the country, he said. Handmade Paper is one of the major rural village industries under the purview of KVIC. It is one of the most employment-generating programmes using cotton rags as raw material and paper waste, which is eco-friendly in nature. There are around 3800 handmade paper units which include conversion units, papier mache and manufacturing units having a production of Rs. 128 crores and providing employment of 28,000 rural artisans. In the era of globalisation, handmade paper is one of the prime sectors, which has a major say. An International Exhibition on Pulp and Paper and allied products, under the name of ‘Paperex’, is being held from 5th to 8th December 2003 at Pragati Maidan, New Delhi. This Buyer-Seller Meet on Handmade Paper as a part of the Paperex-2003, is conducted with a view to boost export and domestic market of Handmade paper and its products, which are being produced and marketed by village entrepreneurs/artisans/institutions. The Minister appreciated KVIC and UNDP for organising these kinds of domestic fairs on Handmade Paper which help in generating significant trade enquiries and helped to spread the awareness about the green and clean environment. Present on the occasion among others were Dr. Maxine Olson, Resident Representative, UNDP and Dr. Mahesh Sharma, Chairman, KVIC.

pr_title: Integrated Rail-cum-Bus Transit System in Delhi
pr_content: RAJYA SABHAThere is a proposal for an Integrated Rail-cum-Bus Transit (IRBT) System connecting Delhi with the towns of Gurgaon, Ghaziabad and Sahibabad and with interface with the Delhi mass rapid transit system (metro rail). The IRBT System includes (i) two dedicated tracks for commuter traffic on the following alignments : Shahdara – Sahibabad – Ghaziabad Sahibabad – Tilak Bridge – Minto Bridge Dayabasti – Bijwasan – Gurgaon and (ii) interface with Delhi Metro Rail at four locations, namely, Shahdara, Trinagar/Dayabasti, Barakhamba Road/Shivaji Bridge and Kirti Nagar/New Patel Nagar. The estimated cost of the three corridors is as under: Corridor Cost (Rs. in crore) a) Shahdara – Sahibabad – Ghaziabad 665 b) Sahibabad – Tilak Bridge – Minto Bridge 621 c) Dayabasti – Bijwasan – Gurgaon 953 T O T A L 2239 The feasibility study of the project has been conducted. The draft Memorandum of Understanding has been circulated to and approved by all stakeholders, except the Government of Uttar Pradesh. A steering Committee has also been constituted to monitor the project This information was given by Shri Bandaru Dattatraya, Minister of State (Independent Charge) in the Ministry of Urban Development and Poverty Alleviation in a written reply to the question of Dr. Akhilesh Das in Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: European Union funding for Tribal Development Projects
pr_content: The Ministry of Tribal Affairs implements Tribal Development Projects/Schemes funded by European Union through the mechanism of "Bilateral Development Cooperation Programme (BDCP)", for which Ministry of Finance (Department of Economic Affairs) is the nodal Ministry. No Tribal Development Projects/Schemes under the said programme has been started in any State including Jharkhand by the Ministry of Tribal Affairs in collaboration with the European Union (EU). However, EU may be providing funds for some tribal welfare programmes through NGOs, of which Ministry of Tribal Affairs is not aware of. This information was given by the Union Minister for Tribal Affairs, Shri Jual Oram in written reply to a question from Shri Abhay Kant Prasad in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Flood Management Programme of Inter-State Rivers
pr_content: LOK SABHACentral Water Commission under the Ministry of Water Resources has established a network of 166 flood forecasting stations on major rivers in the country out of which 31stations are located in Chattisgarh, Jharkhand, Andhra Pradesh and Orissa which are providing timely flood forecasting and warning to the State Governments for flood mitigation. The Central Government is also rendering financial assistance to various State Governments for carrying out critical flood management works. In this connection, a Centrally Sponsored Scheme to take up critical anti-erosion works in Ganga Basin States have been approved for implementation during the X Plan which, interalia, includes a scheme for Jharkhand. Centrally Sponsored Schemes have also been formulated to take up critical anti-river erosion works/raising and strengthening of embankments; and also for improvement of drainage in critical area in the States including Andhra Pradesh and Orissa. Flood Management being a State subject, the schemes for flood control are planned, funded and executed by the State Governments as per their own priorities. The assistance rendered by Central Government is technical, catalytical and promotional in nature. This information was given by the Union Minister of State for Water Resources, Smt. Bijoya Chakravarty in written reply to a question from Shri Bhartruhari Mahtab in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Desilting Gandhak River in Bihar
pr_content: LOK SABHAAccording to the information available there are in all 15 spans in the Dhumariaghat bridge out of which water is flowing through four spans during the lean season, as there is some siltation in other spans. However, in high discharge, Gandak water flows through all vents of Dhumariaghat bridge. As informed by Government of Bihar, there is no proposal with the State Government to desilt river Gandak. However, the Dhumariaghat bridge site was jointly inspected by the officials of Water Resources Department, Government of Bihar, Ganga Flood Control Commission and Central Water and Power Research Station (CWPRS), Pune to look into the problem during which CWPRS suggested some short term measures to be tried before the monsoon 2003. Subsequent to the above joint visit, a Committee of Technical Experts from the Government of Bihar also visited the site. The Government of Bihar has infomed that based on the suggestions made by these experts, various anti-erosion measure were taken by the State Government before the monsoon of 2003. In order to evolve long term solution, the CWPRS has suggested to the Government of Bihar to take up mathematical model study. This information was given by the Union Minister of State for Water Resources, Smt. Bijoya Chakravarty in written reply to a question from Shri Raghunath Jha in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: New varieties of oilseeds
pr_content: LOK SABHA The Indian Council of Agricultural Research in collaboration with State Agricultural Universities has conducted research for developing new varieties of oilseed. As a result, more than 50 new and improved varieties and hybrids of different oilseed crops have been developed and released for cultivation in the last five years. The new varieties and hybrids have 20 to 30% higher yield potential than local cultivars. Some of the improved varieties of oilseeds crops released recently are as follows: Groundnut : LGN 2, Dh 86, GG 14, CSMG 884 Rapeseed-Mustard : RTM-314, VSL-5, Vasundhra, Swarn Jyoti, Geeta, Arawali Soybean : Ahilya 4,MAUS 47, MPUS 61, MAUS 71, RAUS 5,Indira Soya 9, Hara Soya Linseed : LCK 9216, LMH-62, Meera, Parvati Sunflower MSFH-47, MLSFH-82, KBSH-44 Safflower: DSH-129, MKH-11. ` Sesamum : TKG-55, MT-75, JTS-8 Castor : Jyothi, DCH-177,GCH-5 The major oilseeds producing States in India are Madhya Pradesh, Gujarat, Rajasthan, Maharashtra, Andhra Pradesh, Tamil Nadu, Karnataka, Uttar Pradesh, Haryana, West Bengal, Assam, Orissa, Bihar and Punjab. This information was given by the Minister of State for Agriculture, Shri Hukumdeo Narayan Yadav in a written reply to a question by S/shri Y.G.Mahajan and Ramdas Rupala Gavit in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Social Justice and Empowerment Ministry releases Rs. 221.62 crore to 2602 Non-Governmental Organisations
pr_content: RAJYA SABHARs. 221.62 crore were released to 2602 Non-Governmental Organisations under social welfare programmes by the Social Justice and Empowerment Ministry during 2002-2003. Stating this in a written reply in the Rajya Sabha today, the Minister of state for Social Justice and Empowerment Shri Nagmani said that the functioning of the projects sanctioned under various schemes are regularly monitored by seeking periodical progress reports from the grantee NGOs. He said the projects are inspected each year by the State Government authorities/ nodal agencies. The second instalment of grant is sanctioned only on receipt of inspection report indicating the satisfactory functioning of the project. Shri Nagmani said the grantee NGO is required to submit audited accounts and utilization certificates duly certified by the Chartered Accountant. The unspent balance, if any, is adjusted with the grant for the subsequent year. He said that there are 115 NGOs working in Madhya Pradesh.

pr_title: National Commission for Persons with Disabilities to start functioning during the next quarter of the financial year
pr_content: RAJYA SABHAThe Rajya Sabha was informed today that the National Commission for Persons with Disabilities is expected to start its work during the next quarter of the financial year. Stating this in a written reply today, the Minister of state for Social Justice and Empowerment Shri Kailash Meghwal said that the process of creation of posts for the National Commission and arrangement of accommodation for housing this body is under way. Shri Meghwal said that adequate funds have been sought in the current year for setting up the National Commission for Persons with Disabilities.

pr_title: Call Centre Scheme for farmers on anvil
pr_content: The call centre scheme for farmers on anvil. The Agriculture Minister Shri Rajnath Singh stated this, while inaugurating the 44th annual general meeting of the National Federation of Cooperative Sugar Factories Limited, here this evening. Under the scheme any farmer of the country will be able to obtain any agriculture information required by him. The facility will be available free of cost to the farmers. The scheme is likely to be introduced by the end of next month. In his speech the Agriculture Minister said, that the government is committed to resolve the problems of the sugar industry and sugar cane growers. He stressed the need to improve the quality of the sugar to increase exports. He said the sugar industry, should think of ways to make sugar exports from the country more competitive. He said the government has taken several steps to grant autonomy to cooperative societies. He pointed out that cooperative societies could prosper only in an environment of least governmental interference. Earlier, the Agriculture Minister gave away awards for 2002-03 to the winning cooperative sugar factories in the categories of Technical efficiency, cane development, financial management, maximum crushing, maximum exports and best cooperative sugar factories. The overall best cooperative sugar factory was given to Shree Chhatrapati Shahu Sahakari Sakhar Karkhana Ltd. from Kagal in Maharashtra.

pr_title: Economic Partnership Agreement with Sri Lanka proposed
pr_content: There is a proposal to enter into a Comprehensive Economic Partnership Agreement (CEPA) between India and Sri Lanka. Pursuant to the meeting between the Prime Minister of India and Sri Lanka during 2002, a Joint Study Group (JSG) was set up. This Group, in its report submitted to the two Prime Ministers on 20th October, 2003 in New Delhi, has recommended that CEPA could address issues such as reducing items under the negative list, adopting trade facilitation measures like harmonised customs procedures, conclusion of Mutual Recognition Agreements (MRAs). Additionally, the CEPA would include trade in services, investment and economic cooperation. The details of the CEPA are yet to be negotiated by both countries. This information was given by Shri S. B. Mookherjee, Minister of State for Commerce & Industry, in a written reply in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_issued_by: Ministry of Youth Affairs and Sports
pr_title: Shri Vikram Verma condoles the death of legendary cricketer Shri M.J. Gopalan
pr_content: The Union Minister of Youth Affairs and Sports, Shri Vikram Verma has condoled the death of legendary cricketer Shri M.J. Gopalan. The message sent, reads as “I have been deeply grieved to hear the sad demise of legendary cricketer Shri M.J. Gopalan on 21st December 2003 at Chennai. Shri Gopalan is remembered for his outstanding contribution to the sport of cricket and hockey. May God give you and your family the strength to bear this great loss with courage and fortitude.”

pr_title: Special Economic Package for the State of Bihar
pr_content: A Memorandum of Agreement was signed between Government of Bihar and the Union Ministry of Power here today in the presence of Shri Anant G. Geete, Minister of Power, Smt. Jayawanti Mehta, Minister of State for Power and Shri Shakeel Ahmad Khan, Minister for Energy, Govt. of Bihar to implement a scheme for improvement of sub-transmission and distribution system in the State of Bihar at a cost of Rs. 365 crore. The funds for this Scheme would be made available by the Planning Commission under the "Rashtriya Sam Vikas Yojana" through a special grant released by the Union Ministry of Power. The Scheme will be executed by POWERGRID on behalf of Bihar State Electricity Board (BSEB) as deposit work, for which the funds would be released by Ministry of Power directly to POWERGRID. After execution, the lines and substations would be transferred to BSEB. With the execution of the package, quality as well as reliability of power would improve. POWERGRID would complete the work within 18 months. The schemes so planned have twin objectives i.e. to meet the present power requirement of the State of Bihar with reliability as well as to facilitate meeting requirement of future growth in power demand. With the strengthening of system North Bihar will be able to import power from Tala HEP in Bhutan as well. The scheme has been formulated in two parts – the first, being Part-A, covers most areas of North Bihar while the second (Part-B) covers the rest of the State as detailed under: PART-A (North Bihar) a) Transmission lines (220/132/33 KV) 697 Kms. b) Sub Stations (220/132, 132/33 and 33/11 KV) 10 Nos. PART-B (Other Parts of Bihar) a) Transmission lines (220/132/33 KV) 364 Kms. b) Sub Stations (220/132, 132/33 and 33/11 KV) 8 Nos.

pr_title: Railway Minister calls upon wagon industry for expeditious supply
pr_content: The Union Minister of Railways, Shri Nitish Kumar has called upon the wagon industry to expedite supply of wagons to help the Railways meet its ever increasing freight traffic demands. Speaking at the 17th Annual Day Function of the Indian Railway Finance Corporation (IRFC) here yesterday evening, Shri Nitish Kumar expressed his concern over the shortages of wagons stating that out of procurement of 22,000 wagons targeted for the current financial year 2003-2004, only 7,000 wagons were procured so far from the outside sources. Talking of various measures like phasing out of four wheeler wagons, strengthening of Golden Quadrilateral and its diagonals, port connectivity, reducing speed gap and buoyancy in the economy, the Minister exuded confidence that the wagon industry would expedite supply of wagons as the demands for wagons were to go up further. The Minister complimented the IRFC for its excellent performance and asked it and other railway public sector undertakings to invest in the equity of RailTel Corporation of India. The Minister said that having been encouraged by the success of IRFC, its funding was now even more attractive than the funding from budgetary support. As the Railways had huge investment programmes for implementation of the National Rail Vikas Yojana (NRVY), the special purpose vehicle, the Rail Vikas Nigame Ltd. set up to oversee and execute NRVY, was in need for accessing debt markets in the coming years. In this connection, the Government has asked the IRFC to prepare a concept paper looking to its considerable expertise in the area. The Chairman Railway Board, Shri R.K. Singh, who also spoke on the occasion, complimented IRFC for having reduced the cost of borrowing to 6.2 per cent in 2002-2003, hoping it would play an important role in the implementation of the Corporate Safety Plan (2003-2013). The Chairperson, IRFC and Financial Commissioner (Railways) Smt. Vijayalaxmi Viswanathan said that the Company has graduated from a high cost borrowings to the low cost mobilization following growing liquidity in the capital market. The result has been a cumulative investment of Rs. 26,000 crores for augmenting rolling stock. Earlier, the Managing Director, IRFC, Shri Balachandram, in his welcome address gave an overview of the performance of the company during the last 17 years of its existence. During the current fiscal year ending November 2003, IRFC has mobilized 75 per cent of Rs. 2,970 crores, the target fixed for it in the Railway Budget 2003-2004, at an average cost of 6.1 per cent taking advantage of the liquidity in the market and its credit rating, which is the highest. Given the market reports of low appetite for commercial credit, the Company is hopeful of achieving the borrowing target at a cost lower than the previous year.

pr_title: Shillong Water Supply Project materialises with Central aid
pr_content: Central funding has made the Greater Shillong Water Supply Project a reality now. Between 1998 and 2003, the Centre’s grant to the government of Meghalaya for this project totalled Rs. 35.79 crore. Being executed by the State’s Public Health Engineering Department, the project is almost complete. On being fully commissioned by September 2004, it will supply adequate drinking water to nearly four lakh people living in and around Shillong. The project is designed to generate and supply about 11.30 million gallons of water every day. Under the project water is to be pumped from the river Umiew near Mauphlang on the outskirts of Shillong. Treated water from the plant’s reservoir will then flow to different localities in Shillong through a network of distribution system, tiding over its shortage.

pr_title: Consultative Committee of the Steel Ministry meets
pr_content: The Steel Authority of India Limited (SAIL), a public sector unit (PSU) of the Steel Ministry plans to meet its Iron Ore requirement of 33.5 million tonnes by 2011-12 through systematic and comprehensive development of new mines at Rowghat, Chiria, Thakurani and South and Central Blocks of Kiriburu-Meghahataburu deposits. The Rashtriya Ispal Nigam Limited (RINL) the other PSU of the Ministry is also interested to acquire captive iron ore mines to meet its increasing requirements, today said the Minister of Steel, Shri Braja Kishore Tripathy addressing the Members of the Consultative Committee attached to his Ministry. He informed that efforts are being made to obtain mining licences and other clearances from the concerned State Governments to develop large mechanized mines. The Minister said that the quality of iron ore available in India is of world standard and it is the real strength of the Indian steel industry. With a view to ensure that high grade iron ore is available to the Indian industry for a long time, exports of high grade iron ore are made through a designated canalizing agency only and it is subject to the ceiling imposed by the Government. He informed that the steel consumption in the country is expected to increase from 30 million tonnes to 55 million tonnes by the year 2011-12 and the public sector unit would require more iron ore to step up their production to meet the growing need. Shri Tripathy gave a brief account of the growing steel sector and said the finished steel production has grown by 9.9 per cent during 2002-03 and reached 33.67 million tonnes. From April to November 2003-04, its total production was 22.800 million tonnes which is 6.2 per cent higher than the production of the corresponding period last year. The production of pig iron during the year has been 3.54 million tonnes with a growth of 2.25 per cent. He said that the exports during the year 2002-03 at 4.5 million tonnes was higher by 66.6 per cent than the corresponding figure of 2001-02. During the current year, the exports have also shown substantial growth. The Members of the Committee appreciated the Ministry's endeavour to plan acquiring iron ore for the future needs and said both SAIL and RINL should expeditiously implement these plans. They expressed happiness over the turning around of both the public sector companies. They suggested to increase the production capacity in the country to meet the growing demands by reviewing the sick units and upgrading the capacity of the working units. Replying to the queries the Minister said, the Ministry has taken all possible steps for the revival of sick units and gradually upgrading the capacity of major plants. Besides, financial institutions have been approached to extend all help and co-operation to complete the projects which are under way. An awareness campaign has been started in urban and rural areas to step up per capita consumption of steel in the country, he said. Following members of Parliament were present : S/Shri Sunil Khan, Tilakdhari Prasad Singh, Manjaylal, Shibu Soren, Jibon Roy and Gaya Singh.

pr_issued_by: Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food & Public Distribution
pr_title: Free sale sugar quota for January February and March released
pr_content: Government has released 10.5 lakh tonnes of sugar for the month of January, 10.5 lakh tonnes for February and 10 lakh tonnes for March, 2004 as quotas for indigenous free sale. With a levy quota of 2.00 lakh tonnes released for each of these three months, the total availability of sugar would be 12.50, 12.50 and 12.00 lakh tonnes respectively in each of these months. The free sale quotas are meant only for internal consumption and with enough stocks of sugar in hand, Government would not hesitate in releasing further substantial quantities additionally if required.

pr_title: Satellite Survey for Diamond
pr_content: LOK SABHADuring the last three years satellite imagery has been used for identifying kimberlite/lamproite pipes/bodies in Mahboobnagar, Nalgonda, Kurnool, Annanttapur, Khammam and Krishna districts of Andhra Pradesh; Raichur, Gulburga and Tumkur districts of Karnataka; Chandrapur and Gadchiroli districts of Maharashtra; Bastar, Raigarh and Jangih-champa districts of Chhattisgarh and Bargar, Nuapada, Bolangir, Sambalpur, Sonepur and Jharsududa districts of Orissa. Incidence of diamond has been indicated from gravels of Ib river in Raigarh area, Chattisgarh and Wajrakarur Kimberlite field Annanttpur district of Andhra Pradesh. This information was given by the Minister for Mines, Shri Ramesh Bais in a written reply in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Asbestos mining
pr_content: LOK SABHAAsbestos is being mined in the areas already held under mining lease. In view of the hazardous effect of asbestos mining on health, the Government has decided not to grant any new lease for mining of asbestos and minerals found alongwith asbestos. It does not renew the existing mining leases of asbestos. The import of asbestos is mainly being allowed as domestic production of asbestos, particularly chrysotile asbestos which is meager to meet demand of manufacturing units of asbestos cement sheets, asbestos pressure pipes, asbestos cloth, brake lining etc. Domestically available amphibolite asbestos is not suitable for the above said purposes and it finds application mostly in thermal insulation and treatment of acids. This information was given by the Minister for Mines, Shri Ramesh Bais in a written reply in the Lok Sabha today.

pr_title: Results of the National Defence Academy & Naval Academy Written Examinations (II) 2003 announced
pr_content: The Union Public Service Commission has announced the results of the National Defence Academy (NDA) & Naval Academy Examination (II) 2003 held by the Commission in September, 2003. The Candidates whose roll numbers appear in the list have qualified for interview by the Services Selection Board of the Ministry of Defence for admission to Army, Navy and Air Force Wings of the National Defence Academy for the 112th Course and Naval Academy for the 32nd 10+2 (Executive Branch) course commencing from July, 2004. The candidature of all candidates whose roll numbers appear in the list is provisional. They are required to submit original certificates direct to the Army Headquarters. They should not send the certificates to the UPSC. For any further information, the candidates may contact Facilitation Counter of the Commission, either in person or on Telephone numbers 23385271 or 23381125 or 23098543. The result is also available at Union Public Service Commission website at http://www.upsc.gov.in.

pr_title: New Scheme on Sustainable Development of Horticulture Initiated
pr_content: The Centre has initiated a new scheme on Sustainable Development of Horticulture through Technological Interventions. The scheme would address new issues like development of horticulture in island eco-systems and promote Indian horticulture in the international arena. The Agriculture Secretary Shri R.C.A.Jain said this while inaugurating the annual National Horticulture Conference here this morning. A new scheme on High-Tech Horticulture and Precision Farming has also been included in the 10th Plan to promote all aspects of high-tech horticulture covering technology dissemination and application on the farmer’s field. The Agriculture Secretary said that the horticulture sector is still in a transition state and development of technologies starting from production of planting material to value addition of produce needs to acquire accelerated pace. He said that the task of doubling the horticulture production by the end of 2011-12 is a big challenge which will require efforts to implement a National Mission on Horticulture. In the quest for diversification of agriculture, horticulture has emerged as the most viable option. Turning to WTO related issues , Shri R.C.A.Jain called upon the State Governments to urgently identify the crops which are critical from the point of view of food and livelihood security so that suitable measures could be taken in terms of appropriate bound rates of tariff and other non-tariff measures. He assured that all efforts are being made to protect the interests of the country’s farmers during the on –going negotiations . Farmers also need to be sensitized to maintain high quality standards at competitive cost to avail of the market access opportunities abroad. Application of stringent sanitary and phyto-sanitary measures by the developed countries on exports from India is an issue in the context of export efforts. Judicious use of pesticides and chemicals assumes greater significance in the context of food safety issues. Health hazards due to pesticide residues become more acute with the use of pesticides in horticultural crops which are largely consumed fresh. Shri R.C.A. Jain called upon the Plant Protection Orgnisation to gear itself up for surveillance, certification and inspection for export of horticultural crops to the countries with stringent requirements. The Agriculture Secretary lamented that despite efforts being made by the National Horticulture Board to collate and document the information on area, production, productivity, arrival and prices of horticultural produce, the data base on horticulture is very weak. Despite requests to the State Governments to furnish information about the situation of sensitive horticultural crops on weekly basis, the same has not been forthcoming to the desired extent. Pointing out that availability of timely data is crucial for facilitating decisions having a direct bearing on the farming community, the Agriculture Secretary called upon the State Governments to cooperate in furnishing the required information. He informed the Conference that the work for launching an exclusive TV and radio channel on Agriculture for dissemination of knowledge and Kisan Call Centres for easy access to information is in an advanced stage. These initiatives will have far reaching impact on Indian farmers and make agriculture a knowledge-based enterprise. In his address, the Horticulture Commissioner, Dr. H.P.Singh listed the challenges in the way of achieving the targeted horticultural production of 300 million tonnes by the end of the 11th Plan.. He said that productivity of many horticultural crops continue to be low and post harvest losses continue to be high. Quality of produce needs improvement and resource use efficiency requires upgradation. Although India is ranked second in the world in the production of fruits as well as vegetables, availability of fruits and vegetables still continues to be much below the dietary requirements. Dr. Singh also informed the Conference that bamboo is being declared as a horticultural and plantation crop. The Agriculture Ministry is the nodal Ministry for implementation of the Bamboo Mission. The two-day Conference will review the progress of various horticultural programmes and will also discuss emerging issues to develop a road map for the envisaged horticulture- led transformation. Horticulture Secretaries and Directors from various States, Vice Chancellors of various State Agriculture Universities, horticulture experts, senior officers from various Ministries and representatives of various commodity associations are taking part in the Conference.

pr_title: India-Israel for comprehensive agreement on scientific tiesISRAELI SATELLITE LAUNCH BY INDIAN ROCKET
pr_content: India and Israel have agreed to go in for a new comprehensive agreement for cooperation in science and technology. This will spell out the common agenda, methodology, joint technology development and upgradation of technology. Within six months, the two sides will prepare a Plan of Action, identifying the joint projects to be taken up besides other activities for implementation during the next two years. This is revealed in a joint statement issued at the end of discussions between the two delegations, headed by the Israeli Minister for Science and Technology, Mr. Eliezer Sandberg and the Minister of Sate for Science and Technology, Shri Bachi Singh Rawat. The two ministers while reaffirming their firm commitment to promote scientific and technological collaboration, agreed that this constitutes an important element for fostering socio-economic development of the peoples of the two countries. The Israeli Minister was keen on cooperation in Nano-technology, Nano-biotechnology and solar energy. Cooperation in space technology and applications also figured during the talks. Israel is interested in India launching some of its micro-satellites. For this, the Israeli delegation is going to Bangalore tomorrow for talks with ISRO authorities. Shri Bachi Singh Rawat expressing India’s keenness in expanding the scope of cooperation with Israel said opportunities will be provided to young researchers to upgrade their sills in their areas of interest and short-term fellowships would be made available to them. Both the Ministers also agreed to allocate adequate funds required for undertaking joint research projects etc. The Space Agencies of the two countries have already signed a Memorandum of Understanding on TAUVEX-GSAT-4, which offers a unique opportunity to put the Indian and Israeli scientists in the front line of space-astrophysics. The TAUVEX is a set of three wide-field telescopes that will image the ultraviolet sky. It was specifically recognised that installing TAUVEX on-board the technology demonstrator satellite GSAT-4 would be ideal for operating TAUVEX as a scientific payload in geo-synchronous orbit. While this will allow the Israeli team to realise its goals, it will bring in UV expertise to the Indian astrophysical community.

pr_title: The roadside dhabhas and small hotels to get basic hospitality training at doorsteps
pr_content: The Department of Tourism has embarked on a scheme to train and upgrade skills of service providers in the unorganised tourism sector. Under this new scheme of ‘Capacity building for service providers’, people working in small hotels, roadside dhabas, restaurants and other eatery joints spread around the places of tourist interest would be given basic essential training by the Institutes of Hotel Management and Food Crafts Institutes functioning both in the Government and private sector. Objective of the scheme is to enhance service quality and delivery among a large population of workers servicing tourists as they are the cutting edge who can increase consumer satisfaction and trigger repeat travel. The training primarily focuses on service skills, etiquette and basic mannerism, health and personal hygiene, cleanliness, garbage disposal and the like. Lessons on cooking, energy and nutrition saving techniques would also be given. Mobile training facilities are being set up so that the training of the service providers is available at their doorstep.

pr_title: Flood protection in Assam by interlinking of rivers
pr_content: RAJYA SABHAInterlinking of rivers under National Perspective Plan (NPP) prepared by Central Government envisages construction of storage dams. The storage dams reduce the severity of floods and flood damages considerably. Preliminary studies done by National Water Development Agency (NWDA), the flood peaks are estimated to be reduced by about 20-30% in Brahmaputra basin. Under the NPP, Manas-Sankosh-Tista-Ganga link project has been identified for preparation of Feasibility Report. According to the preliminary studies done by NWDA, irrigation benefits to the extent of 2.08 lakh hectare to Assam State in the districts of Goalpar, Dhubri, Kokrajhar and Barpeta is envisaged under the link. This information was given by the Union Minister of State for Water Resources, Smt. Bijoya Chakravarty in written reply to a question from Dr. Arun Kumar Sarma in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Right to decommission dam
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA‘The Kerala Irrigation and Water Conservation Act 2003’ passed by the State legislature empowers the State Government to decommission a dam. This Act provides for constitution of a Dam Safety Authority, which is to be headed by a retired Judge of the High Court. Other members of the Dam Safety Authority will be eminent specialist in the field, officers from the various State Government Departments and Chief Engineer, Central Water Commission, Government of India. Relevant provision of this Act regarding decommissioning of dam are as under 62(e) to advise Government to suspend the functioning of any dam if the public safety so demands; 62(f) to examine the precariousness of any dam, in public interest and to submit its recommendations including decommissioning of dam to the Government; and 62(5) the disbanding, construction or reconstruction of any dam shall be made only after obtaining a report in that regard from the Authority. This information was given by the Union Minister of State for Water Resources, Smt. Bijoya Chakravarty in written reply to a question from Shri K. Rama Mohana Rao in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Proposal for National Water-Ways Project examined
pr_content: RAJYA SABHAThe Central Government has constituted a Task Force in December, 2002 under the Chairmanship of Shri Suresh Prabhu, MP (LS) with a view to bring about consensus amongst the States and provide guidance on norms of appraisals of individual projects and modalities for project funding etc. The Task Force has constituted an Independent Group of Experts (IGE) to assist itself in assessing the alternative proposals received from various individuals/groups to examine practicality, technical feasibility and general cost/benefit projection of such proposals. The National Waterways Project (NWP) as proposed by Shri A. C. Kamaraj, Madurai was examined by the IGE along with various other proposals. The IGE in its report (September, 2003) submitted to the Task Force has concluded that all the proposals examined are not rooted in the basic tenets of temporal and spatial hydrology of the river basins and as such are technically unsound, incomplete and hence, cannot be pursued in their present form. This information was given by the Union Minister of State for Water Resources, Smt. Bijoya Chakravarty in written reply to a question from Shri M. V. Rajasekharan in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Thirteen States & 3 Union Territories sign MoA for Urban Reforms
pr_content: LOK SABHA Thirteen States and three Union Territories have signed a Memorandum of Agreement (MoA) with the Centre, in full or truncated form, for availing Central assistance under the Urban Reforms Incentive Fund (URIF). These are Tamil Nadu, Madhya Pradesh, Chattisgarh, Tripura, Karnataka, Maharashtra, Manipur, Kerala, Haryana, Chandigarh, Andhra Pradesh, A&N Islands, West Bengal, Orissa, Nagaland and Delhi. This information was given by the Minister of State (Independent Charge) in the Ministry of Urban Development & Poverty Alleviation, Shri Bandaru Dattatraya in a written reply to the question of Shri Iqbal Ahmed Saradgi and Shri G.S. Basavaraj in Lok Sabha today. Shri Dattatraya stated that Arunachal Pradesh, Goa, Jammu & Kashmir, Meghalaya, Punjab, Rajasthan and Uttaranchal are willing to sign MoA which is likely to be signed shortly by these States. Assam, Bihar, Gujarat, Himachal Pradesh, Jharkhand, Mizoram, Sikkim, Uttar Pradesh, Daman & Diu & Pondicherry have not responded so far whereas, Dadra Nagar Haveli has informed that URIF scheme can not be implemented as there is no municipality in this Union Territory. Lakshadweep has intimated that they have already implemented six out of seven areas of reforms under URIF scheme and hence do not intend to enter into MoA.

pr_title: 0.9 Billion Gas Reserves in India
pr_content: LOK SABHA Balance gas reserves in the country as on 1.4.2003 have been estimated to be of the order of 0.9 billion tonnes. Giving this information in a written reply in the Lok Sabha the Minister for Chemical and Fertilizers Shri S.S. Dhindsa added that Fertilizer industry is a major consumer of natural gas and accounts for nearly 38 per cent of total consumption of gas. The average actual supply of gas to fertilizer units during 2002-03 was about 21.54 million standard cubic meters per day (MMSCMD). No assessment about the duration for which the gas reserves will last has been made as it is dependent on several factors such as trends of production and consumption, new gas finds, alternative sources of energy etc.

pr_issued_by: Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food & Public Distribution
pr_title: December 24 to be observed as "National Consumer Day"
pr_content: December 24 will be observed as "National Consumer Day" in the country. It was on this Day in the year 1986 that the historic Consumer Protection Act, 1986 received assent of the President. Observance of the day as National Consumer Day is intended to serve as an occasion for highlighting the need for promoting consumer awareness and the measures taken by the Government and other agencies involved in promoting consumer protection and welfare. With increasing consumerism and opening up of the economy towards liberalization and globalization the protection of the rights of the consumers has become even more important. For the first time, Minister of Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution , Shri Sharad Yadav will flag off a Rally of school children at Talkotora Stadium (in front of Swimming Pool) on the occasion organised by the Department of Youth Affairs & Sports, National Service Scheme, New Delhi. Over 2000 students will participate in this rally. With a view to actively associate children in the consumer movement and to launch a new scheme under Consumer Welfare Fund, Shri Sharad Yadav will also launch consumer clubs in Delhi Public School, NOIDA, and in Sadhu Vaswani School, New Delhi along with Chief Minister of Delhi on the occasion of National Consumer Day tomorrow.

pr_title: Presidential assent for the Marriage Laws (Amendment) Bill
pr_content: The Marriage Laws (Amendment) Bill, 2003 has received the assent of the President today, and consequently has become an Act of Parliament. The Act amends the Special Marriage Act, 1954 and Hindu Marriage Act, 1955 to provide that a petition for relief under the provisions of these Acts may be presented by an aggrieved wife to the District Court within the local limits of whose jurisdiction she may be residing. The Act also provides that the parties to a matrimonial suit could prefer appeal within 90 days instead of 30 days. The Act is being published in the Gazette of India, Extraordinary, Part II, Section I, dated the 23rd December, 2003 as Act No. 50 of 2003.

pr_title: New Scheme on sustainable development of horticulture initiated
pr_content: The Centre has initiated a new scheme on Sustainable Development of Horticulture through Technological Interventions. The scheme would address new issues like development of horticulture in island eco-systems and promote Indian horticulture in the international arena. The Agriculture Secretary Shri R.C.A.Jain said this while inaugurating the annual National Horticulture Conference here this morning. A new scheme on High-Tech Horticulture and Precision Farming has also been included in the 10th Plan to promote all aspects of high-tech horticulture covering technology dissemination and application on the farmer’s field. The Agriculture Secretary said that the horticulture sector is still in a transition state and development of technologies starting from production of planting material to value addition of produce needs to acquire accelerated pace. He said that the task of doubling the horticulture production by the end of 2011-12 is a big challenge which will require efforts to implement a National Mission on Horticulture. In the quest for diversification of agriculture, horticulture has emerged as the most viable option. Turning to WTO related issues , Shri R.C.A.Jain called upon the State Governments to urgently identify the crops which are critical from the point of view of food and livelihood security so that suitable measures could be taken in terms of appropriate bound rates of tariff and other non-tariff measures. He assured that all efforts are being made to protect the interests of the country’s farmers during the on –going negotiations . Farmers also need to be sensitized to maintain high quality standards at competitive cost to avail of the market access opportunities abroad. Application of stringent sanitary and phyto-sanitary measures by the developed countries on exports from India is an issue in the context of export efforts. Judicious use of pesticides and chemicals assumes greater significance in the context of food safety issues. Health hazards due to pesticide residues become more acute with the use of pesticides in horticultural crops which are largely consumed fresh. Shri R.C.A. Jain called upon the Plant Protection Orgnisation to gear itself up for surveillance, certification and inspection for export of horticultural crops to the countries with stringent requirements. These initiatives will have far reaching impact on Indian farmers and make agriculture a knowledge-based enterprise. In his address, the Horticulture Commissioner, Dr. H.P.Singh listed the challenges in the way of achieving the targeted horticultural production of 300 million tonnes by the end of the 11th Plan.. He said that productivity of many horticultural crops continue to be low and post harvest losses continue to be high. Quality of produce needs improvement and resource use efficiency requires upgradation. Although India is ranked second in the world in the production of fruits as well as vegetables, availability of fruits and vegetables still continues to be much below the dietary requirements. Dr. Singh also informed the Conference that bamboo is being declared as a horticultural and plantation crop. The Agriculture Ministry is the nodal Ministry for implementation of the Bamboo Mission. The two-day Conference will review the progress of various horticultural programmes and will also discuss emerging issues to develop a road map for the envisaged horticulture- led transformation. pr_title: Development activities launched in Lodhi Road Complex
pr_content: Union Minister of Tourism and Culture Shri Jagmohan and the Minister of State (Independent Charge) for Urban Development & Poverty Alleviation Shri Bandaru Dattatraya launched various development activities of CPWD in Lodhi Road Complex here today. Shri Jagmohan laid the foundation stone of Samaj Sadan to be built at a cost of Rs. 180 lakh. It will provide community facilities for the socio cultural activities of the inhabitants residing in neighbourhood. Rainwater harvesting system will be provided in the campus for effective use of rainwater. Shri Jagmohan also laid the foundation for the ‘Unknown Soldier Park’ to be developed within the Complex at a cost of Rs. 42.71 lakh. On this occasion, Minister of State (Independent Charge) for Urban Development and Poverty Alleviation Shri Bandaru Dattatraya laid the foundation for the ‘Sankara Park’. It will be developed at a cost of Rs. 42.51 lakh. In all, four parks are to be developed in Lodhi Road Complex. The Central Public Works Department (CPWD) under the Ministry of Urban Development & Poverty Alleviation is celebrating its 150th anniversary. The department has been developing parks in Delhi over a period of time, in an endeavour to provide as much green space as possible. CPWD has recently developed 13 parks in various areas of Delhi whereas three other parks are being developed and will be completed shortly. These include Jai Prakash Narain Park at Firoz Shah Kotla and Dara Shikoh Park at Red Fort. Besides, 12 more major parks are proposed to be developed in various colonies within next two years.

pr_title: Centre To Evolve A Strategy For Effective Implementation Of The Special Component Plan For Scheduled Castes, Says Dr. Satyanarayan Jatiya; State Ministers Meeting In February
pr_content: The Minister for Social Justice and Empowerment Dr. Satyanarayan Jatiya has said that the Centre will evolve a strategy for effective implementation of the scheme of Special Central Assistance (SCA) to Special Component Plan (SCP) for Scheduled Castes (SCs). Addressing the meeting of the Parliamentary Consultative Committee attached to his Ministry here today, Dr. Jatiya said that a meeting of concerned Ministers of State Governments and Union Territories would be held in February 2004. The Minister said that the states must utilize funds for the purpose for which they are allocated and will have to furnish utilization certificates in time. He said the objective of the SCA is to support SC families to enhance their productivity and income. SCA is an additive to the Special Component Plan and is expected to give a thrust to family oriented schemes of economic development of SCs below the poverty line. It provides resources for filling the critical gaps and bridging the missing vital inputs so that the schemes can be more meaningful. Referring to the good work being done by NGOs in implementing various schemes of the Ministry, Dr. Jatiya said, " We are working on a system to ensure timely disbursement of funds to NGOs". He said that a system will have to be evolved for undertaking surprise visits of NGOs by the Ministry. Dr. Jatiya specifically referred to the problems of the aged persons. He said that service delivery to the senior citizens has become a challenging task as resources being limited are not keeping a pace with ever-increasing population of older persons. Reiterating government’s commitment to the welfare of the senior citizens, he suggested that the new year be termed as the Social Security Year of the Aged to focus on better service delivery to them. India is poised to have second largest population of aged persons in the world. Projection studies indicate that the number of persons above 60 years will from the present 76 million increase to 100 million in 2013 and further double to about 200 million in next 17 years ( i.e., upto 2030). The interesting aspect of the aged in India is that 80% of them live in rural areas, thus, making service delivery a challenge. Secondly 30% of senior citizens are living below the poverty line. Thirdly, women would constitute half of the elderly population by 2016. The Members of the Consultative Committee said that the government must give top priority to the rehabilitation and service delivery programmes for the aged and disabled. They said that the Centre must give direction to the states to give matching funds to the Corporations working under the aegis of the Ministry. They said that the NGOs doing good work should be encouraged while those found misusing the funds should be blacklisted. The Ministers of state for Social Justice and Empowerment Shri Kailash Meghwal and Shri Nagmani, the Members of Parliament Shri K H Muniyappa and Shri Kishan Lal Diler participated in the meeting. The Social Justice and Empowerment Secretary Shri B. S. Baswan, other senior officials and the Managing Directors of various Corporation of the Ministry took part in the meeting.
