pr_title: Press communique
pr_content: The President has been pleased to appoint the following as Lieutenant-Governors :- 1. Shri N.N. Jha, presently holding the charge of Lieutenant-Governor of Andaman and Nicobar Islands as Lieutenant-Governor of Pondicherry; and 2. Prof. Ramchandra Ganesh Kapse as Lieutenant-Governor of Andman and Nicobar Islands. The above appointments will take effect from the dates the incumbents assume charge of their respective offices.

pr_title: Purchase of pipes by GAIL
pr_content: RAJYA SABHA Shri Ram Naik, Minister of Petroleum & Natural Gas informed the Rajya Sabha today while replying to a question that GAIL (India) Limited (GAIL) has reported that they have procured pipes for their Dahej-Vijaipur Pipeline (DVPL) through international competitive bidding wherein technically the best available material at most competitive prices has been procured. The selection of vendors for procurement of pipelines has been done by GAIL keeping in view the pipeline requirement of the project and as per the technical advice of their consultants M/s Engineers India Limited. Tractebel Engineering, Belgium, who are consultants to GAIL for their upcoming Dahej-Uran Pipeline Project, has also recommended Longitudinally Submerged Arc Welded Pipes only as against the other alternative of Helically Submerged Arc Welded Pipes. GAIL has denied that it has spent an extra amount of Rs. 450 crore in procuring pipes for its gas pipeline project. Based on safety and economic considerations, GAIL has to take a view on specifications of material to be procured for gas pipelines. Government will issue appropriate directions if considered necessary.

pr_title: Train Protection and Warning System
pr_content: Indian Railways have planned to adopt Train Protection and Warning System (TPWS) as per the recommendations of the Justice Khanna Committee on Railway Safety to strengthen the safety and security of passengers and rail installations. It will be installed on 280 track kilometres of ‘A’ route on Southern and North Central Railways, to begin with. The TPWS is a variant of Auxiliary Warning System (AWS) to enhance further safety levels in train operations by preventing cases of ‘signal passed at danger’. At present, AWS is working satisfactorily in Mumbai suburban sections of Central and Western Railways. The TPWS uses Euro Balise as a track device, which is an electronic device with very less copper inside. It uses radio transmission for sending information to cab equipment. The conventional AWS system uses track magnets, which are basically made of copper, making it prone to thefts. In AWS, information about signal aspect is transmitted from track device to cab equipment through electro magnetic induction.

pr_title: SAIL's turnaround this year
pr_content: Public Sector undertaking Steel Authority of India Limited (SAIL), plans to achieve a six to seven per cent growth for the current fiscal and has targeted a 10.8 million tonnes production during the year. Since the domestic market had remained buoyant, prospects are brighter and the company looks forward to turnaround this year. SAIL recorded a net loss of Rs.304 crore in the year 2002-03, which is about 82 per cent lower than loss incurred in the previous year. It recorded a net profit of Rs. 255 crore in the first quarter of the current fiscal. The company is planning to enhance investments in various projects to upgrade existing technology and has so far invested around Rs.12,000 crore to modernise its equipment. It now plans a further Rs.500-Rs.600 crore investment every year for incremental upgradation. In the last financial year, it reduced its borrowing level by more than Rs.1000 crore and overall debt has been reduced from Rs.21,000 crore in 1998-1999 to less than Rs.12,000 crore now. SAIL is also planning to exploit its full potential of the existing facilities by further enhancing its efficiencies. It has approved a project for implementation of long rails facilities at its Bhilai Steel Plant at a cost of Rs.320 crore. On completion, the scheme will enable the plant to produce 78 metre long rails and 260 metre welded rail panels. Work is also on at SAIL's Rourkela plant where the upgradation of ERW pipe plant is in progress at an investment of about Rs.90 crore. Rebuilding of the coke oven battery 1 is also in progress with the investment at Rs.120 crore. In the next five years, SAIL's emphasis will be on augmenting the concast route, energy efficiency and facilitating production of more value added items.

pr_issued_by: Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food & Public Distribution
pr_title: Shri Sharad Yadav calls upon students to make consumer awareness a mass movement
pr_content: Shri Sharad Yadav, Minister of Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution flagged off a rally of school children at Talkotra Stadium here today on the occasion of National Consumer Day. Shri Yadav asked them to spread consumer awareness in a multifarious way in every nook and corner of the country. Shri Yadav said that we should make the consumer movement a people’s movement to ensure that the consumers get the goods and services free from exploitation. He further said consumer movement is slowly but firmly emerging as a strong movement in the country as a result of various Governmental and non-governmental efforts. The programme seeks to protect the rights of the consumers in relation to the sellers of goods and services and provide the legal and administrative framework where the complaints of the consumer could be redressed at nominal cost in the consumer forums without even the help of a lawyer. The Minister said that in our country, given the scenario of economic disparity and level of education and ignorance, educating the consumers, therefore, still remains a gigantic task. This calls for concerted efforts from every one of us. Shri Yadav highlighted that the ministry has taken up a number of activities and schemes for creating consumer awareness in the country. He launched `Consumer Clubs’ in DPS Society in DPS NOIDA and Sadhu Vaswani School in New Delhi today. He urged upon the children to spread consumer awareness and fight against exploitation in trade. In order to further accelerate the consumer movement, it is imperative to educate all categories of people, specially the school children, through formal or non-formal system of education. Shri Yadav desired that every school should have a consumer club. He expressed the hope that the children can keep enhancing the consumer awareness movement according to their own initiative and dynamism so that consumer club may become a model club for the others to follow. The objectives of the scheme are to educate children about the rights of the consumers as provided in the Consumer Protection Act, 1986; to mobilize youngsters by instilling in them the spirit of protection of consumer rights; to impart knowledge about the role of the consumers in protection of their rights and to strengthen the consumer movement in the country. A Consumer Club shall be set up in a middle/high/higher secondary school which is affiliated to a Government recognised Board and shall consist of a minimum 50 members, particularly interested in the welfare and protection of consumers and willing to dedicate time and effort on a regular basis towards this end. The Department of Consumer Affairs shall provide financial support @ Rs. 10,000/- per annum per Consumer Club to the Co-ordinating Agency from the Consumer Welfare Fund, Shri Yadav informed. 24TH December was declared as National Consumer Day in the year 2000 when the historic Consumer Protection Act, 1986 received the assent of the President.

pr_title: More employment opportunities generated GROUP INSURANCE SCHEME FOR ARTISANS LAUNCHED KVIC CROSSES MILESTONE IN SALES TURNOVERSTEADY INCREASE IN EXPORT OF COIR PRODUCTS
pr_content: YEAR END REVIEW-2003 Under the Rural Employment Generation Programme (REGP) of the Ministry of Agro and Rural Industries, about 161505 projects have been financed and 1803752 job opportunities have been created upto 31.03.2003. During 2003-04 (upto September 203), cumulative projects to the tune of 5564 have been financed, generating 87060 employment opportunities in the country. The target set for the current financial year to finance 25253 projects and create 471523 additional opportunities. In view of need to generate additional employment and the successful experience of the programme so far, it has been decided to continue the programme during the 10th Plan period as well. One of the characteristics of the REGP is that with low per capita investment, it generates an additional employment opportunities for two million persons. About 361006 employment opportunities has already been created during 2002-03 and now the Government has decided to create more than 20 lakh new employment opportunities under this scheme in the country in the next four years. GROUP ISURANCE SCHEME FOR ARTISANS To provide insurance cover to khadi artisans, a Group Insurance Scheme, ‘Janashree Bima Yojna’ was launched by the Government on 15.08.2003 under which 13.90 lakh artisans are to be covered in the 10th Plan period in which 3 lakh artisans have to be covered in the current financial year of 2003-04. This scheme has been formulated by Life Insurance Corporation (LIC) with annual premium of Rs. 200/- per beneficiary. The annual premium of Rs. 200/- per beneficiary would be shared by LIC, Rs.100/- from Central Government Security Fund, Rs. 50/- by khadi institution and Rs. 25/- each by khadi artisan and KVIC/GOI. Under the insurance scheme, natural death cover of Rs. 20,000/- while in the case of death due to accident, an amount of Rs. 50,000/- would be payable to the nominee. In case of permanent disability (loss of two eyes/limbs of use) due to accident, Rs. 50,000/- is payable and in the case of partial disability Rs. 25,000/- will be paid to the beneficiary. LIC’s Shiksha Sahyog Yojana would be added benefit to the insurer under JBY without extra premium under the scheme. This benefit would provide Rs. 1200/- per annum for the education of two children of the khadi artisans from class IX to XII. About 1.16 lakh khadi artisans have already been covered so far under this scheme. KVIC CROSSES MAJOR MILESTONE Khadi and Village Industries Commission (KVIC), central agency for rural industries programme crossed a major milestone and its sales figures are above 10,000 crores during the financial year 2002-2003. As per 2002-03 annual report of KVIC, the sales turnover is 10193.34 crores, registering a growth of 14.39 per cent over previous year and the total employment in KVIC network is 66.45 lakhs with a growth of over six per cent. KVIC has generated over 18 lakhs new jobs during last five years and is targeting 25 lakhs job opportunities during Tenth Plan Period. KVIC flagship scheme – Gramodyog Rojgar Yojana (REGP) has been placed on top by the Central Government for creating new employment opportunities in the country. KVIC has identified five mission projects to sharpen the focus and concentrate on select areas of its core competence. It has also been decided to invest Rs. 2000 crores in next four years on select product-range of bio-technology related processing industries. Total investment by KVIC is likely to be around 7500 crores during Xth Plan Period and this will place KVIC in a high growth-trajectory. STEADY INCREASE IN EXPORT OF COIR PRODUCTS There has been a steady increase in export of coir and coir products both in quantity and value. During the year 2002-2003, India has exported 82634 metric tonnes coir products worth of Rs. 34512.75 lakhs compared to 71335 metric tonnes of Rs. 32058.35 lakhs during 2001-02. In order to boost export of coir and coir products, the Coir Board of the Ministry of Agro and Rural Industries has initiated several steps. Some of these are participation in exhibition/catalogue shows, product promotion programmes abroad, assistance to exporters for acquiring ISO 9000 certification etc. A new scheme ‘External Market Development Assistance’ has also been introduced effective from 2000-01 for encouraging small exporters in the coir sector. PRIME MINISTER’S ROZGAR YOZANA The Prime Minister’s Rozgar Yozana (PMRY) has been continuing in then 10th Plan with a target of 11 lakh micro enterprises and an annual target of 2.20 lakhs. The plan target for the year 2002-03 was 2.20 lakh. The target for the current year (2003-04) is 2.20 lakh. During the last three years, 5,02,302 projects have been disbursed loans by the banks under the scheme and 7.55 lakh employment opportunities are estimated to have been generated during this period.

pr_title: Several nations keen on participation in India’s Moon Mission
pr_content: A number of countries have shown keen interest in participating in India’s mission to moon “Chandrayaan-I” programme. The participation vary from taking part in experiments to utilisation of facilities and analysis of data. Russia is a major partner in the programme, with whom an MoU has already been signed. This MoU covers cooperation in space navigation system also. The latest country to express keenness in joining the programme is Israel, whose Minister for Science and Technology, Mr. Eliezer Sandberg is currently on a visit to India. The Israeli delegation is having talks with ISRO authorities in Bangalore today on cooperation with India in space technology and applications. The two sides have already taken up a joint project on the study of ultra violet science and space-astrophysics. Under the already approved 386 crore rupee Chandrayaan-I project, a lunar probe will be launched by our own PSLV in a polar orbit of about 100 km altitude around the moon, from the Satish Dhawan Space Centre in Sriharikota. This will be India’s first mission to moon devoted to high resolution remote sensing of the lunar surface features and mineral composition in visible, near infrared, low and high energy X-ray regions. This will provide Indian scientists an opportunity to study scientific aspects such as origin, features and composition of the lunar surface. The mission is planned to be achieved in five years. Follow-up planetary missions will be decided only on the progress and outcome of Chandrayaan-I. The project will help expand the horizon of our scientific knowledge, help in upgrading our technological capability in a deep space mission, covering a distance of 3.5 lakh km with precision navigation and guidance systems. This will be a useful fore-runner for our long term gains.

pr_title: Agro and Processed food products exports touch record turnover of Rs. 13827 crore AGRI EXPORTS TO AUGMENT INCOME OF FARMERS JAITLEY GIVES AWAY APEDA EXPORT AWARDS
pr_content: Agricultural and Processed food products exports from India have registered a record turnover of Rs. 13827.95 crore with an impressive growth of 35% during the year 2002-03. This was stated by Shri Arun Jaitley, Union Minister of Commerce & Industry and Law & Justice, while giving away the APEDA export awards here today. While complimenting the exporting community for their excellent performance, Shri Jaitley stressed the need to increase India’s share in the world agricultural trade, which is a mere 1.2% presently. “For that to happen, we have to push aggressively in the world market. Agri exports can and should augment the income of farmers”, he said. Shri J. Vasudevan, Secretary, Ministry of Food Processing, Shri S. N. Menon, Special Secretary, Department of Commerce and Shri K. S. Money, Chairman, APEDA were present at the function along with award winners and representatives of trade and industry. Referring to agriculture as a sensitive issue for the developing countries in the ongoing WTO negotiations, Shri Jaitley said that there was no level playing field between the farmers of developing countries and that of developed countries. “That is where the struggle of developing countries regarding agriculture is in the WTO negotiations”, he added. The Minister said that one of the challenges of globalisation was how to connect Indian farmers to the world market. “In other sectors of the economy the benefits of globalisation are increasingly being felt. India is world leader in the services sector and manufacturing sector also is picking up”, he said and added that the benefits had to reach the rural India in terms of increase in income levels so as to get the mass support for the process of economic reforms. Shri Jaitley referred to many government policies and programmes, like Prime Minister’s Gram Sadak Yojana (PMGSY) connecting 8 lakh villages through pacca roads, which would create necessary infrastructure to make agriculture sector more competitive. Shri Jaitley presented the Golden Trophy award to Allanasons Ltd. Mumbai, for excellent performance in export promotion, product safety, quality and packaging. The Silver Trophies were presented to KRBL Ltd., New Delhi, Shivnath Rai Harnarain (India) Ltd., New Delhi, PKS Ltd., New Delhi. Bronze Trophy was awarded to Satnam Overseas Ltd., New Delhi, Sunstar Overseas Ltd., New Delhi, V. K. Udyog Ltd., New Delhi. Certificates of Merit were presented to Emmsons International Ltd., New Delhi, Amira Foods (India) Ltd., New Delhi, Krishna Traders, Kolkata. Shri Money in his speech said that one integrated food law when introduced and futures trading in commodities would make India’s agriculture sector more competitive. He said that APEDA was carrying out many activities on the quality front to improve the market share of Indian agriculture products in the world market.

pr_title: Major initiatives in entertainment sector FDI ALLOWED IN NEWS AND CURRENT AFFAIRS TV CHANNELS 3rd SAARC INFORMATON MINISTERS’ CONFERENCE PRASAR BHARATI LAUNCHES NEWS CHANNEL GOA AS PERMANENT VENUE FOR FILM FESTIVAL
pr_content: YEAR END REVIEW-2003A number of major and far-reaching policy decisions, legislative measures and administrative initiatives were the highlights of the Ministry of Information and Broadcasting to meet the challenges of the fast developing media and entertainment sectors. These included, revised notification of Cable Network Act for the implementation of Conditional Access System (CAS) initially in four metro cities to protect consumers’ interest, revised guidelines for uplinking of news and current affairs TV channels from India, launching of DD News Channel by Prasar Bharati, Government’s approval for Doordarshan’s pilot project of ‘Ku-band transmission, setting up of a committee for the second phase of FM radio privatization, liberalization of visa manual for foreign producers to shoot films in India, premier of Hindi films in the International Film Festival of India-2003, Gao as permanent venue for film festival, active participation in Cannes Film Festival, Children’s Film Festival held in Hyderabad, appointing chairpersons of National Film Society of India and Central Board of Film Certification, 50th National Film Awards and hosting the 3rd SAARC Information Ministers’ Conference. INITIATIVES IN ENTERTAINMENT SECTOR The Government has taken several initiatives to bring about changes in the entertainment sector in the interest of the overall development of this sector. In order to suggest a policy framework for the entertainment industry, both at the Centre and the States, a Committee for Development of the Entertainment Sector has been set up. In the meeting which was held in the month of October 2003, the Committee has made recommendations, mainly relating to a further reduction in entertainment tax rates to 45 per cent, appointment of a nodal officer in each State for assisting in anti piracy matters and facilitating a single point clearance by State Governments for foreign film crews shooting in India. In order to bring about receptive regime in the entertainment sector, within India, a Committee has recently been set up to suggest a strategy to facilitate the flow of venture capital into the sector. FDI IN NEWS & CURRENT AFFAIRS TV CHANNELS The guidelines for uplinking of foreign news channels from India, issued on March 26, 2003, have been revised with the approval of the competent authority on August 28, 2003. The revised eligibility criteria require, inter-alia, that Foreign Direct Investment (FDI) in the applicant company shall not exceed 26 per cent of the paid-up Equity; permission will be granted only in cases where equity held by the largest Indian shareholder is at least 51 per cent of the total equity; at least 3/4th of the Directors on the Board of Directors and all key executives and editorial staff shall be resident Indians; the representations on the Board shall as far as possible be proportionate to the shareholding; and CEO of the applicant company and/or Head of the channel shall be a resident Indian. SAARC INORMATION MINISTERS’ CONFERENCE The Prime Minister Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee inaugurated the 3rd SAARC Information Ministers’ conference was held in New Delhi from November 11 to 13, 2003. During the conference, several issues including evolution of SAARC-recognized Regional Media Forum, annual conference of editors from SAARC nations, training facilities for media persons and establishing a SAARC Media Development Fund besides fostering an active media brotherhood among the SAARC nations in the fields of films, information and music were discussed at length. PRASAR BHARATI LAUNCHES NEWS CHANNEL Prasar Bharati has launched a 24 hours News Channel on 3rd November, 203 which provides free to air round the clock news, which is objective and biased, to the public so as to inform and educate them. The channel is available in both the terrestrial and satellite mode and it is the only terrestrial news channel in the country. According to Prasar Bharati, the DD News Channel in all homes and the second most watched news channel in cable and satellite homes ahead of many established news channels. CONDITIONAL ACCESS SYSTEM In order to improve the system of providing access to television channels to the consumers, a major effort to upgrade the technology was initiated. Effort was to have a smooth transition from the present system to Conditional Access System (CAS.) In the first phase only four metro cities were picked up. The system when totally introduced is expected to provide protection to the cable viewers choice to subscribe for channels of their choice only and thereby not pay for the channels which they are not interested in. GOA AS PERMANENT VENUE FOR FILM FESTIVAL The Ministry, after consultations with the Goa Government, has decided that Goa will be the permanent venue for the International Film Festival of India (IFFI). The reasons for deciding on a permanent venue were that Film Festivals are known by the cities and not be the countries where the take place and Goa is a well known all over the world. Premier of three Hindi films were introduced first time during the 34th International Film Festival of India-2003, which was held in New Delhi. The Lifetime Achievement Award was conferred upon famous the renowned Italian film actress Liv Ullaman at the festival. In order to encourage foreign film producers to shoot at Indian locations, the Ministry assured to rework on visa manual to provide a single window clearance. This would enable foreign film producers to come to India with a script and leave with the complete films in cans. For this a whole lot of post-production facilities would have to tone up.

pr_title: Vice President greets the people on the occasion of Christmams
pr_content: Vice President has greeted the people of India on the occasion of Christmas. In a message he has said “I offer my greetings to the people of India on the joyous occasion of Christmas, which celebrates the birth of Jesus Christ, one of mankind’s greatest prophets. Jesus Christ showed us the noble path of peace, love, non-violence and tolerance for realizing the kingdom of God on earth. His teachings have the power to provide spiritual solace to the humanity by lifting us all from turmoil and moral decay. Christmas reminds us of the essence of the teachings of this great apostle for the larger good of mankind.”

pr_issued_by: Ministry of Consumer Affairs, Food & Public Distribution
pr_title: Shri Sharad Yadav inaugrates 69th Annual General Meeting of the Indian Sugar Mills Association
pr_content: With a view to boosting the export of sugar from the country, the Government has constituted a Committee having members from both the apex bodies of sugar industry and leading exports of sugar. The committee is going to submit its report within 60 days. This was announced by the Minister of Consumer Affairs, Food and Public Distribution, Shri Sharad Yadav while inaugurating 69th Annual General Meeting of the Indian Sugar Mills Association here today. The Minister said to help the sugarcane growers, the Government has taken certain other steps like creation of 20 lakh tonnes of buffer stock for a period of one year w.e.f. December 18, 2002 for which the sugar factories will be reimbursed the carrying cost amounting to Rs. 412 crores from the Sugar Development Fund (SDF). In addition, an amount of Rs. 374 crores has been made available by the banks on account of this buffer stock. Thus, a total amount of Rs. 786 crores is being provided to the mills which will be exclusively utilised for payment of cane price dues of the growers. The periods of this buffer stock has further been extended for another year. This disbursement of the buffer subsidy has already started. Shri Yadav said that the Government has also announced one time assistance of Rs. 678.06 crores to the States of Uttar Pradesh, Uttaranchal, Haryana, Punjab and Bihar to clear the cane price arrears of the private sugar factories in respect of the difference between the State Advised Price (SAP) and Statutory Minimum Price of 2002-2003 sugar season by way of a soft loan to the State Governments at a concessional rate of interest of 4 per cent per annum with an initial moratorium of 3 years and repayable in 3 years thereafter. The Government has further decided to extend assistance to non SAP States by way of additional market borrowings to clear the cane price arrears of 2002-2003 sugar season. The Minister further said that due to drought in many parts of the country, the sugar production in the current season, 2003-2004 would be somewhat lower than the last season. This will to some extent help the industry in reducing the inventory cost. In order to meet the increasing demand of sugarcane which is a renewable source of energy, we must take all possible steps for increasing its production through improvement in productivity, evolution of new high yielding and high sucrose content varieties for different agro-climatic conditions, use of GM technology etc. Government will not only provide financial help from SDF but also technological input through premier technical institutions like ICAR, NSI etc. said Shri Yadav.

pr_title: India-Israel agree to widen scope of scientific cooperation
pr_content: India and Israel have agreed to expand and widen the scope of scientific and technological cooperation. This emerged at a meeting here today, between the visiting Israeli Minister for Science and Technology, Mr. Eliezer Sandberg and the Minister of State for Science and Technology, Shri Bachi Singh Rawat. Scientific secretaries and experts from both sides were present during the talks. The two ministers noted that both the sides have made considerable progress in the joint scientific programmes identified for mutual collaboration, in the last ten years. Both the sides decided that it is time to expand and widen the scientific cooperation, in view of the greater interest among the scientific communities of the two countries. It was particularly noted that cooperative activities initiated three years back in Genomics have been going on fruitfully and should be continued. It was agreed to extend the cooperation to cover fields like, Nano-technology, other areas of biotechnology, science and technology management and non-conventional energy etc. To begin with, a joint workshop is being organised in Israel on Nano-technology early next year. Both the countries have also agreed to make available adequate funds for the implementation of joint projects. During his stay here, Mr. Sandberg among others, met the former Chairman of the Indian Space Research Organisation and Member of Parliament, Dr. K. Kasturirangan and visited a few scientific institutions in New Delhi like the Indian Institute of Technology and the Institute of Genomics and integrative biology. After his visit to New Delhi, Mr. Sandberg will go to Bangalore on Wednesday, for talks with ISRO authorities on collaboration in space technology and applications.

pr_title: Arun Jaitley begins Pre-Exim Policy interactions with Trade & Industry
pr_content: Shri Arun Jaitley, Union Minister of Commerce & Industry and Law & Justice has begun the process of pre-Exim policy consultations with trade & industry bodies with first meeting held here today for obtaining inputs for the forthcoming Exim Policy (2004-05) to be announced on 31st March 2004. In a first meeting held with Federation of Indian Export Organisations (FIEO), Shri Jaitley said that new realities of the economy has to be taken into account to make the Exim policy more dynamic. “We have consciously fixed the target of 12% growth in exports this year which will take us to achieve 1% of the global trade by the year 2007”, he said. Shri L. Mansingh, Director General of Foreign Trade and Shri M Rafeeque Ahmed, President of FIEO were present at the meeting along with senior government officials, representatives of trade and industry. Shri Jaitley said that the last year had been very challenging year for India because of the hardening of rupee vis-à-vis US $ since it had made export products costlier. “These are the dynamics of the free market and we have to face and live with it”, he said and complimented the exporting community for their entrepreneurship in the times of adversity. The Minister said that the capacity to cut down costs and improving efficiency was the only way to make Indian products world-beaters. He said that despite the great challenges in the last one-year, several sectors have shown remarkable growth rates including that of services, manufacturing and agriculture. “There has been resurgence in the country’s economy as a whole and the Indian brand must ride on in the world market given the changed perception about India”, Shri Jaitley said. Replying to the suggestions made by FIEO for restoring full 80 HHC benefits, he said that he had already written to the Finance Minister about the issue and would meet again to review the situation. Shri Rafeeque Ahmed urged the Minister to give a boost to exporting units in the Domestic Tariff Area (DTA) by treating those which export more than 75% of their production at par with 100% EOUs in the matter of facilities and benefits, including Green Card etc. He also requested the Minister to advise the ECGC to settle 100% of the exporters’ claims, instead of the current 90% claims, in cases where payments are not realized from the buyer. In this way, he said, the exporters can be reassured that they would not be losing any share of the benefits associated with exports. He also made a strong plea for reduction in processing fees by banks etc., and also in withdrawal or lowering of State levies on exports so that the exporters’ transaction cost could be cut drastically. FIEO Vice President, Shri Subhash Mittal, appealed to the Minister to personally intervene on behalf of the exporters to seek some immediate remedial measures to protect exporters’ interests against the appreciating rupee. The continuing loss to exporters on account of the rising rupee, he said, could be reduced by restoring full 80-HHC benefits on export proceeds repatriation, and through allowing weighted deduction for expenditure on marketing. Besides, he said, exporters can be helped under the present circumstances by making Dollar loans at LIBOR+75 basis point easily available to them. In addition to seeking such finance-related remedies, the President of FIEO also appealed to the Commerce Minister to relax the criterion set for grant of recognition status to exporters as even many of the existing status holders could find themselves disqualified after March 2004, as a consequence of the fall in their exports due to the appreciating rupee.

pr_title: Delhi Chief Minister charges on CAS unfounded
pr_content: The attention of the Ministry of I&B has been drawn to news items in a number of daily newspapers quoting the Chief Minister of Delhi Smt. Sheila Dikshit as stating in the Delhi Assembly that rejected and inferior technology was being imported from a single foreign company and being imposed on the people of Delhi, in the process of implementation of CAS. The Chief Minister is also quoted as having told the Assembly that the Ministry of I&B does not have any plan of action and there is total confusion. The Chief Minister, according to Press reports, said the manner in which CAS was sought to be implemented had raised doubts about the motives behind the whole move. The above statements are unwarranted and do not at all represent the factual position. The technology for the manufacture of Set Top Boxes does not at present exist in India and this has been confirmed on a number of occasions by representatives of the Indian Electronic Industry in the course of meetings with officials of the Ministry of I&B. CETMA (Consumer Electronics and TV Manufacturers Association), in their last meeting with the Ministry of I&B on 11.12.2003, had confirmed that Indian industry would only be able to manufacture set top boxes if there was a guarantee of sufficient volumes, a situation that could come about if CAS is implemented in several cities. As far as the import of set top boxes is concerned, these have been imported directly by different MSOs from reputed manufacturers namely, (1) Hundon (Korea)-Siticable; (2) Humax (Korea)-Hathway; (3) Konax (Norway)-Siticable; (4) Nagravision/Hindujas, (5) C-Net (China)/Trinity (formerly the Spectranet). A team of highly qualified Engineers from BECIL (Broadcast Engineering Consultants India Limited), a Public Sector Undertaking under the Ministry of I&B, was sent to Korea to inspect the manufacturing facilities and to report on quality control measures undertaken by the manufactures. The team visited the Plant of Humax at Seoul in the fist week of July, 2003 and has confirmed that the boxes were being manufactured according to stipulated quality standards. Boxes imported into India were also subject to random checking of their technical specifications by BECIL and it has been confirmed that these meet the norms of the Bureau of Indian Standards specified for set top boxes. The Chief Minister of Delhi, Smt. Sheila Dikshit had a meeting with Minister for I&B during which It was emphasized that in the implementation of CAS, the State Government along with its machinery has to play an effective role. This position was acknowledged by the Chief Minister herself. If there are any specific complaints the nodal officers appointed by State Government like SDM/Deputy Commissioner with due corporation of I&B officers will address. It is totally incorrect to say that the Ministry of I&B has no plan of action or that it is confused about its approach. The implementation of CAS in south Delhi is an immediate consequence of the order of the Delhi High Court dated 4th December, 2003 and the Chief Minister was apprised of this fact when she met the I&B Minister on 22nd December, 2003. The Ministry of I&B is fully aware of its responsibilities in the implementation of CAS, and has in turn requested the State Governments concerned for their full co-operation.

pr_title: President, PM greet nation on Christmas
pr_content: The President Dr. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam and the Prime Minister, Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee have sent their heartiest greetings to fellow citizens on the occasion of Christmas. In his message, the President Dr. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam has said, “Christmas is a beautiful and a happy day. The day comes with the message of peace for the home, the nation and the world. Jesus Christ taught humanity about giving peace and happiness to others. Let me wish on this occasion happiness and peace to every family in the country and those living abroad.” Wishing the countrymen a Merry Christmas, the Prime Minister Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee said that the festival symbolises the values of giving and forgiving, of sacrifice, reconciliation, doing one’s best for the suffering people and their well being. May the chime of the bells bring peace, prosperity and happiness to every heart and hearth, Shri Vajpayee added.

pr_title: President Kalam’s poetic birthday greetings to poet PM
pr_content: The President Dr. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam greeted the Prime Minister Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee on the Prime Minister’s 79th birthday, at the latter’s residence today. Dr. Kalam presented Shri Vajpayee a bouquet of flowers and a greeting card with the following message, including a few lines from a poem penned by the President himself: “May I wish you a very happy birthday. I would like to dedicate on this day the following verse to you: “When guns are silent, Flowers blossom on the earth, Fragrance engulfs good souls, Who created beautiful silence.”

pr_title: UGC to be renamed ‘ Higher Education Development Commission’ Foundation for New Campus laid
pr_content: The University Grants Commission (UGC) is to be renamed as ‘ University Higher Education Development Commission’, to make it look less bureaucratic and effective instrument of top-level education. The UGC should also strive to become a role model of international standards across the globe. This was stated by the Minister for Human Resource Development Dr. Murli Manohar Joshi, at the ground-breaking(Bhoomi Pujan) ceremony of the UGC’s modern but traditional building complex near JNU here today. The 30 crore rupee new campus is scheduled to be completed within 2 years. Dr. Joshi urged the UGC to function and operate in a manner of a professionally competent and effective body contributing to the spread of quality higher education. It should be less dependant on the Government in formulating its programmes and methodologies. It is necessary to ensure that there are no impediments in the way of providing quality education based on human values, said Dr. Johsi. The Chairman, UGC Dr. Arun Nigavekar said the UGC will strive to fulfill its mandate and make it an organization of international repute. The former Education Minster Dr. Karan Singh expressed happiness that the UGC will now have a new campus and a modern auditorium. The campus is coming up on a 20 acre plot and will house all its offices which are now spread out in different locations in Delhi. It will have excellent conference facilities and a large Guest House. A Consortia for Educational Communication (Inter University Centre) will also come up under the aegis of UGC. In order to reflect Indian traditions, the campus will have a 20 metre high pillar(Stambh).

pr_title: Railways to procure most modern track recording car
pr_content: Indian Railways is in the process of procuring state-of-the-art track recording car with laser based sensors to further step up safety of train operations. The new machine is likely to be commissioned by March 2004. As of now, five modern track recording cars are in operation to record track geometry and oscillation characteristics thereby assessing riding quality of tracks. Inspection, repair and maintenance of track are carried out as per well-laid down procedure and the entire track on Indian Railway network is inspected by trained personnel everyday.

pr_title: Aluminium prodcution during November 2003
pr_content: The Aluminium production in the country during April-November, 2003 has been estimated at 5,45,684 tonnes against 4,38,120 tonnes during the same period last year. Out of total production, the public sector National Aluminium Company Limited (NALCO) has produced 1,98,026 tonnes. Bharat Aluminium Company Limited (BALCO) with 49 per cent, Central Government Equity produced 64,513 tonnes and the private sector Hindustan Aluminium Company Limited (HINDALCO) contributed 2,18,574 tonnes followed by Indian Aluminium Company Ltd. (INDAL) 43,331 tonnes and Madras Aluminium Company Limited (MALCO) 21,240 tonnes. During November 2003, the total production of Aluminium was 65,787 tonnes. NALCO exported 1,00,216 tonnes of Alumina and 9996 tonnes of Aluminium metal during the month.

pr_title: Prasad condoles the death of P.R.Azad
pr_content: The Minister of Information and Broadcasting, Shri Ravi Shankar Prasad has condoled the death of Shri Prithvi Raj Azad, a senior journalist and a special correspondent with ‘Univarta’ who passed away here this morning. In his message, Shri Prasad said that Shri Azad was always very alert and contributed immensely in the development of Hindi journalism. His death is a great loss to the media, Shri Prasad said.

pr_title: Guwahati-Okha Express named Dwarka Express
pr_content: The Ministry of Railways has issued orders naming 5635/5636 Guwahati-Okha Express as “Dwarka Express” with immediate effect. Accordingly, the General Managers of N.F.Railway and Western Railway have been instructed to ensure implementation.

pr_title: Jaitley approves 26 cases of foreign technology collaboration
pr_content: Shri Arun Jaitley, Commerce & Industry Minister has approved 26 cases of foreign technology collaboration/franchise agreements and 4 cases for grant of Industrial Licence. The Project Approval Board and Licensing Committee in the meeting held on 18.12.2003 under the Chairmanship of Shri Lakshmi Chand, Secretary, Department of Industrial Policy & Promotion, had recommended these cases for approval. Hotel & Tourism industry with 11 proposals accounts for the largest share of the approved foreign collaborations followed by Transport Industry with 6 proposals and Oil refinery/Petroleum products with 4 proposals. The approved proposals from the Hotel & Tourism Industry include 4 proposals of the group companies of the EIH Ltd for Franchise and Marketing Support agreement with M/s. Hilton International, USA. The approved proposals in the transport sector include the proposal of M/s. Hero Honda Motors for transfer of technology from M/s. Honda Motor, Japan for a new two wheeler model. The proposal of M/s. Toyota Kirlosker Auto Parts Pvt. Ltd. for technical assistance from M/s. Toyota Motor Corporation, Japan and M/s. Aisin Takaoka Co., Japan for the manufacture of Axles and Propeller Shafts for the proposed new model multi purpose vehicle to be manufactured by M/s. Toyota Kirlosker Motor Pvt. Ltd. has also been approved. Government has also approved three proposals of M/s. Kalyani Brakes Ltd. for transfer of technology for the manufacture of Load Sensing Proportioning Valve and Passenger Car Braking systems and parts from M/s. Bosch Automotive Systems Corporation, Japan and M/s. Robert Bosch GmbH, Germany. The four proposals approved for grant of Industrial Licence are from textiles, explosives and pharmaceutical sectors. The detailed list of cases approved now is available on the website of the Department of Industrial Policy & Promotion viz., http://dipp.nic.in. Since April 2003, a total 136 foreign technology collaboration/franchise agreement proposals and 75 proposals on industrial licensing have been approved by the Government during the current calendar year.

pr_title: Defence Minister George Fernandes visits Tawang, Bhuj Siachen Glacier, distributes Christmas cake
pr_content: The Defence Minister, Shri George Fernandes, today distributed Christmas cake to jawans and airmen at Bhuj. Earlier he left Leh for Bhuj in the morning and did an aerial recce of Rann and Creek and met the troops at Bawarle Bet. Mr Fernandes reached Jodhpur in the evening and distributed the cake to the airmen. Yesterday the Defence Minister visited Ladakh Scouts Battalion and later went to the forward posts in the Siachen Glacier where jawans keep vigil in sub-zero temperatures. He met the jawans and distributed the cake. On Dec 24th Mr George Fernandes went to Arunachal Pradesh and met the jawans at Lumpo outpost in Zimithang sector which overlooks the Line of Actual Control along the India-China Border. He also visited the district headquarters at Tawang and distributed Christmas cake to the jawans of the posted there. He also placed a wreath at the war memorial raised in honour of 2420 officers and jawans who laid down their lives during the India-China conflict in 1962. Today after visiting the Rann of Kutch the Defence Minister will proceed to Rajasthan Sector where he will meet the jawans posted in the desert outpost. He will meet the jawans at Jodhpur, Lathi, Jalipa, Uttarlai and return to Delhi on Dec 27th 2003. During the four-day visit, Shri George Fernandes will distribute 45,000 pieces of cake (weighing 4.5 tonnes) to the jawans and officers and airmen of the Indian Air Force in the forward airfields. The Christmas cake has been donated by Canadians of Indian origin and was made by Koshy bakery in Bangalore. In his interaction with jawans Shri George Fernandes said that their welfare was uppermost in the minds of the people. The Government was making all efforts to modernize the Armed Forces and take steps to improve the welfare measures for the jawans and their families. The Defence Minister said that the prospects for peace looked brighter this year. During the visits to China of the Prime Minister and himself, the Chinese have expressed a desire to improve cooperation with India and strengthen their age-old friendship with us. In the western sector, the Prime Minister's 12-point goodwill gesture has had good response. Guns have fallen silent on the Line of Control and the International border along Jammu and Kashmir. He hoped that infiltration from across the border will also stop and there will be an end to militancy. The formation commanders at the different locations briefed the Defence Minister about the security situation in their respective sectors.

pr_title: Year-end Review of the Labour Ministry
pr_content: YEAR-END REVIEW<U+F0B7> 39th Session of the Indian Labour Conference was held on 16-18 October 2003 under the chairmanship of Union Labour Minister. PM inaugurated the Indian Labour Conference on 16th October 2003. The conference unanimously recommended the need for umbrella legislation on unorganized workers <U+F0B7> Government approved continuation and expansion of the scheme of National Child Labour Project (NCLP) during the Tenth Plan Period. The opening of additional 50 NCLPs selected for the plan period, has been approved by the Government. A budget provision of Rs.602 crore has been provided for NCLPs in the 10th plan. <U+F0B7> Govt. suggested the ILO to set up an International Skill Development Fund, Dr. Sahib Singh made this suggestion to Mr. Juan Somavia, DG ILO for setting up this fund with active assistance from developed world for eradicating poverty. He added that the fund was needed for giving the poor an access to training opportunities at affordable costs. The Minister also apprised Dr. Somavia on the need for enhanced representation for developing countries in the apex labour organization. <U+F0B7> The President launched nationally unique Social Security Number on 25th February 2003 under “Re-inventing EPF India” project. The system will centralize registry and record keeping for the whole country at one centralized locations close to the members. The programme envisages goals which will guarantee “anytime anywhere” service from any EPF location to any member regardless of where the member works, where he is registered. The programme also seeks to establish a turn around time in claim settlement to within 2-3 days. <U+F0B7> The Employee State Insurance Corporation is taking over one hospital in each State to be run as a model hospital which, in effect, will lay down the bench-mark for running an ESI hospital. The process is nearly complete except in one or two States. <U+F0B7> An Expert Group was constituted under the chairmanship of Dr. B.N. Gupta, Ex-Director, Netaji Subash Institute of Technology, New Delhi to go into the network of the present vocational skill development system and to suggest employable courses, revised space and power norms to make vocational training cost effective. The recommendations of the Expert Group were placed before newly constituted NCVT. <U+F0B7> 37 Shramik received awards for 2001 on 25.4.2003. Ms. Kommu Ujjwala of Defence Research and Development Laboratory received the Shram Devi Award, while Shri Wali Mohamad Bhat, a blind worker, was awarded Shram Shree. No Shram Ratna was awarded. In lieu of Shram Ratna Award, Shram Bhushan was awarded. <U+F0B7> The Cabinet, in its meeting held on 4.3.2003 approved a proposal for rectification of the anomalies in the wage structure of journalists recommended by the Manisana Wage Boards set up under the Working Journalists & Other newspaper Employees (Conditions of Service) and Miscellaneous Provisions Act, 1955. <U+F0B7> The Union Cabinet in its meeting held on 4th March, 2003, approved ratification of Protocol of 1990 to the ILO Night Work (Women) Convention (Revised), 1948 to provide flexibility in the matter of employment of women during night and related amendment to the Factories Act, 1948 with adequate safeguards for their safety, dignity, honour and transportation from the factory premises to the nearest point of their residence. <U+F0B7> Foundation stone of the building for the Regional Labour Institute at Faridabad was laid by Hon’ble Union Labour Minister on 19th May 2003. This institute, conceived as a center for excellence will be comparable for such institutes in other industrially developed countries. <U+F0B7> The Vishwakarma Rashtriya Puraskars and National Safety Awards are given to workers/managements of factories, industries and docks in recognition of their achievements, safety performance and accident prevention initiatives. The awardees for the years 2001 & 2002 have been selected by a committee constituted for this purpose.

pr_title: Consumer Price Index for Urban non-manual Employees for November 2003 (BASE 1984-85=100)
pr_content: The All-India Consumer Price Index for Urban Non-Manual Employees [CPI(UNME)], on base 1984-85=100, for the month of November 2003 has been released by the Central Statistical Organisation (CSO), Ministry of Statistics and Programme Implementation; together with the indices for 59 selected urban centres in India. The All-India CPI (UNME) for November 2003 is 422, which is 1 point less than the index for the month of October 2003. At the major group level, the index in November 2003 when compared to last month that is October 2003 has decreased by 0.48% in the case of "Food, Beverages and Tobacco". At the sub-group level, the index for "Vegetables" has decreased by 6.74%. With the corresponding All-India index for November 2002 being 408, the index for the month of November 2003 has shown a rise of 3.4 % over a year. The average index for the period April 2003 to November 2003 works out to 419, which is higher by 3.7% over the average index of 404 for the corresponding period of the previous year. Statement-1 gives the CPI (UNME) for All-India, and 59 selected urban centres in the country, for November 2003; together with the indices for the preceding five months. The CPI (UNME) for November, 2003 in respect of four metropolitan cities of India, together with the corresponding indices for the previous month and also for November, 2002 are given below:- City November, 2002 October, 2003 November, 2003 Kolkata 365 387 387 Chennai 488 501 503 Delhi 416 430 426 Mumbai 407 416 417 Statement-2 gives a comparison of CPI(UNME) for November, 2003 in respect of 59 selected urban centres, with the indices for the corresponding month of last year, namely November, 2002. Percentage change in the index is shown in the last column. From the statement, it may be noted that the variation in the index for various centres ranges from -0.7 to 10.4%; with the largest increase being in the case of Chandigarh and the least in the case of Kurnool. The increases are less than 0.0 for 1 centre, 0.0 to 2.0% for 13 centres, 2.1 to 4.0% for 25 centres, 4.1 to 6.0% for 17 centres, 6.1 to 8.0% for 2 centres and more than 8.1% for 1 centre. As many as 29 centres have lower annual percentage increase as compared to that of the All-India figure of 3.4% while 29 centres have recorded a higher percentage increase as compared to the All-India average, whereas 1 centre has recorded the same percentage increase as that of All India average. pr_title: Railways to replace over-aged locos to further step up safety
pr_content: Indian Railways will be replacing 1070 over-aged diesel and electric locomotives with modern locos having enhanced safety features in the coming ten years. During the first five years of the Ten-Year Corporate Safety Plan (2003-2013) 450 diesel and 100 electric locos will be replaced, and the remaining in the second phase. Replacement of over-aged locos within a stipulated time-frame is one of the action plans envisaged in the Corporate Safety Plan, which came into effect in August 2003.

pr_title: Ministry of Rural Development-Year End Review -2003
pr_content: Year End Review -2003The year 2003 marked the launching of ‘Hariyali’ with the objective of empowering Panchayati Raj Institutions both financially and administratively in the implementation of watershed development programme in the country. The Ministry of Rural Development has instituted annual awards for Best Performing Panchayats. On promoting rural sanitation Ministry has launched ‘Nirmal Gram Puraskar’. Along with this Vigilance and Monitoring Committees have been reconstituted with greater involvement of Members of Parliament. WASTELANDS DEVELOPMENT A new initiative ‘Hariyali’ was launched in January 2003 for watershed programmes being implemented through Panchayati Raj Institutions. Under this initiative, all ongoing area development programmes namely, Integrated Wastelands Development Programme (IWDP), Drought Prone Areas Programme (DPAP) and Desert Development Programme (DDP) will be implemented through Panchayati Raj Institutions w.e.f. April 2003. The budget provision for the Department of Land Resources which was about Rs.300 crore in 1997-2000 was enhanced to Rs. 900 crore in the last two years (2000-2002). It has further been enhanced to Rs.1,050 crore for the year 2003-04. During the current year, the Ministry has sanctioned 2535 new watershed projects under DPAP, 1630 new watershed projects under DDP and 1094 watershed projects under IWDP with the total cost of Rs. 1577.70 crore for implementation as per provisions of the guidelines for ‘Hariyali’. RURAL DRINKING WATER A new initiative named as Swajaldhara was launched by the Prime Minister on December 25, 2002 for providing of drinking water to all the villages in the shortest possible time at minimum cost. Under the scheme, 10 per cent of the cost of the project would be contributed by the villagers while the remaining 90 per cent would be borne by the Union Government. In case of villages /Panchayats where SC/ST population is at least 50 percent of the total population, the contribution of the community will be five percent. The Swajaldhara programme is an extension of reform initiative in rural drinking water supply where the community will plan, implement, operate, maintain and manage the asset. The Ministry has been mandated to make provision of safe drinking water to all habitations by 2004. Under Accelerated Rural Water Supply Programme (ARWSP), the budgetary support has been increased from Rs.1,960 crore in 2000-01 to Rs. 2535 crore in 2003-04, which is more than 40 per cent increase over 1998-99. Out of the total number of 14.22 lakh rural habitations in the country, almost 93.74 per cent rural habitations are fully covered with drinking water facility, about 5.52 per cent habitations are partially covered and only about 10,489 habitations are not covered. As per the announcement made by the Prime Minister in his Independence Day address to the nation on August 15, 2002, three programmes viz (I) installation of one lakh hand pumps, (ii) providing drinking water facility to one lakh rural primary schools, and (iii) revival of one lakh traditional sources of water have been launched. The schemes will be completed in two years 2003-2004 and 2004-2005. SAMPOORNA GRAMEEN ROZGAR YOJANA (SGRY) Gainful employment, food security and strengthening of infrastructure in rural areas is a must for national renewal for a resurgent India. The Prime Minister launched an ambitious scheme on September 25, 2001 to provide additional employment in rural areas under the Sampoorna Grameen Rozgar Yojana (SGRY) with an annual outlay of Rs.10,000 crore. During the year 2003-2004, an amount of Rs. 2661.55 crore were released and 45 lakh tonne foodgrains have been allocated. Around 2775.72 lakh mandays have been generated so far. Special component of the SGRY replaces Food for Work programme w.e.f. April 1, 2002. Under special component of the SGRY, 49.14 lakh tonnes of foodgrains has been released to drought-affected states/districts and 1188.14 lakh mandays have been generated so far. PRADHAN MANTRI GRAM SADAK YOJANA (PMGSY) Rural roads are vital to economic growth and poverty alleviation in rural areas. The Prime Minister launched the Pradhan Mantri Gram Sadak Yojana (PMGSY) on December 25, 2000, with the objective of providing road connectivity through good all-weather roads to all unconnected habitations having a population of more than 1,000 persons by the year 2003 and those with a population of more than 500 persons by the end of the Tenth Plan period (2007). An investment of about Rs.60,000 crore is envisaged. The scheme entails connecting about 1.6 lakh habitations in addition to the existing rural roads. During 2001-02 and 2002-03 (Phase II) of the Scheme, an amount of Rs.4616.69 crore was released to the States/Uts. During Phase III of the Scheme, i.e. 2003-2004, an amount of Rs.477.89 crore has been released. The number of road works completed so far (upto September, 2003) during the first two phases of the Scheme is 16,760. SWARNJAYANTI GRAM SWAROZGAR YOJANA (SGSY) The Swarnjayanti Gram Swarozgar Yojana (SGSY) is a holistic self-employment programme launched during the year 1999-2000. The SGSY aims at bringing all assisted swarozgari (beneficiary) above the poverty line by providing them income generating assets through a mix of bank credit and government subsidy. A total of 18,15,590 Self-Help Groups (SHGs) have been formed since inception. During this year, 12573 Groups have taken up economic activities and a total of 64,665 swarozgaris assisted so far. The total investment upto September, 2003 is Rs. 415.30 crore which includes Rs.146.29 crore as subsidy and Rs. 269.01 crore credit from Banks. SARAS is being organized coinciding with India International Trade Fair in Pragati Maidan, New Delhi to improve and develop marketing linkages of the SGSY products. 1200 participants from 27 States/ UTs, 90 Non-Governmental Organisations and all 7 Zonal Cultural Centres will take participated in Saras 2003. Total cumulative sale was Rs. 3.45 crore for this event. RURAL HOUSING Shelter is one of the basic requirement for human survival, which needs to be met on a priority basis. ‘Housing for All’ is the goal. Efforts are being made to end the shelterlessness by the end of the Tenth Plan period. During 2003-2004, the Central allocation under Indira Awaas Yojana (IAY)/Credit-cum-Subsidy Scheme for Rural Housing (CCSS)/ Samagra Awaas Yojana (SAY) is Rs. 1870.50 crore for construction/upgradation of 14,84,554 houses. During the current financial year, an amount of Rs. 994.96 crore has been released under the Scheme so far. RURAL SANITATION PROGRAMME A Total Sanitation Campaign has been launched in 1999 to suit district specific requirements. The campaign is now being implemented in 374 districts with an outlay of Rs. 3604.82 crore. Under the Total Sanitation Campaign, 44.33 lakh individual household toilets, 1817 sanitary complexes for women, 47,825 toilets for schools and 5,429 Balwadi toilets have been constructed so far. In order to emphasise on promoting rural sanitation and involving all the stake holders, Ministry of Rural Development has launched ‘Nirmal Gram Puraskar’. Under the scheme, Panchayati Raj Institutions who are successful in eliminating the practice of open defecation will be rewarded. EMPOWERING THE PANCHAYATI RAJ INSTITUTIONS Panchayats have been recognised as the backbone for the development of Indian villages. To mark the celebration of ten years since the passing of the Constitution (73rd Amendment Act), Ministry has instituted annual awards for Best Performing Panchayats. The award will be given to 6 District Panchayats, 12 Intermediate Panchayats and 50 Gram Panchayats. A national consensus is being developed to devolve more powers amongst the Panchayati Raj Institutions so as to make them vibrant local bodies at the grassroots level. MONITORING The Ministry of Rural Development has reconstituted Vigilance and Monitoring Committees at the State/Districts Levels with greater involvement of Members of Parliament. These Committees monitor the implementation of the programmes and introduce greater transparency in the same. These Committees also include MLAs, elected representatives of PRIs, and reputed Non-Government Organisation (NGOs), etc. The Ministry conducts the Below Poverty Line (BPL) census in the rural areas of the country in the beginning of the each plan period, through the State/UT administration for identification of persons living below the poverty line for targeting them under the poverty alleviation programmes. BPL census 2002 for the Tenth Plan has been initiated in all rural areas of the country. RURAL DEVELOPMENT FELLOWSHIPS IN JOURNALISM The Ministry has instituted the "Pandit Deen Dayal Upadhaya Fellowship for Journalism in Rural Development" from 2003-2004 mainly to sensitise media persons about issues relating to Rural Development. These Fellowships are of two kinds : (I) One year Long Term Fellowships to one person each in Hindi and English; (ii) Ten six months Short Term Fellowship to one person each in the languages of Assamese, Bengali, Gujarati, Kannada, Marathi, Malayalam, Oriya, Punjabi, Tamil and Telgu. Besides a short Term Fellowship in Photo-Journalism has also been instituted. NATIONAL CONFERENCE OF PROJECT DIRECTORS OF DRDAs 2003 The Ministry organised a Conference of Chief Executive Officers of Zilla Parishads/Project Directors of District Rural Development Agencies (DRDAs) on October 9-10, 2003, with the objective to provide a platform for interaction, sharing of experiences and orientation on the rural development programmes to make the programme implementation and delivery of benefits more effective and result oriented.

pr_title: Madhya Pradesh gets fund for providing safe drinking water
pr_content: Ministry of Rural Developlment has released an amount of Rs. 1520.10 lakh to the State Government of Madhya Pradesh. The amount would be spent for providing safe drinking water to 411 problem habitation on control of fluorosis in the Jhabua district during 2003-2004. This is the fourth instalment against the total approved cost of Rs. 4504 lakh under Sub-Mission Project during the 2003-2004. Sub-Mission programmes of the Government of India were launched with the objective to provide safe drinking water facilities in rural habitations affected by water quality problems like fluorosis, arsenic, brackishness, excess iron, nitrate, etc. The States undertake these projects.

pr_title: New Science Policy, Saras, fast breeder reactor, mission to moon, anti venom serum from egg etc. Some of the highlights
pr_content: YEAR ENDER 2003 - SCIENCE AND TECHNOLOGY <U+F0D8> The new Science & Technology Policy –2003 was unveiled at the Indian Science Congress in Bangalore. It provides the much-needed boost to scientific growth and research. <U+F0D8> Indo-US Science Forum takes up joint research in hydrogen energy and fuel cells, as alternative sources of energy. <U+F0D8> The India Meteorological Centre, New Delhi now serves as a global Regional Centre for climate change study. This is because of the readily available infrastructure and expertise here. <U+F0D8> ‘SARAS’, 14-seater light-transport aircraft poised for first test-flight shortly. It was unveiled (Roll-out) at the Air show in Bangalore. <U+F0D8> The National Innovation Foundation set up to encourage and support grass-root inventions crossed 40,000 applicants this year. <U+F0D8> India’s contribution in a ten-nation international effort to sequence rice genome secures worldwide acclaim. The draft sequence of the rice genome is now complete. <U+F0D8> Genetically modified Bt cotton introduced. commercial production highly successful. <U+F0D8> Eight more nuclear power reactors under various stages of construction. This is the largest number of reactors coming up at a given time in the world. These will add 3960 MW power capacity to the national grid. <U+F0D8> Government gives nod for the first 500 MW prototype fast breeder reactor at Kalpakkam. The reactor is the first of its kind in the world that uses plutonium-uranium mixed carbide fuel. In Fast Breeder Reactors the utilisation of nuclear fuel is very optimal. <U+F0D8> The Bhabha Atomic Research Centre (BARC) has developed an advanced heavy water reactor to tap India’s vast thorium resources, the largest in the world. <U+F0D8> The performance of India’s nuclear power plants achieves a new record. The average capacity factor has crossed 90 percent. Kakrapar-1 has achieved the distinction of world’s best performing Pressurised Heavy Water Reactor on the basis of its gross capacity utilisation factor of 98.4 percent. <U+F0D8> A 25-year Space Vision unveiled. Having already achieved self-sufficiency in the fabrication of satellites, India is now nearing full self-reliance in launching capabilities. <U+F0D8> The indigenous cryogenic engine undergoing successful trials at the Liquid Propulsion Centre, Mahendragiri in Tamil Nadu would be ready by 2005. This will help make GSLV operational and replace in Russian supplied cryogenic upper stage. <U+F0D8> The EDUSAT, exclusive satellite for enhancing the literacy level, is programmed for launch by the indigenously built GSLV from our own soil during 2005-06. <U+F0D8> INSAT-3A and INSAT 3E operational. 9 satellites 6 launch vehicle missions are programmed in the coming two years. <U+F0D8> The GSLV (Geosynchronous Satellite Launch Vehicle) has undergone successfully the second developmental flight. When fully commissioned it will launch INSATs from our soil. <U+F0D8> India is currently in the process of developing advanced remote sensing satellites. This is for applications in land and water resources management, large-scale mapping operations and ocean and meteorological services. <U+F0D8> ‘Chandrayaan’ an un-manned mission to moon has been cleared by the Government at a cost of Rs. 386 crore. The mission to be accomplished by 2008. <U+F0D8> A vision document on Ocean Development 2015 aims at socio-economic benefits to the coastal population on a sustainable basis. <U+F0D8> A preparation known as “Wonder Drug” for the treatment of Systemic Mycosis and Kala-Azar, has now been commercialised. The wonder drug Liposomal Amphotericin-B is available in the market under the brand name “Fungisome”. This is much superior to the imported one and costs one tenth. <U+F0D8> CSIR diamond jubilee technology award of Rs. 10 lakh instituted for successful development of indigenous technology and its commercialisation. <U+F0D8> Anti-venom serum from egg to hit the market soon. Tie up with industry underway. Longer studies on toxicity already taken up to ensure efficacy. Another significant aspect of this great discovery is that larger animals like horse will now be spared of painful experiences at the lab. <U+F0D8> A new programme “Nano-Materials Science and Technology Initiative” launched to promote research and development in this frontier area of science. Rs. 100 crore has been earmarked for this in the 10th Plan. <U+F0D8> India has developed a hybrid poppy plant and patented in the United States. The variety named “Rakshit” has been developed from disease resistant and high yielding genotypes. It has shown high resistance to downy mildew and is moderately resistant to damping off and collar rot. Its straw is an additional source of morphine. <U+F0D8> Bioprospecting of biological wealth and landscape biodiversity characterisation through remote sensing completed for North East, Western Ghats and North West Himalayas. The Government has allowed commercial production of transgenic Bt cotton. <U+F0D8> The National Project on Drugs from Sea has made considerable progress with promising leads relating to development of Anti-Diabetic, Anti-Diahorreal, Anti-Cholestrol, Larvicidal and Anti-Anxiety drugs. Toxicity studies on monkeys are underway. <U+F0D8> Satellite based Air Traffic Management Services for the Indian Airspace in the offing. The Indian Space Research Organisation in coordination with the Airports Authority of India is working on a Technology Demonstration Project for this. <U+F0D8> As a spin-off effect, the BARC has developed a domestic water purifier. Already commercialised, it provides bacteria-free, clean drinking water, when attached to the tap. <U+F0D8> India supplied so far 1000 super conducting magnets to CERN i.e. the European organisation for Nuclear Research for the Large Hadron Collider project. India is one of the five non-European countries to join the LHC project for discovering new particles.

pr_title: Five new General Managers appointed in Railways
pr_content: Shri R R Bhandari, Secretary Railway Board has been appointed as General Manager, South Eastern Railway, Kolkata on superannuation of Shri V.N.Garg and Shri S.R. Chowdhuri, Additional Member (Works), Railway Board will be the new General Manager, East Coast Railway, Bhubaneswar. Shri M.Z. Ansari, Additional Member (Mechanical Engineering) has been appointed as General Manager, Western Railway, Mumbai and Shri Shyam Kumar, Additional Member (Civil Engineering), Railway Board will be taking over as General Manager, Eastern Railway, Kolkata. Shri S.B. Ghosh Dastidar, at present working as Additional Member (Traffic), Railway Board has been appointed as the new General Manager, Central Railway, Mumbai.

pr_title: Initiatives for planned development 13 STATES SIGN MoA FOR URBAN REFORMS DELHI METRO ON SCHEDULE VAMBAY REVAMPED
pr_content: YEAR END REVIEW – Ministry of Urban Development & Poverty Alleviation The urban population of the country has increased from 25.7% in 1991 to 27.8% in 2001. As such the stress of Urban Development & Poverty Alleviation Ministry during the year was on planned development and urban reforms. Delhi Development Authority (DDA) Ministry issued broad guidelines to DDA for formulating a draft Master Plan 2021 for Delhi. Thrust areas of the Master Plan being private participation in planning, intensification of land use, redensification in old areas, higher FAR, more green coverage for better environment, an efficient and integrated mass transport system and preservation of heritage areas. Guidelines also aim at enabling farmers to have a share in the benefit of urbanization by streamlining the process of acquisition, development & disposal of land. Government allowed certain additions/alterations in the DDA flats meeting longstanding demand of the residents. Conversion of leasehold land tenure in Delhi into freehold, which was applicable to residential properties only, was extended to industrial, commercial and mixed land use properties. DDA floated five new housing schemes during the year and allotted 3768 flats and about 4000 plots. Delhi Metro The progress of world class Delhi Metro system continued on schedule with two sections already running. While the first section between Shahdara and Tis Hazari (8.3Kms) was inaugurated in December last, the second between Tis Hazari – Inder Lok (earlier Trinagar) , covering a distance of 4.7 km. was inaugurated by the Prime Minister Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee on 3rd October,2003. This section is equipped with state of the art signaling and Automatic Train Protection (ATP) system. Tis Hazari –Inder Lok section will be followed by commissioning of Inder Lok-Rithala (8.5Km)section in March,2004. Deputy Prime Minister Shri L.K. Advani laid the foundation stone of Barakhamba Road – Dwarka line (22.8Km) on 3rd June 2003 which is expected to be completed by September 2005. First phase of the metro system aggregating to a total length of 62.1 km is expected to carry 2.2 million commuters in the year 2005. About 80 thousand passengers are already using Delhi Metro on Shahdara – Tis Hazari –Inder Lok section daily. Urban Reforms In order to deal with ever growing urban problems, an Urban Reforms Incentive Fund (URIF) with an initial outlay of Rs. 500 crore has been set up to provide reforms linked assistance to the States. 13 States and 3 Union Territories have so far signed a Memorandum of Agreement with the Centre for availing assistance under URIF. The seven reform areas covered by URIF include rationalization of stamp duty, revision of municipal laws in line with a model legislation prepared by the Ministry, reform of Rent Control Laws and repeal of Urban Land Ceiling Act. Housing and Employment Schemes Two Million Housing Programme HUDCO sanctioned 873047 housing units, Housing Cooperatives 73,461 units, Housing Finance Institutions 2,59,772 units and public sector Banks 3,77,319 units during the year 2002-2003, under this programme. Valmiki Ambedkar Awas Yojana (VAMBAY)designed to provide shelter and toilet facilities to economically weaker sections and slum dwellers has been reviewed for suitable restructuring. States have been asked to constitute State level coordination committees for effective implementation of the scheme. An amount of Rs. 26,500 crore was allocated during the year to the States under the Valmiki Ambedkar Awas Yojana (VAMBAY). So far, 41,502 housing and 11,837 toilet units have been completed under the scheme. Housing Ministers Conference A conference of Housing Ministers and Housing Secretaries of States was organized on 7th October 2003 to discuss various housing issues and schemes and to suggest measures for boosting housing activities in the country. Housing for Govt. Employees Directorate of Estates allotted 514 (200Type V and 314 Type IV special) general pool residential houses to central government servants. Houses have been constructed by CPWD at a project cost of Rs. 55 crores. Reduction in rate of interest on housing loans HUDCO reduced rate of interest on housing loans by 1.25% during the year. Interest rates on House Building Advance for government employees were also reduced by one percent. Swarna Jayanti Shahari Rozgar Yojana (SJSRY) 4.72 lakh beneficiaries have so far been assisted for setting up micro enterprises and 4.81 lakh persons provided training in various skills under this scheme.

pr_title: Steel Sector in 2003
pr_content: Year-End ReviewThe Indian Iron and Steel Industry, during the year 2003, has touched a new high both in terms of profitability and value for investment. With emerging buoyancy in the steel market, both public and private sector units have increased their profits. The total production of finished steel during January-November, 2003 has been provisionally estimated at 31.911 million tonnes as against 29.076 million tonnes during January-November 2002 showing increase of about 9.75 per cent. Pig iron production during this period was about 4.921 million tonnes as against 4.336 million tonnes during the same period last year showing an increase of 13.49 per cent. The availability of finished steel during the period has been 27.011 million tonnes as compared to the figures of 25.749 million tonnes for the same period last year showing an increase of 4.9 per cent. The apparent consumption of finished steel during the year has been 27.326 million tonnes against 25.868 million tonnes during the last year recording a growth of 5.63 per cent. The industry has been successful in diversifying the export distributions to new areas in Asia, Africa and Middle East. Steel Authority of India Limited (SAIL), this year has geared up to achieve all-time best production levels. The upward trend in almost all performance parameters of the company indicates the inner strength to achieve a turnaround at the end of this fiscal. It achieved highest ever production of saleable steel in 2002-03 with production level crossing 10 million tonne mark for the first time. During April-November, 2003 saleable steel production (including IISCO) was 73.3 lakh tonne as against 67.9 lakh tonne in the corresponding period last year with an improvement of 8 per cent. It recorded a 15 per cent rise in sales during the months of October and November 2003. During the year, there has been a steady increase in demand for SAIL's product, in both long and flat product categories. The Steel Ministry has planned to meet the increasing needs of iron ore by the major steel companies by 2012. Accordingly, the SAIL will develop two large iron ore mines to produce 10-11 million tonnes of ore per annum at Chiria in Jharkhand and Rowghat in Chhattisgarh to meet its internal requirements. Rashtriya Ispat Nigam Limited (RNIL) will also add to its captive mines. Visakhapatnam Steel Plant (VSP), another public sector unit which staged a turnaround last year, during April-November, 2003, has achieved a record sales turnover of Rs.3541 crore and earned a profit of more than Rs.500 crore. In many fields the plant has shown an excellent performance. Public sector National Mineral Development Corporation (NMDC) earned a net profit of Rs.245.87 (before tax) during this period against a target of Rs.202.38 crore. It produced 105.75 lakh tonnes of iron ore and 39,600 carrots of diamond during this period achieving 92 and 73 per cent of the target respectively, and sold nearly 122.34 lakh tonnes of iron ore and 51,334 carrots of diamond. It ranked among top ten public sector enterprises of the country. Deputy Prime Minister, Shri L.K. Advani laid the foundation stone of the world's first commercial Romelt plant at Nagarnar in Chhattisgarh on September 23, 2003. The plant, being set up by Romelt-SAIL (India) Limited (RSIL) for its client NMDC, is scheduled to be commissioned in about two years time. Manganese Ore (India) Limited (MOIL), the single largest producer of high grade manganese ore in the country achieved a sales turnover of Rs.134.46 crore during the period and earned net profit of Rs.15.44 crore. Metals Scrap Trading Corporation (MSTC) has earned a net profit of Rs.9.71 crore during this period while its subsidiary Ferro Scrap Nigam Limited earned a profit after tax of Rs.1.99 crore during the same period. Public sector Bharat Refactories Limited (BRL) has registered cash profit of Rs.173.68 lakh till November, 2003. The company is expected to close the year with net profit for the first time. The production of the company during April-November, 2003 has increased to 38,299 tonnes from 21,119 tonnes during the same period last year with a growth of more than 81 per cent.
