pr_title: Lt Gen Ranjit Singh is new Director General Border Roads
pr_content: Lieutenant General Ranjit Singh takes over the reins of the Border Roads Organisation from Lieutenant General Prakash Suri who retires today. Lieutenant General Ranjit Singh after his initial training at National Defence Academy, Khadakwasla was commissioned in the Corps of Engineers on 25 Dec 1965. In his 38 years of illustrious service in the Army, the General Officer has held varied command and staff appointments. These include the command of an Armoured Engineer Regiment, Chief Engineer of Project Dantak of the Border Roads Organisation, Chief Engineer of Eastern Army Command and Director General Works in the Engineer-in-Chief’s Branch, Army Headquarters. An Alumni of Defence Services Staff College, Wellington, the General Officer has attended Higher Command Course at Army War College, Mhow and National Defence College at New Delhi.

pr_title: Lt Gen Prakash Suri Director General Border Roads retires
pr_content: Lt Gen Prakash Suri, Director General Border Roads retires today, after rendering over 40 years of distinguished meritorious service in the Army. During his long and illustrious career, he effectively held many challenging and prestigious appointments in various Command and Staff streams. The General Officer will be best remembered for his outstanding contribution to the Border Roads Organization, as its Director General. With his visionary zeal, the General guided this elite Organization in fulfilling its objectives and becoming the Nation’s most reputed, dependable and modern construction organization. Under his tutelage, Border Roads Organization achieved all targets, through skillful, effective and efficient employment of its resources. The two outstanding achievements during his Command were the inauguration of Rohtang tunnel project works by Hon’ble Prime Minister on May 26, 2002 and completion of preliminary recce for the construction of a 220 kms long road in Afghanistan. The welfare of the rank and file of the Border Roads Organisation were of utmost concern to him. The General Officer was awarded Param Vishisht Seva Medal in recognisition of his distinguished services to the Nation. He was also honoured by the Indian Institute of Engineers (India) Delhi State Centre for his dedicated service to the Armed Forces, the Border Roads Organization and Nation. Over the last two years and three months in Command, Lieutenant General Prakash Suri ensured a concentrated and dedicated effort, to improve the quality of life of BRO employees and the Casually Paid Labour Force. He was ably supported by his wife, Mrs Kamlesh Suri, who with her vision and untiring effort rendered valuable service to the Border Roads Wives Welfare Association.

pr_title: India emerges key player in WTO
pr_content: The year 2003 witnessed the emergence of India as a key player in the World Trade Organisation (WTO) at the Cancun Ministerial Conference. Shri Arun Jaitley, Union Minister of Commerce & Industry, who led the Indian delegation at the Ministerial Conference in September 2003 described Cancun as a historical turn in the WTO and summed it up thus: “Our achievement in Cancun is that India and the developing countries have left their imprint on the WTO Agenda. We set the agenda at Cancun. The agenda was two-pronged: First, our strong demand for end to subsidies that rich countries provide to their farmers, which in turn, hurt our farmers; and Two, our objections to areas such as foreign investment. We had built strong alliances of the developing countries – G-22 on agriculture and G-16 on the Singapore issues….. Unlike in the past, the developed nations could not break our alliances. Third, this time our stand was not negative…. We did not always say no. We proactively engaged in the negotiations.” Emergence of the coalition of countries on agriculture in the WTO (G-20) representing the needs of millions of farmers in all the major less developed regions of the world in Asia, the Americas and in Africa, was another major development during the year. As a founder member, India accords the highest priority to the Group which will continue to work for significant reduction in trade distortions, more meaningful market access and a better deal for farmers in all developing countries. Shri Jaitley, who also attended the first post-Cancun meeting of the Group in Brasilia (Brazil), has indicated that India will continue to play its role in supporting and strengthening the Group from within. The year also saw India’s export crossing the US $ 50 billion mark. India’s exports of merchandise goods during 2002-03 crossed the crucial milestone of US $ 50 billion, by reaching a figure of US $ 51.7 billion. The export growth achieved during the year was 18.05%, exceeding the target of 12% fixed for 2002-03. With this achievement, India was able to more than double its exports of merchandise goods in dollar terms in a span of 10 years. In 1993-94, India’s exports were valued at US $ 22.2 billion. In rupee terms, the export of merchandise goods during 2002-03 was valued at Rs. 2,50,130 crore compared to Rs. 2,09,018 crore in 2001-02 with a growth rate of 19.67%. The growth rate of 18% achieved by India was next only to that of China at 22% and was the second highest among the 30 leading exporters in world merchandise trade in 2002. Significantly, with this, India’s share in world exports in merchandise goods increased from 0.4% in 1992-93 and 0.7% in 2001-02 to 0.8% in 2002-03. Export growth momentum in 2003 was sustained despite strengthening of the rupee vis-à-vis the US dollar and other adverse factors. On the bilateral front, the year witnessed a record increase in exports to China with a growth of almost 106% in US dollar terms in 2002-03. Exports to USA also showed a substantial increase of over 27% with exports crossing the US $ 1 billion mark during 2002-03. It is significant that export growth was registered during the year across all regions. Exports to Latin America went up by 34% while exports to Asia and Oceania region grew by 42.85%. Among the neighbouring countries, India’s exports to Pakistan grew by 42.92% during 2002-03; exports to Sri Lanka by 45%, to Nepal by 38% and to Bangladesh by 9%. Among the territorial initiatives, “Focus: CIS” programme, announced on 31 March, 2003 by Shri Jaitley at the time of announcement of the Exim Policy for the year 2003-04 is under way and aims to focus on trade with countries of the CIS with emphasis in the first phase on seven countries viz., Kazakhstan, Kyrgyzstan, Uzbekistan, Turkmenistan, Tajikistan, Azerbaijan and Ukraine. The “Focus: Africa” programme was extended with effect from 1st April, 2003 to all countries of sub-Saharan Africa where India has Missions along with six countries of the North Africa region. The total number of countries thus covered under “Focus: Africa” increased from initial seven countries to 24 countries of the African continent. As many as 48 Agri Export Zones (AEZs) for different products have been set up in 19 States and the total anticipated value of exports from these AEZs in the next 5 year would be Rs. 10,299 crore. The state-wise break-up of approved AEZs include West Bengal (5), Karnataka (3), Uttaranchal (4), Punjab (3), Uttar Pradesh (4), Maharashtra (6), Andhra Pradesh (4), Jammu & Kashmir (2), Tripura (1), Madhya Pradesh (3), Tamil Nadu (3), Bihar (1), Gujarat (2), Sikkim (2), Himachal Pradesh (1), Orissa (1), Jharkand (1), Kerala (1) and Assam (1). Approvals have been given for setting up of 23 Special Economic Zones (SEZs) in the country and a number of measures were taken during the year for promoting SEZs. Exports from SEZs have been growing steadily. During the first 6 months of the current financial year 2003-04, exports from SEZs amounted to Rs. 6,008.46 crore compared to Rs. 4889.85 crore during the corresponding period of last year representing a growth of 23%. Movement towards free trade agreements received a major impetus with the signing of a Framework Agreement for establishing a Free Trade Area (FTA) between India and Thailand (on 9 October, 2003). A Framework Agreement for Comprehensive Economic Cooperation were also signed between India and ASEAN in the Second ASEAN-India Summit at Bali in Indonesia during October, 2003. The Framework Agreements include provisions relating to FTA in goods, services and investments and are aimed at strengthening India’s trade and economic cooperation with its Southeast Asian neighbours, consistent with the country’s Look East Policy.

pr_title: Clarification on Patents (Amendment) Bill 2003
pr_content: Reacting to the report in a section of the press regarding the Patents (Amendment) Bill 2003 “kills opposition to patent application; and Patent application can be opposed on 2 grounds”, the Department of Industrial Policy & Promotion, Ministry of Commerce & Industry, have said that the reports are not only factually deficient and misleading but also based on incomplete understanding of the patent system and the Patents (Amendment) Bill, 2003 which was recently introduced during the Winter Session of Parliament. The factual position in respect of opposition procedures under the patent law is as below: <U+F0B7> The Bill does not do away with opposition procedures; instead it seeks to introduce a revised and tiered mechanism for representation against patent applications as well as for opposition and revocation of patents. <U+F0B7> The proposed restructuring/revision basically aims at introducing simplified, efficient, cost-effective and user-friendly mechanisms which not only facilitate expeditious grant of patents but also safeguard the interest of third parties. <U+F0B7> The proposed restructuring/revision is also in line with the Bill’s objective of revising the time lines for processing of patent applications. The time taken for processing and grant of patents has been a matter of concern and subject of criticism. Analysis has indicated that delays are also substantially due to statutory provisions which prescribe lengthy time lines for each stage/level of processing. The Bill therefore seeks to fully rationalise/ restructure all time lines with a view to progressively reduce the time for each activity and bring patent office operations in line with international standards. <U+F0B7> In respect of existing provisions relating to opposition, it has been noted that a notice of opposition, when filed, becomes a quasi-judicial proceeding and holds up the processing of patent application till the proceedings are finalised. Theoretically, therefore, if an opposition proceedings continues indefinitely the patent application also remains unresolved indefinitely. Further, statistics reveal that not more than 3 per cent of all patent applications accepted (and less than 0.5% of all applications filed) are opposed at any given point of time. On the other hand, all accepted and published applications have to wait for a statutory period of at least 5 months before being processed further. The Bill seeks to provide correctives against such avoidable delays. <U+F0B7> The restructured/revised procedures proposed in the Bill provide the following opportunities for representation against patent applications by third party and for opposition and revocation of patents: <U+F0FC> In the first instance any person may represent under Section 25(1) (a) and (b) against the processing/grant of a patent application on substantial grounds of patentability namely novelty, inventiveness and industrial applicability. The challenge can also be made on grounds of non-disclosure or wrong disclosure of source of geographical origin of biological material and anticipation by traditional knowledge available in India or elsewhere. <U+F0FC> Further all the grounds on which patents can be opposed have also been retained as the grounds of revocation of patent under Section 25 (3) whereby any person can approach the Controller within one year. The decision of the Controller under Section 25 is also appealable under Section 117 (A) i.e. clause 55 of the Bill. <U+F0FC> A third opportunity is also available to any person to oppose and seek revocation of a patent any time during the term of a patent. This opportunity is available under Section 64 and can be availed before the Intellectual Property Appellate Board or High Court. <U+F0B7> In view of the above it would be obvious that the Bill neither seeks to dispense with the opposition opportunities nor restrict the basis for the same. In fact the proposed amendments are in tune with the Government’s intention to revamp intellectual property administration through simplification and rationalisation of procedures so as to make them user-friendly and comparable to international standards/ practices.

pr_title: Mines - Year-End Review 2003
pr_content: Year-End Review 2003The Mines Ministry, during the year 2003, has taken measures for greater private sector participation and foreign investment in mineral exploration, mining, mineral processing and metallurgy. Foreign Investment Promotion Board (FIPB) has so far approved 72 applications for FDI in the mining sector amounting to about Rs.4,018 crore. These proposals are mainly in the fields of mining, exploration, mineral processing and technical consultancy. The proposals cleared include 13 from Australia , 9 from U.K. 9 from U.S.A., 8 from South Africa, 6 from Canada, 4 from Netherlands, 3 from Mauritius, 2 each from Korea, Malaysia, Norway, Singapore, Sweden, the balance being 1 proposal each from other countries. Appropriate policy changes and changes in the Acts and Rules made to make the climate investment friendly. The Ministry has allows foreign equity holding upto 100 per cent on the automatic route for all minerals and upto 74 per cent in diamonds and precious stones. The Ministry has delegated powers to the State Governments for renewal and amalgamation of mining leases for all non-fuel and non-atomic minerals. The State Governments have been empowered to approve mining plant (open cast mines) in respect of 29 non-metallic and industrial materials. It has introduced concept of reconnaissance operations to bring in state of the art technology in mineral exploration. Reconnaissance Permits were granted in 161 cases involving an area of about 2,13,530 Sq. km. as in December 2003. 65 prospecting licenses granted for large areas involving 90,142 Sq. km. Geological Survey of India (GIS) completed 150 years of service to the nation in 2001. It has been engaged augmenting the mineral inventory through extensive survey and exploration. It has been successfully locating platinum group of metals in Baulanausai in Orissa and Skoli in Maharashtra. To explore coal, bauxite and iron ore, it has undertaken 37 items of regional exploration for coal and lignite, and 2 items each for iron ore and bauxite during the field season 2003-04 in various parts of the country. During this season, it has taken up 26 investigations for gold, 11 for diamond and 13 for basements including zinc in the States of Maharashtra, Rajasthan, Madhya Pradesh, West Bengal, Sikkim, Jharkhand, Orissa, Chhattisgarh, Uttar Pradesh, Andhra Pradesh, Meghalaya and Karnataka. GIS has brought out seismo-technonic atlas of India and is intimately associated with seismic study in the country including Bhuj area of Gujarat. The Aluminium production in the country during April-November, 2003 has been estimated at 5,45,684 tonnes against 4,38,120 tonnes during the same period last year. Out of total production, the public sector National Aluminium Company Limited (NALCO) has produced 1,98,026 tonnes. Bharat Aluminium Company Limited (BALCO) with 49 per cent, Central Government Equity produced 64,513 tonnes and the private sector Hindustan Aluminium Company Limited (HINDALCO) contributed 2,18,574 tonnes followed by Indian Aluminium Company Ltd. (INDAL) 43,331 tonnes and Madras Aluminium Company Limited (MALCO) 21,240 tonnes. NALCO is currently implementing a Rs.4,206.6 crore expansion project to increase its mining, refinery and smelter capacity. It will also expand its power production from its captive power plant. The work for expansion and mining and refinery capacity and addition of 7th Unit in the captive power plant has been completed by the end of this year. Smelter expansion project has also been mechanically completed. The company this year, has submitted a proposal for Rs. 4,091.51 crore for expansion project which is under the consideration of the Government. At the instance of Indian Bureau of Mines ( IBM) 61.24 million trees were planted in mining areas for pollution control. About 7.35 hectares of mined out areas have been reclaimed/ rehabilitated by IBM. The total value of mineral production during 2001-02 and 2002-03 Rs.60,832 crore and Rs.63,540 crore, respectively. Minerals worth Rs.46,618 crore were exported during 2002-03. The 19th World Mining Congress and EXPO 2003 was held here in November, 2003. Over 1500 delegates from 48 countries participated in this mega event of the mining industry. Nearly 300 exhibitors from different countries participated in the EXPO, in which the state-of-the-art technology in the field of mining, equipment and machinery from the world over was displayed. 50,000 visitors interacted in this five-days EXPO which generated business worth nearly Rs.5,000 crore. Offshore Areas Mineral (Development and Regulation) Act, 2002 was notified on 31.1.2003 to provide for development & regulation of mineral resources in the territorial waters, continental shelf, EEZ and other maritime zones of India. Rules under the Act were finalised during the year.

pr_title: Envoys present credentials to President
pr_content: Seven envoys presented their credentials to the President of India, Dr. A.P.J. Abdul Kalam at a ceremony at Rashtrapati Bhavan here today. The envoys who presented their credentials were:- His Excellency Mr. Walid Adel Nasr, the Ambassador of Lebanon, His Excellency Mr. Hemayetuddin , the High Commissioner of Bangladesh, His Excellency Mr. U Kyi Thein, the Ambassador of Myanmar, His Excellency Mr. Vasile Sofineti, the Ambassador of Romania, His Excellency Mr. Jorge Heine, the Ambassador of Chile, His Excellency Mr. Fahd Salim, Ambassador of Syria and His Excellency Pundit Maniedeo Persad the High Commissioner of Trinidad and Tobago. The credential presentation ceremony was attended by the senior members of the missions, senior officials of the Ministry of External Affairs and Rashtrapati Bhavan.

pr_title: Press Communique
pr_content: The President of India has accepted, on the Prime Minister’s recommendation, the resignations of Shri M. Kannappan, Minister of State (Independent Charge) for Non-Conventional Energy Sources and Shri Gingee N. Ramachandran, Minister of State for Textiles from the Council of Ministers with immediate effect.

pr_title: 75 Institutions selected under second phase of TEQIP
pr_content: Seventy five engineering institutions from seven states have been selected for financial support in the second phase of the Technical Education Quality Improvement Programme (TEQIP). The states are Andhra Pradesh, Gujarat, Jharkhand, Karnataka, Tamil Nadu, Uttaranchal and West Bengal. The financial help to these institutions is estimated to be around Rs.500 crore. The National Screening Committee of the Ministry of Human Resource Development has also recommended 19 polytechnics for support under the TEQIP from 13 participating states. In the first phase 40 institutions from six states namely, Haryana, Himachal Pradesh, Kerala, Madhya Pradesh, Maharashtra and Uttar Pradesh were selected and financial support of Rs.310 crore extended. The government announced the Rs.1550 crore TEQIP to improve the quality of education in the engineering institutions across the country, in December last year. The programme aims at modernisation of laboratories and workshops, faculty and staff development, curricula improvement and developing culture for research and undertaking consultancy assignments and development of management capacity etc.

pr_title: Electronic media no way hamper growth of print media newspapers circulation up by 24 per cent – RNI Report
pr_content: The 47th ‘Press In India’ Report reveals that the total circulation figure of newspapers jumped up from 11,52,53,948 copies in 2001 to 14,20,05,543 copies in 2002-03, registering an increase of more than 24 per cent. The increase can be attributed to the larger number of publishers submitting Annual Statements. During 2002-03 newspapers in Uttar Pradesh had a total circulation of 2,80,46,287 copies followed by Delhi with 2,18,56,174 copies. On 31st March 2003 the total figure for registered newspapers stood at 55,780, an increase of 7.35 per cent over the previous year. The Report, the first on a financial year basis, was presented by Shri G.D.Beliya, Registrar, Newspapers of India to Shri Pawan Chopra, Secretary, Ministry of Information and Broadcasting here today. The Report indicates that among multi-edition Dailies, Dainik Bhaskar publishing in Hindi with 18 editions, had the largest claimed circulation of 17, 17,294 copies, followed by Times of India with 13,94,646 copies. For single-edition Dailies, Hindustan Times an English Daily claimed a circulation of 11,12,160 copies, while the Hindu came second with a figure of 9,22,407 copies. The circulation pattern also revealed that while big publishing houses dominated the metropolises, the Medium and Small newspapers with their local content influenced small town and rural areas. Big newspapers claimed a circulation of 5,11,72,068 copies, while Medium newspapers had 5,26,00,091 copies and small newspapers claimed 3,82,33,384 copies. Since many small newspapers perhaps do not send Annual Statements, these figures do not reflect their actual share in the circulation scenario. Out of the 7156 newspapers who sent their Annual Statements in 2002-03, 5371 were owned by individuals while 950 were owned by Joint Stock Companies. Language-wise, Hindi dominated with 3410 newspapers, followed by English with 750. In circulation too, Hindi maintained its lead with 6,17,68,735 copies while English followed with 2,6213,142 copies. The Report also reveals that the challenges from the electronic media have in no way hampered the growth of the Print Media. The Indian reader still relishes detailed analysis in addition to hourly news bulletins and talks shows. The present Report having made a change from the calendar year to the financial year contains an analysis for 15 months i.e. from 01.01.2002 to 31.03.2003.

pr_title: High Level Education Meet asks UNESCO to use updated statistics
pr_content: RAJYA SABHAMany of the participating countries in the third meeting of the High Level Group on Education for All agreed that the projections made and inferences drawn in the Global Monitoring Report on Education For All-2003 were based on old data. There was call for the UNESCO Institute of Statistics (UIS) to fine-tune their estimation methods to include updated survey data and not wait for desegregated census data. It was felt that UIS also needs to enhance its capacity for analysis and forecasting so that the conclusions drawn by it can be more realistic. The (EFA) was co-hosted by India and UNESCO from 10th to 12th November, 2003. Sixteen countries participated in this meet. Other salient observations made by the participating countries included: i. All participating countries agreed that there was a need to step up efforts for girls’ education to achieve the gender equality at primary stage by 2005 and the gender parity goal by 2015; ii. Donor countries and international agencies should fulfil their commitments made at Dakar and Monterrey. This referred to the need to substantially step up their Official Development Assistance (to reach 0.7% of their GNP) and increase the allocation therefrom to Elementary Education. This information was given by Dr. Vallabhbhai Kathiria, Minister of State for Human Resource Development in written reply to a question in the Rajya Sabha today.

pr_title: Rs. 193 crore spent on social science in five years
pr_content: RAJYA SABHAThe budget allocation in respect of the important national level research councils/institute of social sciences, engaged in research related to social sciences, during the last five years is Rs. 19, 306.49 lakhs. The budget allocation for IITs during the last five years, is Rs. 2,53,551.00 lakhs. There is no proposal under consideration with the government to set up Indian Institute of Social Sciences on the same standards as the IITs in the country. This information was given by Dr. Vallabhbhai Kathiria, Minister of State for Human Resource Development in written reply to a question in the Rajya Sabha today. The Minister added that the University Grants Commission (UGC), is paying due importance on the development of high quality social sciences capabilities as in the case of S&T. However, disparity exists in various universities in respect of appropriate academic and other support structure as well as diversity of teachers. Disparities in the standard of education in universities is attributed to a large number of critical factors including the age of the university, quality of curricula, teaching work force, evaluation techniques, resources, governance, leadership, accountability, geographical location etc.

pr_title: Measures to improve credit flow to small scale sector taken DEVELOPMENT INITIATIVES FOR NORTH-EASTERN REGION INTRODUCED
pr_content: Year End Review – 2003 - Min. of SSI & DONER This year the focus of Government was to facilitate the promotion and development of small scale industries through the programmes and schemes relating to credit, technology, infrastructure, entrepreneurship and market development. SMALL SCALE INDUSTRIES–PROSPECTS AND CHALLENGES: A Seminar on "SSIs – Prospects and Challenges" was held on 25th April, 2003 in New Delhi. Various problems of SSI like delayed financing, inadequate and costly credit even after offering manifold collaterals were addressed at this Seminar. The initiatives taken by the Government in improving the flow of credit to SSI sector include raising the limit of collateral free loan from Rs. 1 lakh to Rs. 5 lakhs and increasing the limit for composite loan to Rs. 50 lakhs. Under the National Equity Fund, the limit of the projects has been raised from Rs. 25 lakhs to 50 lakhs. Revision in eligible loan limit for coverage under Credit Guarantee Scheme from Rs. 10 lakhs to Rs. 25 lakhs has been done. Laghu Udyami Credit Card Scheme has been introduced. NATIONAL LEADERSHIP SUMMIT: The Summit was organised by the Centre for Bharatiya Marketing Development (CBMD), in New Delhi on 18th – 19th August, 2003. CBMD organised this seminar to focus on re-vitalising the small-scale industry sector in the country. For widening the base of SSI in the country and to inspire new entrepreneurs, the Ministry of SSI has initiated a move to encourage setting up of five new SSI units and revival of another five sick SSI units in each parliamentary constituency with active participation of the public representatives. SSI CONVENTION – 2003: The Ministry of Small Scale Industries held its fourth National Convention on 30th August, 2003. The focus of this years’ convention was Machine Tool Industry. National Awards were presented to Outstanding SSI Entrepreneurs and SSI units who had excelled in the field of entrepreneurship, quality projection research and development. A special award for Women entrepreneur was also presented. National awards were given to banks for "Excellence in SSI Lending." VENDOR DEVELOPMENT PROGRAMME: The objective of this programme is to give open platform to buyers from Government and Public Undertakings and SSI sector to interact directly. The SSI manufacturers through this programme have the opportunity to interact with the representatives of the consuming units and know about the products used at present or those which may be needed in the future. Laghu Udyog Bharati organised the Vendor Development Programme cum Buyer-Seller Meet and Exhibition in association with National Small Industries Corporation and Small Industries Service Institute. MEETING WITH CMD’S OF PUBLIC SECTOR BANKS: For adequate and timely availability of credit at reasonable cost, a meeting was held on 19th December, 2003 with CMD’s of Public Sector Banks regarding lending to SSI. The meeting was held to discuss the status of credit flow to SSI Sector, the problems coming in the way of realisation of 12% annual growth target for SSI sector, creation of 4.4 million additional jobs during the 10th Five Year Plan and development of clusters which have economies of scale. There was unanimity among the banks for increased lending to SSI sector. SSI CLUSTER DEVELOPMENT INITIATIVES: THE ROLE OF PUBLIC PRIVATE PARTNERSHIP: SSI Ministry has selected 21 new clusters for intensive development under the scheme of ‘Small Industry Cluster Development Programme’ this year. 20 more clusters are to be selected. The Role of Public Private Partnership in cluster development programme was highlighted in the inter institutional meeting on 24th of December, 2003 in New Delhi. Public-Private Partnership is the key for economic reforms in the country. The Tirupur project, taken up by IL&FS in collaboration with the Government of Tamil Nadu is taken as a role model for public-private partnership. INTEGRATED INFRASTRUCTURE DEVELOPMENT CENTRES: The Government has amended the IID Scheme to progressively cover the entire country with 50% reservation for rural areas. The funding pattern for the Scheme has also been suitably modified to enhance the quantum of central grant from 40% to 80% in respect of North-Eastern Region (including Sikkim), J&K, Himachal Pradesh and Uttaranchal. CREDIT GUARANTEE FUND: The Credit Guarantee Fund Scheme for Small Industries is being implemented by the Government through the Credit Guarantee Fund Trust for small industries with the corpus fund shared by the Government of India and the Small Industries Development Bank of India in the ratio of 4:1. The objective is to extend guarantee cover for mitigating credit risk upto 75 per cent of the collateral free credits subject to a maximum credit of Rs. 25 lakh per unit. The Scheme is being operated all over the country. DEPARTMENT OF DEVELOPMENT OF NORTH-EASTERN REGION : The Government is fully committed to accelerate the pace of development of North-Eastern Region. Special developmental projects have been undertaken by the Ministry with due emphasis on local infrastructure and availability of resources. NON-LAPSABLE CENTRAL POOL OF RESOURCES (NLCPR): Union Ministries except for a few exempted Ministries are required to spend at least 10% of their Plan budget in the North Eastern Region. The unspent balance out of this 10% is transferred to Non-lapsable Central Pool of Resources (NLCPR). Funds available in NLCPR are used for financing infrastructure projects in the North Eastern Region. Rs. 550.00 crore were released to various North-Eastern States in 2002-2003. EXHIBITION - TREASURES FROM THE NORTH-EAST: An exhibition of handicrafts and gifts from the North-East was organised on 27th February, 2003 in New Delhi. There was strong participation of leading exporters from different parts of the globe. The collection showcased the rich legacy of eco-friendly crafts from the North East in the form of Cane and Bamboo furniture. Dry flowers and Christmas decorations, Basketry, Silk furnishings, Utility items and Woodcarvings. NATIONAL BODO MELA 2003: The Mela was organised in March, 2003 at Himachal Bhawan, New Delhi. The Mela was attended by huge gathering of people of North-Eastern Region. For speeding up the development of North Eastern Region, the converging of activities in SSI sector as well as promotion of Handicrafts and Handlooms, cultivation of medicinal and aromatic plants, and growth of Information Technology and Sericulture were discussed at this meet. Government had also plan to provide training to youths in job oriented processes. CHAPCHAR KUT FESTIVAL: The Chapchar Kut festival was held in March, 2003 at Aizwal. Chapchar Kut is one of folk festival in Mizoram. The local populace especially the younger generation were urged to come forward and add to development of Mizoram and assured all possible help and cooperation from the central government for the purpose. This year’s Chapchar Kut celebrations were organised by the Central Young Mizo Association (CYMA), Department of Art and Culture and Tourism Department. UDYOG EXPORT 2003: This was organised with a focus on North-East to exhibit various products from this region. The Expo was organised by the National Small Industries Corporation Ltd.(NSIC). Products on display included processed food, bamboo handicrafts, cane furniture, jewellery, handloom and moonga silk. Live demonstration of weaving of loom and moonga silk had been organised. About 44 participants from north east region had taken part in the exhibition. NSIC also offered 75% subsidy on freight of goods from north-east. EXHIBITION ON DEVELOPMENT INITIATIVES IN THE NORTH-EASTERN REGION: The exhibition was held from 7th – 10th April, 2003 at Parliament House Annexe, New Delhi. This was the first such exhibition since the Department of Development of North-East had been created. The exhibition focused on the key initiatives taken by the Government so far towards the socio-economic and infrastructural development in the North Eastern Region. UTSAV PURVANCHAL: Department Of North-East Region (DONER) in collaboration in Nehru Yuva Kendra Sangathan undertook a programme called "North-Eastern School Student/Youth Cultural Exchange Program". As part of the programme, Utsav Purvanchal was organised from 24th to 26th May, 2003 at Guwahati, Assam. The objective of the above programme was to take the youth of both from North-Eastern as well as other parts of the country on a cultural voyage so that they may understand the rich cultural heritage and diversity of our country. CERTIFICATE PROGRAMME IN FASHION AND CLOTHING : DONER organised a 3-month certificate programme in fashion & clothing (CPFC) for the youth of North-Eastern Region at National Institute of Fashion Technology(NIFT) in Kolkata. The programme is fully funded by DONER and is first of its kind undertaken by the Department. It aims to provide the students with formal technical education in fashion apparel design, construction and technology to be later absorbed as merchandisers, fashion co-ordinators in various exports and design houses. ECONOMIC PACKAGE FOR NAGALAND: The Prime Minister during his visit to Nagaland on 27th – 29th October, 2003 announced an economic package for the development of Nagaland. Some of the highlights of this package are: The Government of India jointly with the State Government will draw up a plan for creating 25000 employment and self- employment for the youth. Approximately Rs. 250 crores will be provided to implement this plan. A 23 MW Thermal Power Project will be funded by the Government of India at a cost of around Rs. 105 crore. Government of India will provide Rs. 35 crore for the development of infrastructure of Nagaland University at Lumami. In addition Rs. 10 crore will be provided for the development of Kohima campus. A Regional Institute for Information Technology in Nagaland will be set up for Rs. 20 crore. Rs. 10 crore will be provided for upgrading the higher secondary and high schools for science education and facilities for girls’ education. The district hospitals at all district headquarters will be upgraded. Rs. 15 crore will be provided for self-help groups and for empowerment of women. Over a period of three years Rs. 15 crore will be provided to control jhum and for development of horticulture in the State. A joint Task Force on tourism will prepare an action plan based on public private partnership.An ‘Action Plan’ for implementation of this package has been drawn up in consultation with implementing agencies and the same is being monitored closely.

pr_title: Expansion of Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan, increasing the number of trained teachers, new regulations concerning foreign universities are some of the highlights
pr_content: Year Ender - 2003- HRDExpansion of Sarva Shiksha Abhiyan (SSA), Increasing the number of trained teachers to bridge the gap between availability and requirement at elementary and secondary level, National Commission for Children poised to become operational, Opening up of new Kendriya Vidyalayas (KVs), New regulations concerning foreign universities and 17 new universities becoming Centres of Excellence are some of the highlights of the year. The SSA has takenoff with a flying start. The Centre approved all the state plans at a faster pace to facilitate them to implement the programme. Rupees 9500 crores have been provided for SSA and District Primary Education Programme during the current financial year. A strong monitoring system has been put in place so that the programme is implemented by all the states on a time bound basis. The HRD Minister has taken personal interest in the implementation of SSA. He himself held a number of review meetings in Delhi and state capitals and has been impressing upon Chief Ministers of those states which have lagged behind in the implementation of the programme. The National Council for Teacher Education (NCTE) took a number of initiatives to bridge the gap between the teacher availability and the requirement in view of the massive expansion of education at the elementary level. It has allowed State Governments to increase the intake in their District Institutes of Educational Training (DIET) from 200 to 500 seats per year . It has agreed to accord recognition for new Basic Teacher Certificate (BTC) courses for elementary school teachers in B.Ed. institutions. The Council also proposes to allow State Governments to offer special courses to B.Ed. candidates for enabling them to tech at elementary level. The Planning Commission has estimated a requirement of around 11.5 lakh additional trained teachers in the country to attain the objective of universalisation of elementary education by 2010. A special programme ‘Accelerated Female Literacy Programme (AFLP) has been launched in Bihar and Uttar Pradesh to give a boost to female literacy in the backward regions. Special awards have also been instituted for commendable work undertaken in regions of Bihar and Uttar Pradesh where female literacy rate was poor as per the 2001 census. A pilot project has been initiated for expansion of secondary education in un-served areas. This pilot project has begun in Balia (U.P.). In the long run it would become a model for central support for secondary schools in other backward areas of the country, with funds being made available under the 10th Plan. During the year, a new programme, the National Programme for Education of Girls at Elementary Level (NPEGEL) was also implemented in 21 states. Forty five new Kendriya Vidyalayas are being opened in the current fiscal year in various states and union territories to cater to the rising demand. The All India Council for Technical Education (AICTE) issued a set of rules to regulate the operation of foreign universities and the institutions providing education in India. Under the new regulations no foreign university or institutions will establish or operate its educational activity in India leading to award of diploma/degrees in technical education without the express permission of AICTE. Identifying technology as a tool of national progress, a committee has been set up to select five institutions/colleges to be upgraded and converted into I.I.Ts . With these the number of I.I.Ts in the country will go up to 12. The National Commission for children in all set to become a statutory body to give further protection to children and act as an independent ombudsman for them. A Bill was introduced to set up the Commission in the winter session of Parliament. The proposed Commission will have a chairperson and six other members. The Chairperson will be either a sitting or former Judge of the Supreme Court or a person of eminence who has done outstanding work in children related matters. New Delhi was declared the World Book Capital for 2003 by UNESCO in association with the international publisher’s association. The National Book Trust was the nodal agency for book promotion during the year. The University Grants Commission (UGC) has selected 5 more universities to make them centres of excellence, while 12 universities have already been chosen as centres for excellence. It has circulated a model curricula in core subjects for updating. Under the project of history of Indian science, philosophy and culture about 30 volumes were brought out, covering India’s achievements through the ages in different branches of humanities. The project is expected to be completed by 2010 with publishing of 77 volumes.

pr_title: Chemicals & Fertilizers - Year-End-Review-2003
pr_content: Year-End-Review-2003OMIFCO Fertilizer Plant The Foundation Stone for the Oman Indian Fertilizer Company (OMIFCO)’s fertilizer plant at Sur in Oman has been be laid by the Union Minister for Chemicals & Fertilizers on Oct.1, 2003. OMIFCO is a joint venture fertilizer company promoted by IFFCO & KRIBHCO from Indian side and Oman Oil Company from Oman, at a total cost of US $ 969 million, with equity contribution of US $ 80 million each by IFFCO and KRIBHCO and US $ 160 million by Oman Oil Company. The plant will produce 16.52 lakh tonnes of urea and 2.48 lakh tonnes of ammonia per annum on completion in July, 2005. Government of India has signed a contract to procure urea from OMIFCO for a 15 year period, at a fixed long term price. Similarly IFFCO, one of the Indian sponsors, has signed an agreement to procure surplus ammonia from OMIFCO for 10 year period at a fixed long term price. OMIFCO is a mega industrial project being undertaken by the Indian Fertilizer Industry with support from the Governments of Indian and Oman and is a shining example of Indian entrepreneurship and economic cooperation with other countries. The OMIFCO Project would be a test case for future ventures by Indian Fertilizer Industry outside the country. New Fertilizer Pricing Policy A new pricing policy for the urea industry in the shape of Group Concession Scheme is introduced. The new pricing policy brings about greater transparency, uniformity and efficiency in subsidy disbursements to urea units and induces urea manufacturers to take cost reduction measures on their own and be competitive. The policy of the Government has been aimed not only to achieve maximum possible degree of self-sufficiency in production ofNitrogenous and Phosphatic fertilizers but also to ensure affordability to farmers by fixing uniform selling prices, to be applicable through out the country. Self sufficiency in Urea and DAP India has achieved self-sufficiency in production capacity of urea. In case of DAP and complexes, their installed capacity has bypassed the current level of domestic requirement. However, to meet the requirement of potash, the country will continue to depend entirely on import in the absence of its own reserves. India has today become the third largest producer in the world by producing about 146 lakh MT and N&P in nutrient terms. There has been a significant increase in consumption of fertilizers compared to last year. The sales of urea and DAP have been 93.1 lakh MT and 22.1 lakh MT respectively, a growth rate of 4 per cent in urea and a decline of about 4 per cent in DAP sales compared to last year. The supply situation is comfortable throughout the country. Even the procurement and marketing of DAP and other forms of complex fertilizers is totally decontrolled. A Control Room monitors the movement, dispatches and arrivals of stock in different parts of the country. Decontrol of Urea A beginning has been made in the realm of decontrol and liberalization by restricting allocation of Urea under the essential commodities Act to 75 per cent of the reassessed capacity of each unit in Kharif 2003 and 50 per cent of the capacity in Rabi 2003-04. The Urea units will be free to sell the remaining Urea at the designated maximum Retail Price (MRP). During Stage-II commencing from April 1st, 2004, urea distribution will be totally decontrolled after evaluation of the performance in Stage – I. Guidelines for implementation of the concession Scheme for decontrolled phosphatic and potassic (P&K) Fertilizers have been revised. The revised guidelines lay stress on timely certification of sales; restricting eligibility for concession on SSP units that undergo the mandatory inspection by Technical Audit and Inspection Cell and use grades of rock phosphate notified by the Department of Fertilizers. Closure of loss making units The entire Fertilizer Corporation of India Ltd. (FCI) and Hindustan fertilizer Corporation Ltd. (HFC), excepting its Jodhpur Mining Organisation have been closed as they were running in losses. Pharma Industry Indian drugmarkers ruled on the global pharmaceutical map in 2003 as their low-cost medicines made HIV/AIDS treatment accessible to a million poor in sub-sahran Africa and Asia. The Indian Pharmaceutical Industry today leads India’s knowledge based industries with wide ranging capabilities in the complex field of drug discovery, manufacture and technology. It hold a leadership position in the world in terms of technology, quality and range of medicines manufactured. From simple drugs like Anacin sophisticated antibiotics and complex biotechnology derived products, India now produces almost every type of medicine. India produces not only pharmaceutical formulations but also over 500 active pharmaceutical ingredients are manufactured from basic stage. Ancillary industry is also fully developed and a complete range of pharmaceutical manufacturing equipment is locally produced. Re-Structuring of sick PSU The Government spends annually approximately Rs. 300 crore as non-plan assistance on four sick fertilizer companies viz. HFC, FCI, PDIL and PPCL, which have accumulated losses of more than Rs. 15,000 crore as on March 31, 2002. Considering this, the Government is pursuing closure of non-viable units and revival of viable units through comprehensive restructuring proposals based on unit-wise techno-economic viability with regard to these companies. Accordingly the Government took the decision to close down the entire Fertilizer Corporation of India Ltd. (FCI) and Hindustan fertilizer Corporation Ltd. (HFC), excepting its Jodhpur Mining Organisation, as the two public sector undertakings have been making losses since inception and their accumulated losses as on March 31 this year were Rs.7921 crore and Rs.6726 crore respectively. The decision to close down the two undertakings will not impact the prices or availability of Urea as none of the units of FCI and HFC were in operation and the Haldia Fertilizer Project of HFC though mechanically completed in 1979 could never be commissioned. The country is almost self sufficient in Urea and its total availability in 2001-2002 was 21.6 million MT and consumption only 19.9 million MT. In addition, from 2005 – 2006 onwards, 1,652 Million MT of urea would be available from the Oman – India Fertilizer Company (OMIFCO). Also, the Government is considering expanding KRIBHCO at Hazira and the RCF at Thal. Pharmaceutical Policy – 2002 New Pharmaceutical Policy, 2002 being implemented with objective to ensure abundant availability of quality medicines at affordable price. The Policy also aims at promoting R&D, strengthening indigenous capability for manufacture of quality medicines & encouraging new investments with a view to prepare the domestic industry to meet the challenges of post 2005 scenario. The span of drug price control under the Drug Price Control Order would also get reduced considerably. Extension center of Central Institute of Plastic Engineering & Technology (CIPET) Central Institute of Plastic Engineering & Technology, an autonomous body under the administrative control of the Department of Chemicals & Petrochemicals, has set up extension center at Guwahati in Assam; Haldia in West Bengal & Patna in Bihar. These centers provide trained manpower for the Plastic Procession Industries in the Eastern & North-Eastern Region. Plastic Processing Industry Plastic Processing Industry is removed. Considering the necessity of modernization and upgradation of technology in this sector, a new scheme of Plastic Technology Upgradation Fund (PTUFs) would be launched. Mega Chemical Industrial Estate Apart from improving basic infrastructure like power, communication, transportation etc. The Task Force on Petrochemicals and recommended setting up of a Mega Chemical Industrial Estates (MCIE) in the private sector. The industrial estate would have a world class infrastructure and would be supported under the Industrial Infrastructure Upgradation scheme of Department of Industrial Policy and Promotion, Ministry of Commerce and Industry, Government of India. National Policy on Petrochemicals A high-powered group of experts has studied the various facets of Petrochemicals Industry and has made recommendations for enhancing competitiveness and growth of this sector. Based on this report, the Department is now engaged in the formulation of a National Policy on Petrochemicals. Plastic Export Processing Zones The domestic downstream plastic processing industry is highly competitive and plastic processed articles are exported to both development and developing countries. The export performance of plastic processed articles in 2002-03 is Rs. 941 million with a growth of 17.35 pr cent. Pharmaceutical Export Pharmaceutical exports from India have crossed the five-digit figure in financial year 2003. As per statistics of Directorate General of Commercial Intelligence and Statistics (DGCIS) the total value of pharma exports reached the figure of Rs.11925 crore. Compared to previous year’s figures export increased by about 21 per cent.

pr_title: Ministry of Coal - Year-End-Review - 2003
pr_content: YEAR-END-REVIEW - 2003 Coal India Limited (CIL) Coal India Limited (CIL) contributing 88 per cent of coal production in India is the single largest coal producing company in the world. Apart from being the largest public sector company in India, CIL as the prime energy provider to the nation is also conscious of its great social responsibility. India is the third largest coal producing country, next to China and USA. Coal Production and its Supply to Consumers Coal production in the country from April to November is 216.4 Million MT and Coal dispatches to all parts of country are being made simultaneously to ensure the availability of coal. Output per man ship (productivity) is also good. In India almost 70 per cent electricity generated by utilities is dependent upon coal. Besides power other major sectors dependent upon coal are Steel, Cement, Fertilizer, Paper, a host of small industrial units and Brick kilns. Coal India Ltd. (CIL) which incurred loss of Rs. 1414 crores in 2000-01 increased its profit to Rs. 2865.5 crores during 2002-2003. Its profits were Rs. 1754.56 crores during 2001-02. The CIL adopted various measures to improve productivity and quality and reduce costs to make CIL profitable. North-Eastern Coalfields (NEC) earned a profit of Rs. 1293.01 crore during the year 2002-03. This was highest profit among all the subsidiaries of Coal India (CIL) Limited. Mahanadi Coalfield Ltd. (MCL) earned a profit of Rs. 882.31 crore followed by South-Eastern Coalfields Ltd. which earned a profit of Rs.882.13 crore. Reduction of Ash content in Coal The Government has made it mandatory to use coal of ash content not exceeding 34 per cent in any thermal power plant (TPP) located beyond 1000 kms. from pithead or located in urban area or sensitive area or critically polluted area. To satisfy this stipulation, coal supply matrix for TPPs coming under purview of MoEF’s notification has been drawn up and is under operation. Coal Bed Methane Project Gas emitting out of coal mines is a type of natural gas which can be used for industries depending on its composition, heat value and other infrastructure for use of the gas. A demonstration project namely Coal Bed Methane Recovery & Commercial Utilization has been taken up by government of India in collaboration with United Nations Development Programme (UNDP), Global Environment Facility (GEF) at Moonidih and Sudamdih mines of Bharat Coking Coal Limited in Jharia Coalifields, District Dhanbad. The Central Mine Planning & Design Institute Limited (CMPDIL) is the main local implementing agency on behalf of Government of India. Bharat Coking Coal Limited is the co-implementing agency. Smart Cards Scheme launched The Coal Minister Shri Kariya Munda launched Smart Card Scheme for coal miners. Instituted by Coal Mines Provident Fund Organization (CMPFO) the Card enables an employee to examine his Provident Fund account without taking any trouble to visit the CMPFO office. He can also view his pension status, lodge grievance and make enquiry at his own convenience by inserting his smart card in a kiosk at Coal India Ltd. office at Kolkatta. These kiosks will be gradually installed in facilitation centers of all the 23 regional offices of CMPFO during the next one to two years. Safety Measures Measures taken for improving Safety measures were pursued for enhancement of safety in operations in Coalmines and also for community and peripheral development.

pr_title: Year marked by acquisition of interest in producing Sudanese oil field in country’s march towards oil security NATIONAL AUTO FUEL POLICY FINALISED FOR IMPROVED ENVIRONMENT OIL COMPANIES’ PROFIT REGISTERS SHARP INCREASE IN THE POST-APM ERA
pr_content: YEAR END REVIEW 2003Efforts to enhance oil security of the country through accelerated steps for increasing domestic production of oil and gas and through acquisition of interest in oil fields abroad received a big boost during 2003. ONGC Videsh Ltd (OVL) completed acquisition of 25 per cent interest in the producing Greater Nile Oil Project in Sudan on 12th March, 2003. Under the first such deal OVL’s share comes to 3 million tonne per annum (MMTPA) from the Mumbai High size 12 MMTPA oil field and the first consignment of crude oil from abroad was received on 15th May at Mangalore Port. The event was of great significance in view of country’s 70% import dependence. Simultaneously contracts for 23 oil & gas exploration blocks were signed taking total blocks awarded to70 in first three rounds of global bidding under New Exploration Licensing Policy (NELP) besides 21 more approved for award under fourth round. Domestic exploration & production (E&P) efforts met a major success with 20 MMT inplace reserves oil discovery in block in Rajasthan in February 2003 and 30 MMT inplace reserves oil and gas discovery in Vasai East oil field of ONGC off Maharashtra Coast in March 2003. Besides, other oil and discoveries were also reported in Assam, Rajasthan, etc. To further augment the natural gas supply for bridging the demand and supply contract for 5 CBM blocks were signed on 6.2.2003 and another 8 blocks were awarded under the second round of Coal Bed Methane (CBM) Policy . In all 8 CBM Blocks contracted already including 3 awarded earlier, efforts are on to soon produce CBM gas which is the low pressure locally utilisable in power, fertilizer, city gas projects, etc. Simultaneously, gas import in the form of liquefied natural gas (LNG) is progressing well as the LNG import project at Dahej (Gujarat) is almost complete to receive the first shipment in January 2004. In order to give boost to the exploration and production activities in the country, the Government has increased the rates of security deposit, annual licence fee, mining lease fee, etc., w.e.f. 1st April, 2003. This puts in place an effective mechanism for faster growth of the oil sector with fuller support of the State Governments. The amended rates are in line with the global practices to subserve the recent developments in hydrocarbon sector which aims at accelerating the efforts to find more oil and gas in the country. The initiative to address country’s oil security needs was fructified with the receipt of India’s first consignment of crude oil from equity oil abroad on 15th May at Mangalore Port from the Greater Nile Oil Project, Sudan in which ONGC Videsh (OVL) took over 25% stake in the Project from Talisman Energy of Canada. The first ever acquisition of a large producing field by India overseas is a landmark in the oil history of India and a path-breaking step forward towards oil security of the country and assumes great significance in view of the country’s heavy import dependence and the strategic importance of uninterrupted supplies of Petroleum products. Government allocated 15 lakh tonnes of Ravva crude to Bongaigaon Refinery & Petrochemicals Ltd. (BRPL) from the year 2003-04. This will increase the availability of crude to the refineries in North-East which have been facing difficulty of under utilisation of their refining capacity of 7 million metric tonnes per annum (MMTPA) as around 5 MMTPA crude was available in North-East earlier. The allocation to BRPL obviated the immediate need for capital investment of about Rs. 500 crore by BRPL to produce Euro-II fuels. The refineries in North-East are of sub-economic size and suffer from locational disadvantages. These refineries, keeping in view the government’s policy to stimulate industrial development and to provide for socio-economic development in North-East region, are being operated despite being economically unviable. Oil companies have so far invested about Rs. 10,000 crore in refineries to upgrade the fuel quality to Bharat Stage-I all over the country and Bharat Stage-II in 11 major cities. To the benefit of oil producing states the Government revised the rate and the principle of fixing royalty on crude oil which was Rs. 578/tonne earlier to about Rs. 1200 per tonne depending upon the international price. The States would benefit as royalty rates were in between revised upward on three occasions on adhoc basis before finalisation of the present ad valorem royalty regime on 4.2.2003. The National Auto Fuel Policy was laid on the Table of the Lok Sabha. The policy provides a clear cut road map for changes in vehicular technology and corresponding fuel quality for the whole country. Measures are also proposed to reduce emissions from in-use vehicles. It is expected that the implementation of the policy would lead to better ambient air quality which will reflect through improvement in public health and better environment. The Government formulated draft Natural Gas Pipeline Policy for the development of natural gas sector and optimum utilisation of the gas available from various sources in the country. In accordance with the draft Policy, transportation of all gas is envisaged to be done through a network of pipelines laid with the authorisation granted by the Regulator through a transparent mechanism. As per the draft Policy all trunk pipelines covering more than one State or operating at a pressure more than the notified level will be built/managed by a company to be notified by the Government, and till it is notified by GAIL. It is proposed to set up a National Gas Grid consisting of 7,000 Km long pipeline network at a cost of around Rs. 18,000 crore over the next 5-6 years. Further, any producer of gas, subject to prior permission of the Regulator (and Central Government for the PSUs) will have the right to sell gas within 100 Kms. of well-head or land-fall point to consumers directly and lay the pipeline for this purpose. The Minister of Petroleum & Natural Gas, Shri Ram Naik complimented the 12 oil PSUs under the Ministry of Petroleum & Natural Gas for outstanding performance in the year 2002-03, which he described as a watershed for the oil industry. The oil sector was opened up for competition in the post-APM era, in all spheres which included exploration and production, refining, marketing of products and pipeline. In the first year post-APM, the net profits of oil PSUs registered an impressive increase of 83 per cent to Rs. 23,250 crore from Rs. 12,700 crore in 2001-02. in combined net profit of PSUs in 2002-03 is 4 ½ times of the paid up capital of Rs.5200 crore. He exhorted the oil PSUs to come good while facing the challenge of maintaining these excellent figures of profitability in future. At the same time, the benefits of competition and de-regulation were passed on to the consumers in the form reduction in prices of petrol and diesel, (4 times) marking a departure from earlier practice when prices of these products never came down. Oil PSUs did not increase the prices of LPG and Kerosene in the interest of consumers in household sector and the consumers from weaker sections of the society even in the face of volatility in international market. Furthermore, the Cabinet, in its meeting of 11th September deliberated upon the issue of pricing of PDS Kerosene and Domestic LPG and decided that the selling price of these products would not be increased by the oil marketing companies during the current financial year. The Cabinet also decided to increase the phasing out period for subsidies on these products from three years to five years with effect from 1st April 2002 i.e. the subsidies will now be available upto 31.03.2007. The Government has approved the proposal for preponing the date of introducing Bharat Stage-II emission norms compliant fuels in the cities of Lucknow (Uttar Pradesh) and Sholapur (Maharashtra). Accordingly, the petrol and diesel with 0.05 per cent maximum sulphur content petrol and diesel would be supplied in these cities w.e.f. 1.1.2004 instead of 1.4.2005 as per Auto Fuel Policy. Presently, petrol and diesel with 0.25% sulphur content are being supplied all over the country from January 2000 including Lucknow and Sholapur excepting 11 other cities which have Bharat Stage-II fuels. The supply of 5 per cent ethanol blended petrol, called "Gasohol" was launched by the Government on January 1, 2003. Out of 255 Districts notified in nine States and four UTs which were to be supplied with ethanol blended petrol by 30th September 2003, 205 Districts have been covered so far including 16 Districts in part. Out of the remaining 50 Districts 32 fall in Tamilnadu (29) and Pondicherry (3) where the programme is being kept in abeyance. Of the 16 Districts covered in part, 12 are in the State of Andhra Pradesh and 4 in Gujarat. There are 18 uncovered Districts in Gujarat, Karnataka and Andhra Pradesh and the UT of Daman & Diu which will be fully covered by 31.12.2003. Ethanol-petrol blending programme is further extended to the States of Madhya Pradesh and Uttaranchal from 1st January 2004. Ethanol blended petrol carries an excise duty concession of 30 paise per litre. The additional excise duty on petrol has been reduced from the normal rate of Rs. 6 per litre to Rs. 5.70 per litre for petrol to be sold after blending with ethanol, as per the notification issued by the Finance Ministry. To encourage the use of ethanol in petrol, the Government has requested the States to exempt the sales tax payable on ethanol to be used for blending with petrol. Further, in order to supplement availability of hydro-carbons in the country, the Government is aiming at commencing implementation of blending bio-diesel with the diesel up to 20% by the year 2011-12. There would be a greater emphasis on producing bio-diesel from non-edible plants as the edible oil in India is in short supply. For producing bio-diesel mainly the plants like neem, mahua, karanja, kusum, jatropa etc., can be grown. Plants like jatropa have a characteristic of growing in areas with scarcity of water, deserts and in wasteland. Besides having advantages to blend bio-diesel with diesel and producing other bio-fuels, these initiatives are crucial to the energy security of the country and to reduce the ill effects of pollution caused by conventional fuels. A Memorandum of Understanding (MoU) on Cooperation in Hydrocarbon Sector between India and Iran was signed during the visit of Iranian Delegation in January this year. The MoU has been finalized in the background of significant potential for cooperation between the two countries in the Hydrocarbon sector including the Farsi Block by ONGC Videsh Consortium. The MoU seeks to establish a framework for cooperation in specific areas of Hydrocarbon Sector, ranging from Exploration and Production, Supply of Hydrocarbons, both oil and gas, services sector, R&D sector etc. This was followed by another agreement reached between the two countries in the first meeting of Indo-Iran Joint Working Group in Iran in May 2003 to formulate a package of importing 5 MMT LNG in phases from Iran to India and participating interests for Indian PSUs like OVL in appropriate discovered and semi-discovered oil and gas fields. The LNG project envisaged would have a period of 25 years. Indian Oil Corporation made its maiden entry in retail market abroad with the launch of Lanka IOC at Colombo in May 2003. LIOC’s first modernised RO as part of a chain of 100 ROs took over from Ceylon Petroleum Corporation in addition to 150 more franchisee ROs to be taken over in phases. IOC also took on lease Sri Lanka’s product storage tankage of 1 million tonne capacity at Triconamalee for modernisation and operations for mutual benefit. IOC will also supply 1 million tonne products every year to Sri Lanka from the refinery of its subsidiary Chennai Petroleum Corporation Limited. Shell India Pvt. Ltd. (SIPL), a subsidiary of Shell Group of Companies, was granted authorisation for marketing transportation fuels in the country subject to the company furnishing Bank Guarantee to the Government of Rs. 500 crore towards fulfilling the commitment to invest Rs. 2,000 crore in the building of infrastructure in the hydrocarbon sector. SIPL has plans to set up around 2,000 retail outlets spread all over the country of which 11% will be in remote/low service areas. Likewise, ONGC was also granted authorisation to set up additional 500 ROs in the country. With the rejuvenation of MRPL by ONGC acquiring majority stake in the refinery, ONGC will become a fully integrated company by opening retail outlets which can be easily fed from MRPL. Indian Oil Corporation, with an initial capital support of Rs. 2 crore, entered the select club of global providers of Hydrocarbon technology and process formulations developed by the Indian Oil R&D Centre located at Faridabad (Haryana). IndianOil Technologies Limited has a vision of evolving into a leader in technology provider through excellence in management of knowledge, technology and innovation. It aims to add value to Indian Oil’s intellectual property through Consultancy, Licensing and providing specialized services by commercially exploiting indigenous cutting-edge technologies. The proven technologies of Indian Oil’s R&D Centre is being offered to the refineries of India as well as to the petroleum companies of the Middle East, South East Asia and African markets. A Laboratory at the R&D Centre of Indian Oil Corporation Limited at Faridabad was set up at an investment of about Rs. 34 crore to develop new technologies for producing value added products like LPG, Needle Coke, etc., from crude oil residues. The laboratory houses pilot plants dedicated for various upgradation and related processes. Security Deposit on domestic LPG cylinder of 14.2 Kg. weight was reduced by Rs. 50/- w.e.f. 1.3.2003 thus the security deposit came to Rs. 650/- per cylinder from the Rs. 700/- per cylinder. First LPG Bottling Plant of Andaman & Nicobar Islands was commissioned at Port Blair on 20.4.2003. Manmad-Indore pipeline of Bharat Petroleum Corporation Ltd. (BPCL) was inaugurated on 12th September. Distributors’ commission increased on domestic LPG by 38 paise on a 14.2 kg. cylinder and by 20 paise on a 5 kg. cylinder w.e.f. 1st October, 2003. Over 7 crore Indian families are using LPG as cooking fuel. India stands second to China in LPG consumer population. The Government approved the proposal to provide subsidised LPG for all School & College Hostels, Government/Municipal Hospitals, Social Welfare institutions like child/women welfare homes, old age homes, homes for disabled etc., and for implementing Mid-day Meal Schemes. Following the dismantling of Administered Price Mechanism (APM) a number of administrative orders/circulars were withdrawn and the subsidised LPG became available for only domestic use. This resulted in sharp increase in the cost of procurement of LPG to Rs. 650 for 19 Kg. Cylinder at commercial rates by the consumers in these categories. These were earlier eligible for getting subsidised LPG at domestic rate of about Rs. 250 for 14.2 Kg. Cylinder. The price of LPG nearly doubled to about Rs. 34.2 per kg. from about Rs. 17.6 per kg. The 5th International Petroleum Conference – Petrotech 2003 was held in New Delhi from 9.1.2003 to 11.1.2003. The three-day event was preceded by inauguration of an Exhibition by Shri Ram Naik, Minister of Petroleum & Natural Gas at Pragati Maidan, New Delhi. DGH in association with PETRAD of Norway organised a three-day Seminar on "Development of Deepwater Discoveries – Challenges and New Technologies" in New Delhi from 25th to 27th March. Over 350 delegates, scientists and research scholars from India and abroad attended the three-day International Workshop on Hydrogen Energy organised by Indian Oil Corporation from 11th December to 13th December. The Government approved a proposal for implementation of Voluntary Retirement Schemes (VRS) in Oil and Natural Gas Corporation (ONGC) and Indian Oil Corporation (IOC). The approved schemes are in line with the guidelines of Department of Public Enterprises (DPE). In appreciation of the remarkable performance of the special category young boys and girls of India in Special Olympics 2003 at Dublin (Ireland) the oil PSUs donated Rs. One crore to award each of the 34 gold medal winners a cash prize of Rs. 1,00,000/-, 36 silver medal winners Rs. 50,000/- and 40 bronze medal winners Rs. 25,000/- and further made a contribution of Rs. 38,00,000/- to the Special Olympics Bharat Trust which organised the events on behalf of India, thus making the total amount to Rs. 1 crore. IOC donated four Ambulances for the use of people in the Andaman & Nicobar Islands are being donated by Indian Oil Corporation (IOC). These Ambulances will be used for ferrying patients to hospitals in different regions of the Andaman & Nicobar Islands which include Car Nicobar, Rangat, Diglipur and Port Blair. The operations and maintenance of these ambulances will be looked after by the organisations engaged in serving the people across the Andaman & Nicobar Islands. 312 Petrol Pumps & LPG Agencies made operational for the families of Kargil Martyrs. Oil companies in the country are set to launch the nation’s first Hydrogen gas dispensing stations in select cities in the next two to three years, which will serve as a pilot project to prove the efficacy of Hydrogen gas as a clean and environment-friendly automotive fuel. An exclusive fleet of two- and three-wheelers, which can use Hydrogen gas in admixture with CNG (Compressed Natural Gas), would be another option arising out of this pilot project. The Government set up an Independent Inquiry Committee headed by Shri T. S. Vijayaraghavan, a former Secretary to Government of India in the Ministry of Petroleum & Natural Gas to look into the safety and security related aspects of offshore operations of ONGC submitted its interim report on 2.12.2003. The committee was set up in the aftermath of ONGC Copter crash off-Mumbai Coast on 11th August, 2003

pr_title: New Year Greetings of the President APJ Abdul Kalam
pr_content: My Dear Citizens May I greet you for this beautiful year 2004. It is beautiful because the year is promising to be creative. First time our economy is in the ascent phase and nation is confident that we can do it. What can be a greater mission for us other than transforming India into a developed nation, thereby bringing the smiles on the faces of the 260 million people who are below the poverty line. The nation will be projectising the inter linking of rivers. Above all, we can confidently enter into the mission of providing urban facilities in rural areas of our six hundred thousand villages with a population of seven hundred million. My dear citizens, it is natural that we have to face problems and overcome them before achieving our ultimate aim in respect of any mission. We should have the courage of conviction and strength of character to overcome the problems and succeed in our efforts. I have no doubt that we have both these qualities. God is with us. My best wishes to all citizens of our nation for a happy, prosperous and peaceful 2004. (A.P.J. Abdul Kalam)

pr_title: Three Book-Runners appointed to manage the IPO of ONGC
pr_content: The following three Book-runners have been appointed to manage the IPO of 10% of the equity of ONGC: 1. M/s Kotak Mahindra Capital Company Limited 2. M/s DSP Merrill Lynch Limited 3. M/s Morgan Stanley Private Limited ONGC is a Public Sector Undertaking engaged in the exploration and production of crude oil and natural gas. The paid-up capital of the company is Rs. 1425.93 crore. Government of India holds 84.11% of the equity of the company. The issue is being targeted within this financial year. Government proposes to sell up to 10% of the equity of ONGC held by Government through an Officer for Sale in the domestic market using the book-building route.

pr_title: Two Book-Runners appointed to manage the IPO of GAIL
pr_content: The following two Book-Runners have been appointed to manage the IPO of 10% of the equity of GAIL: i) M/s HSBC Capital Markets (India) Pvt. Ltd. ii) M/s ICICI Securities Ltd. Government proposes to sell up to 10% of the equity of GAIL held by Government through an Officer for Sale in the domestic market using the book-building route. The issue is being targeted within this financial year. GAIL (India) Ltd. is a Public Sector Undertaking engaged in the transportation of natural gas and manufacture of LPG and petrochemicals. The paid-up capital of the company is Rs. 845.65 crore. Government of India holds 67.35% of the equity of the company.

pr_title: First phase of Biodiversity characterisation complete report on Andaman Nicobar Islands relesed
pr_content: The first phase of the Biodiversity characterisation at landscape level is complete with the release of the report on Andaman and Nicobar islands. The report on other three priority areas namely North-Eastern region, Western Ghats and Western Himalayas was released in January this year. In all four priority areas were taken up in the first phase by the Department of Biotechnology in collaboration with Department of Space using Satellite Remote Sensing and Geographic Information system. The Andaman and Nicobar islands report was released by eminent scientist Prof. M.G.K.Menon, at a national seminar organised jointly by the two departments here today on “Biodiversity characterisation at landscape level for Bioprospecting”. In his inaugural address, the Chairman ISRO and Secretary, Department of Space, Dr. G. Madhavan Nair said, that with the launching of RESOURCESAT-1, Biodiversity characterisation has become a bit easier. Multi-spectral capability provides us with the kind of resolution which makes the task more accurate and precise. He also said that IRS-1C and IRS-1D have been providing valuable and comprehensive data for the project. He also spoke on the need to preserve and sustain our biodiversity not only for our needs but also for global requirements. Prof. M.G.K.Menon said, the society has been plundering its biodiversity more for greed than for need and it is time that we thought of concrete measures to conserve our ecology, while sustaining the same. They have to go hand in hand. Our rich biodiversity has to be safe-guarded, for it has a significant role in agriculture and health, in the distant future. In her welcome address, the Secretary, Department of Biotechnology, Dr. Manju Sharma said that the second phase of the project has already begun in the remaining important regions like, central India, Eastern Ghats and Mangroves of East Coast. Biodiversity assessment at different levels is of prime importance to evolve conservation strategies and sustainable utilisation, she said.

pr_title: PM greets countrymen on the New Year’s eve
pr_content: The Prime Minister Shri Atal Bihari Vajpayee has greeted the countrymen on the New Year’s eve. In his message the Prime Minister said : “My dear countrymen, kindly accept my greetings for the New Year. The New Year comes with new hopes and new expectations. We have successfully met the challenges of the year by gone. Now we have to mould ourselves according to coming times. I pray to the Almighty that the New Year be auspicious to all of us and bring with it the message of peace and prosperity. Once again I express my heartiest best wishes to all of you. Thank you.”
